In 2018, the company made an agreement with [[Blumhouse Productions]] to co-develop and co-finance low budget Chinese language genre films.{{cite web |last1=Frater |first1=Patrick |title=Jason Blum-Donald Tang Hatch Chinese Genre Film Production Pact |url=https://variety.com/2018/film/asia/jason-blum-donald-tang-china-1202849336/ |website=Variety |accessdate=29 June 2018 |date=18 June 2018}} Global Road's 2018 film distibution slate includes the teen drama ''[[Midnight Sun (2018 film)|Midnight Sun]]'', starring [[Bella Thorne]] and [[Patrick Schwarzenegger]];{{cite news|last=Jerde |first=Sara |url=http://www.adweek.com/agencies/indie-film-studio-global-road-taps-mullenlowe-mediahub-as-agency-of-record/ |title=Indie Film Studio Global Road Taps MullenLowe Mediahub as Agency of Record |work=Adweek |date=2018-01-22 |accessdate=2018-09-11}} family comedy ''[[Show Dogs]]'', starring [[Will Arnett]]; science fiction thriller ''The Silence'', which it acquired for US distribution;{{cite news|last=Tartaglione |first=Nancy |url=http://deadline.com/2018/02/global-road-greg-shapiro-cristina-garza-exit-im-global-1202276440/ |title=IM Global Execs Greg Shapiro, Cristina Garza Exit Global Road Entertainment |work=Deadline |date=2018-02-01 |accessdate=2018-09-11}} the action-thriller ''[[Hotel Artemis]]'', starring [[Jodie Foster]] and [[Sterling K. Brown]];{{cite news|last=Busch |first=Anita |url=http://deadline.com/2018/02/jodie-foster-action-thriller-hotel-artemis-drew-pearce-global-road-1202300131/ |title=Global Road Entertainment Acquires Drew Pearce’s Action Thriller ‘Hotel Artemis’ |work=Deadline |date=2018-02-22 |accessdate=2018-09-11}} science fiction family adventure ''[[A.X.L.]]'';{{cite news|last=Kay |first=Jeremy |url=https://www.screendaily.com/news/global-road-targets-1bn-production-war-chest/5126655.article |title=Global Road targets $1bn production war chest | News | Screen |work=Screendaily |date=2018-02-16 |accessdate=2018-09-11}} and animated family adventure-comedy ''[[Playmobil (film)|Playmobil: Uncharted]]''. executive produced by [[Carla Gugino]] for [[Cinemax]];{{cite news|url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/carla-gugino-star-cinemax-straight-series-crime-drama-jett-1103762 |title=Carla Gugino to Star in Cinemax Straight-to-Series Crime Drama 'Jett' |work=Hollywood Reporter |date=2018-04-18 |accessdate=September 4, 2018}} the reality cooking competition ''Fridge Wars'' for [[Canada]]'s [[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation|CBC]] network;{{cite web |author1=Etan Vlessing |title=Reality Series 'Fridge Wars' in the Works From Global Road Entertainment |url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/reality-series-fridge-wars-works-global-road-entertainment-1111746 |website=The Hollywood Reporter |accessdate=1 August 2018 |date=May 14, 2018}} and global rights to ''[[Idiotest]]'', based on the [[Game Show Network]] quiz show.{{cite web|url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/global-road-entertainment-gets-game-show-business-idiotest-1100864 |title=Global Road Entertainment Gets in the Game Show Business With 'Idiotest' |work=Hollywood Reporter |date=2018-04-09 |accessdate=September 4, 2018}} In January 2018, Global Road signed a development deal with [[Reginald Hudlin]] and Byron Phillips through their company New Nation Networks, under which Hudlin and Phillips would develop and produce original content for Global Road.{{cite web|author=Daniel Holloway |url=https://variety.com/2018/tv/news/global-road-eginald-hudlin-byron-phillips-1202677496/ |title=Global Road Signs Co-Development Deal With Reginald Hudlin, Byron Phillips |work=Variety |date=2018-01-25 |accessdate=September 4, 2018}} Later that month, the company signed a first-look television deal with [[Adam Shankman]] and [[Jennifer Gibgot]]'s production company [[Offspring Entertainment]]; projects announced under this deal include ''Wolfgang'', based on the life of [[Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart]], and an untitled comedy from husband-and-wife actor-producers [[Carlos Pena Jr.|Carlos]] and [[Alexa Vega|Alexa PenaVega]]. Around the same time, Global Road also announced co-development deals with [[France|French]] production company [[Newen]] and the [[Ukraine|Ukrainian]] FILM.UA Group. Global Road's film unit was taken over by its primary lenders, [[Bank of America]] and [[East West Bank]], in August 2018 as [[Donald Tang]] had not raised enough funds for Global Road. Lenders did have Global Roads release ''[[A.X.L.]]'' while stopping the release of "City of Lies" slated for September 7, 2018.{{cite news |last1=McNary |first1=Dave |title=Global Road Layoffs Begin in Los Angeles and London |url=https://variety.com/2018/film/news/global-road-layoffs-1202918992/ |accessdate=September 4, 2018 |work=Variety |date=August 28, 2018}}{{cite news |last1=Lang |first1=Brent |title=Global Road in Crisis: Banks Take Control of Studio |url=https://variety.com/2018/film/news/global-road-in-crisis-banks-take-control-of-studio-1202912690/ |accessdate=September 4, 2018 |work=Variety |date=August 21, 2018}} With A.X.L. not doing well at the box office, the company was forced to layoff employees without severance, a requirement of the lenders. The company was also looking to sell a number of its upcoming films, ''City of Lies'', ''[[The Silence (2018 film)|The Silence]]'' and ''[[Playmobil (film)|Playmobil]]''; it was also 'backing out of' development for ''The Secret Garden''. The company was also sued along with TV rights distributor [[Miramax]] by lender Bank Leumi over loans for ''City of Lies''.{{cite news |last1=Maddaus |first1=Gene |last2=Lang |first2=Brent |title=Global Road on Verge of Bankruptcy Filing |url=https://variety.com/2018/film/news/global-road-bankruptcy-soon-1202923956/ |accessdate=September 4, 2018 |work=Variety |date=September 4, 2018}} On September 6, 2018, Global Road's film unit filed for Chapter 11 Bankruptcy.{{Cite news|url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/thr-esq/global-road-files-bankruptcy-1140266|title=Global Road Files Chapter 11 Bankruptcy for Film Division|work=The Hollywood Reporter|access-date=2018-09-07|language=en}} On October 23, 2018, Global Road filed with the court plans for an auction its assets beginning November 7th with a stalking horse bidder selected with term of $800,000 in expenses coverage and a $2.1 million outbid fee if approve by the judge.{{cite news |last1=Gardner |first1=Eriq |title=Open Road Reaches $87.5 Million Deal With Stalking Horse Bidder |url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/thr-esq/open-road-reaches-875-million-deal-stalking-horse-bidder-1154407 |accessdate=October 23, 2018 |work=The Hollywood Reporter |date=October 23, 2018 |language=en}} In November 2018 after lack luster auction bidding, Open Road agreed to be purchased by Raven Capital Management for $87.5 million pending court approval.{{Cite news|url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/thr-esq/open-road-bankruptcy-auction-called-raven-capital-set-acquire-spotlight-studio-1158472|title=Open Road Bankruptcy: Auction Called Off; Raven Capital Set to Acquire 'Spotlight' Studio|work=The Hollywood Reporter|access-date=2018-11-09|language=en}} ==Management== In August 2017, [[Rob Friedman]] was named Global Road's chairman and CEO.Dave McNary, [https://variety.com/2017/film/awards/tang-media-partners-rebrands-global-road-entertainment-1202602536/ "IM Global, Open Road Owner Tang Media Rebrands as Global Road Entertainment,"] ''Variety'', October 30, 2017. Rodolphe Buet was named president of international in October 2017, and the following month Lynn Harris was named president of worldwide production.Mike Fleming Jr, [http://deadline.com/2017/11/lynn-harris-global-road-worldwide-production-president-rob-friedman-1202215741/ "'Shallows' Producer & Former New Line, WB Exec Lynn Harris Named Global Road WW Production President,"] Deadline.com, November 28, 2017.Pamela McClintock, [https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/global-road-names-lynn-harris-president-worldwide-production-1062107 "Global Road Names Lynn Harris President of Worldwide Production,"] ''The Hollywood Reporter'', November 28, 2017. In early 2018, Jack Pan was named president of worldwide theatrical marketing.Dave McNary, [https://variety.com/2017/film/news/jack-pan-marketing-president-global-road-1202610195/ "Jack Pan Tapped as Marketing President for Global Road Entertainment,"] ''Variety'', November 8, 2017. In March 2018, the company announced several new hires to their international operations division, including Charlotte Van Weede as President of International Sales (replacing Michael Rothstein); Brad Kembel as Executive Vice President of Distribution and Operations; Melissa Martinez as Executive Vice President of International Marketing; and Sarah Genazzani as Director of International Marketing, with Executive Vice President of International Sales Tatyana Joffe extending her contract to work with the new team.{{cite web |author1=Andreas Wiseman |title=Global Road Solidifies International Operations With Key Hires Including Charlotte Van Weede As Sales Chief |url=https://deadline.com/2018/03/global-road-charlotte-van-weede-lionsgate-entertainment-one-1202312399/ |website=Deadline Hollywood |accessdate=1 August 2018 |date=March 6, 2018}} ==Filmography== ===As Open Road Films=== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! {{BLP sources|date=March 2009}} '''Hari Punja''', [[Fijian honours system|OF]], [[OBE]] (born 1936) is an [[Indians in Fiji|Indo-Fijian]] [[Business magnate|businessman]] and Chairman of [[Hari Punja Group of Companies]]. [[Hari Punja and Sons Limited]] is a very diversified (and probably the largest) company in [[Fiji]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.fijitimes.com/story.aspx?id=55844 |accessdate=2010-07-20 |title=Be rich to help poor: Punja |date=January 25, 2007 |newspaper=[[Fiji Times]] }}</ref>
Hari Punja was born in Cuvu, [[Sigatoka]], Fiji and received his education in Fiji and [[Australia]]. He trained as a [[chemical engineer]]. Punja joined the business in 1960. He has served as a mayor of [[Lautoka]]<ref name='tcf'/> and on a number of prestigious boards such as [[Fiji Broadcasting Corporation|Fiji Broadcasting Commission]] and [[Fiji Sugar Corporation]].<ref name='tcf'/> He served as a [[Senate of Fiji|Senator]]<ref name=tcf/> from 1996 to 1999.
Punja has been married to Tara for about fifty years and has five children: Rohit, Ajai, Sanjay, Deepa, Leena.
==Honors== Punja has been bestowed with many credentials and honors. Some of these include:
* [[Order of the British Empire]] (OBE)<ref name='tcf'>{{cite book |title=Twentieth century Fiji |author=Stewart Firth, Daryl Tarte, University of the South Pacific |publisher=USP Solutions, University of the South Pacific |year=2001 |page=198 |url=https://books.google.com/books?ei=UaJGTNGBN43msQOc3oDcAg&ct=result&id=qFNzAAAAMAAJ&dq=order+british++%22hari+punja%22&q=order+british++#search_anchor |accessdate=2010-07-21 }}</ref> * Justice of the Peace (JP) * [[Order of Fiji#Order of Fiji Division|Order of Fiji]]: Bestowed by the [[President of Fiji]], [[Kamisese Mara|Ratu Sir Kaisese Mara]] * The Fiji National Millennium Committee recognized Hari Punja as an outstanding contributor in shaping the nation of Fiji during the 20th Century * He was named as one of the 10 most successful businessmen living outside India in "The Encyclopedia of the Indian Diaspora" (2006) by Professor Dr. Brij Lal ([[Australian National University]]) * Punja was rated the 6th most influential person in the [[Pacific Ocean|Pacific]] region through a poll carried out by the Australian-based [[Pacific Magazine]].
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{authority control}}

{{Infobox company |name = Hellenic Australian Business Council (HABC) |logo = Hellenic Australian Business Council.jpg |type = [[Nonprofit organization]] |foundation = 2012 |location = [[Athens]], Greece |area_served = [[Greece]], [[Australia]], [[European Union]] |key_people = Michalis Bodouroglou <small>(President, HABC)</small>, Ioanna Gouvatsou <small>(Director, HABC)</small> |industry = [[Nonprofit organization]], [[Business]], [[Trade]], [[Investments]] |homepage = [http://www.habc.gr www.habc.gr] }}
The '''Hellenic Australian Business Council''', or '''HABC''' is a non profit trade and investment development agency that supports bilateral business and political relations between [[Greece]] and [[Australia]], as well as providing a forum and platform for information exchange via news, announcements and events such as business forums, roundtables, conferences, missions and road shows.<ref>[http://neoskosmos.com/news/en/greek-australia-business-council-set-up Greek-Australia Business Council established] Retrieved on 16 October 2012, Neos Kosmos</ref> The HABC’s mission is to forge stronger business links between Australia and Greece. Members include key economic and political stakeholders in Greece and Australia: corporations, organisations, trade and investment agencies, as well as distinguished individuals from business, politics, government and academia.<ref>[http://www.greeknewsagenda.gr/2012/10/greece-australia-business-council.html Greek Australian Business Council] Retrieved on 16 October 2012, Greek News Agenda</ref>
==Global network== The Secretariat of the HABC and Director reside in [[Athens]], [[Greece]] with branches in [[Thessaloniki]] and [[Heraklion]]. Meanwhile, strong political and business ties existing in Australia, backed by both the Australian and Greek foreign embassies, as well as leading private enterprises. HABC business partners and members originate from a variety of sectors in both [[Greece]] and [[Australia]].
==History== The Hellenic-Australian Business Council (HABC) was founded in June 2012 in [[Athens]] to connect and support bilateral business relations between [[Greece]] and [[Australia]], including private enterprise, organisations, foreign trade agencies and investments, as well as corporations with significant commercial interests in Greek and Australian markets or SMEs striving to do so. The HABC is the first organisation established in Greece that provides a direct platform and network for Greek and Australian companies, business and industry groups, as well as other organisations to have regular exchange on trade imports-exports, and investment issues.
==Organisational services== The Hellenic-Australian Business Council (HABC)'s mission is to connect and support bilateral business relations between Greece and Australia, including private commercial enterprises, foreign trade agencies, investors, SMEs, organisations, individuals, political figures, as well as others with significant business interests in the Greek and/or Australian markets - boosting trade.<ref>[http://neoskosmos.com/news/en/plugging-the-trade-gap Plugging the trade gap] Retrieved on 18 April 2012, Neos Kosmos</ref> From trade exports and imports, investment opportunities in key sectors relevant to each market, education prospects, to information on starting a business in Australia and Greece, the HABC is a non-profit, non-governmental agency. HABC endorses members and offers them an avenue to connect with the right trade, investment and business partners. HABC’s services include: * Members directory platform to search and connect with possible business and political partners in Greece and Australia * Participation in events: business seminars, conferences, business missions, corporate forums, luncheons, receptions, roundtables and other functions * Business and political networking possibilities * Trade/investment support mechanisms * Media and information: website, special announcements, press releases, newsletters, multimedia * Identification and promotion of trade and investment opportunities in both Greece and Australia * Market/sector information on Greece and Australia, including general business environment, economy, politics, sectors, doing business * On-the-ground support, through partnerships/allies in both Australia and Greece
==Governance== HABC is a [[Nonprofit organization]] registered in Greece as an association. It is a non-governmental, non-political association governed by a Board of Directors elected by Members. The Board of Directors, elected for one year from founding members, has the task of attracting new members and driving initiatives and the organisation’s charter. Corporate membership and event sponsorship is the sole source of funding for the Business Council.
;Board of the Hellenic Australian Business Council <ref>[http://www.habc.gr/habc_board.asp HABC Board] Retrieved on 12 March 2013, Hellenic Australian Business Council</ref> * President, Mr Michalis Bodouroglou, President and CEO of shipping group Allseas Marine S.A. * V. President, Mr Christos Folias, CEO of Folias & Associates / ex-Minister of Development * G. Secretary, Dr Antonis Markopoulos, Deputy Managing Director Asia Pacific, Intralot * Treasurer, Mrs Annie Michaelides, Executive V. President of Ε.ΒΙ.Ε-I. Michailides S.A.
;Members & Deputy Members <ref>[http://www.habc.gr/habc_board.asp HABC Board] Retrieved on 12 March 2013, Hellenic Australian Business Council</ref> * Captain Panayiotis N. Tsakos, Founder of the Tsakos Group of Companies * Mr Antonis Adamopoulos, President and CEO of Shelman-Alfawood * Mr Emmanuel Domazakis, CEO of Creta Farms * Mr Konstantinos Salonikis, CEO and General Manager of Thrace Minerals * Mr Konstantinos Koronakis, President of D. Koronakis * Mr Stefanos Tsipas, President of Denima * Mr Nicolas Fournarakis, President of Vandomus * Mrs Christina Sakellaridis, President of PanHellenic Exporters Association * Mr Athanasios Lavidas, President of Lavipharm * Mr Athanasios Tzikas, President and CEO of Thessaloniki International Fair
;Secretariat & Managing Director * Ms Ioanna Gouvatsou, Director of Hellenic Australian Business Council
==Official partners== HABC’s official partners include bilateral Chambers of Commerce (Hellenic-Australian Chambers of Commerce and Industry),<ref>[http://au.greekreporter.com/2012/12/12/bloomfield-hacci-want-closer-greek-aussie-relations/ Greek Australia Reporter] Retrieved on 12 December 2012, Greek Australia Reporter</ref> the Australian Embassy in Athens, the Greek Embassy in [[Canberra]], Australia, and [[Consulates]] throughout the country, as well as official government agencies and organisations that support trade and investment in both countries, such as Invest in Greece and [[Austrade]]. Former Australian [[Ambassador]] to Greece, [[Albania]] and [[Bulgaria]], H.E. Mrs Jenny Bloomfield - Department for Foreign Affairs and Trade ‘Ambassadors’ is an honorary member of the Hellenic Australian Business Council, and was influential in its establishment.<ref>[http://www.greece.embassy.gov.au/athn/home.html Australian Embassy Greece] Retrieved on 12 March 2013, Australian [[Embassy]] Greece</ref>
[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Pu7e9phgFcA Ms Jenny Bloomfield is Australia's Ambassador to Greece and non-resident Ambassador to Bulgaria and Albania. Here she discusses the strong community links and the growing trade relationship between Australia and Greece. She also discusses Australia's relations with Albania and Bulgaria.]
== See also == * [[Economy of Australia|Australian economy]] * [[Economy of Greece|Greek economy]] * [[List of High Commissioners and Ambassadors of Australia]] * [[Austrade]] - Australian Government's trade, investment and education promotion agency
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== ;Official * [http://www.habc.gr Hellenic Australian Business Council (HABC)] * [http://www.austrade.gov.au/Invest Invest in Australia] * [http://www.investingreece.gov.gr/ Invest in Greece]
[[Category:Foreign trade of Australia]] [[Category:Business organizations based in Greece]] [[Category:European Union member economies|Greece]] [[Category:Australia–Greece relations]] [[Category:Business organisations based in Australia]]

{{Infobox Software | name = i-net Clear Reports (formerly i-net Crystal-Clear) | logo = | screenshot = [[Image:inetDesignerXML.jpg|300px|i-net Designer Screenshot]] | caption = | developer = [http://www.inetsoftware.de i-net software] | released = 1999 | latest_release_version = 11.0 | latest_release_date = May 16, 2011 | programming language = [[Java (programming language)|Java]], [[.NET Framework|.NET]] | operating system = [[Cross-platform]] | language = English, German, Spanish | genre = [[Reporting software]] | license = [http://www.inetsoftware.de i-net software] [[Software license agreement|EULA]] | website = [http://www.inetsoftware.de/products/crystal-clear inetsoftware.de/crystalclear] }}
'''i-net Clear Reports''' (formerly known as i-net Crystal-Clear) is a Java-based cross-platform reporting application providing a [[report]] designer and a server component to create reports in numerous output formats like PDF, HTML, PS, RTF, XLS, TXT, CSV, SVG, XML, as well as being viewable in a Java applet or Swing component.<ref name="Freshmeat">{{cite web |url = http://freshmeat.net/projects/crystalclear |title = i-net Clear Reports / freshmeat.net |date = May 15, 2009 |accessdate = 2009-05-18 }}</ref> Application programmers can integrate i-net Clear Reports using the public [[API]] which spans over 200 classes.<ref name="API">{{cite web |url=http://www.inetsoftware.de/documentation/clear-reports/online-help/programming/apispec/index.html |title = i-net Clear Reports API |date = May 17, 2011 |accessdate = 2011-05-17 }}</ref> Starting with release 11.0 i-net Clear Reports also supports the [[.NET Framework|.NET]] programming language and offers a public API for further integration in other products.
==History== in Version 11.0 i-net Crystal-Clear was renamed to i-net Clear Reports. At this time it also gained .NET integration as a major feature.
i-net Crystal-Clear was primarily designed to read [[Crystal Reports]] templates. It had to be capable of reading the RPT report format and producing a reasonable output. For exporting and saving reasons a new file format had to be created later on, enabling Crystal-Clear to save the API results back and make them editable by a designer.<ref name="History">{{cite web |url=http://www.inetsoftware.de/products/clear-reports/developement-timeline |title = Development Timeline |date = March 17, 2011 |accessdate = 2011-05-17 }}</ref>
In 2002 the first version of i-net DesignerXML, the report designer, was written using Java Swing. The editing concept is slightly different from some other designers, using a band-oriented report template format, meaning that reports are designed based on rows of data.
The development efforts has changed in more recent years to a full reporting platform approach, rather than the developer-only, framework-based one.
True to its roots, i-net Crystal-Clear still has the ability to read and execute Crystal Reports report templates up until the latest versions of Crystal Reports.
Unlike Crystal Reports, however, the i-net Crystal-Clear report file format has always been an open format. Until version 9.0 it was an XML format. Since version 9, the report file format is in a [[ZIP (file format)|zip]]-based format similar to [[OpenDocument]].
==Flexibility==
Being a Java application, i-net Clear Reports has the ability to run on a variety of platforms and environments. There is virtually no restriction concerning data sources that can be used, as long as there is a [[JDBC]] driver available for accessing the data. For non-JDBC data sources, there are how-to's to write simple mini-drivers. With the new .NET API it got even more flexible and allows integration into .NET based applications.
i-net Clear Reports comes as a standalone server as well as a [[servlet]] which can be run on any [[Java EE]] application server such as [[Apache Tomcat|Tomcat]], [[Jetty]], [[Internet Information Services|IIS]], or [[Apache HTTP Server|Apache]] (via [[PHP]]).
Features can be added using the public [[API]], or by adding custom [[JavaBeans]] which can be added to reports. User defined functions (UDF) extend the formula features of the embedded formula calculation routines.
==Notes and references== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.inetsoftware.de/products/clear-reports i-net Clear Reports Homepage] * [http://www.inetsoftware.de/products/clear-reports/samples Sample Reports] * [http://www.inetsoftware.de/products/clear-reports/screenshots Screenshots]
{{DEFAULTSORT:I-Net Clear Reports}} [[Category:Java platform software]] [[Category:.NET Framework software]] [[Category:Reporting software]] [[Category:Business intelligence]]

{{Infobox person | name = Joaquín Bau Nolla | image = Joaquin Bau.png | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = Joaquín Bau Nolla | birth_date = 1897 | birth_place = [[Tortosa]], Spain | death_date = 1973 | nationality = [[Spaniards|Spanish]] | death_place = [[Madrid]], Spain | body_discovered = | death_cause = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = <!-- {{coord|LAT|LONG|display=inline,title}} --> | citizenship = | other_names = | known_for = Politician | education = | alma_mater = | employer = | notable works = | occupation = lawyer, politician | years_active = | home_town = | salary = | networth = | height = | weight = | title = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party = [[Spanish Patriotic Union|Unión Patriótica]], [[:es:Comunion Tradicionalista|CT]], [[Falange|FET]] | opponents = | boards = | spouse = | partner = | children = | parents = | relations = | callsign = | awards = | signature = | signature_alt = | website = | footnotes = | box_width = | misc = }} '''Joaquín Bau Nolla''' (1897–1973) was a [[Spaniards|Spanish]] [[Carlism|Carlist]] and [[Francoism|Francoist]] politician.
==Family and youth== [[File:Tortosa - Casa Bau 2.JPG|thumbnail|160px|left|Casa Bau, Tortosa]] Joaquín Bau Nolla was born to a [[bourgeoisie]] [[Catalans|Catalan]] family. His paternal grandfather [[Miguel Bau Isern]] (1836-1911) ran a chocolate manufacture in [[Tortosa]]<ref>Joaquín Monserrat Cavaller, ''Joaquín Bau Nolla y la restauración de la Monarquía'', Madrid 2001, {{ISBN|8487863949}}, p. 20</ref> and served as mayor of the city in 1901-1903,<ref>Monserrat Cavaller 2001, p. 20</ref> co-founding Banc de Tortosa,<ref>Emili Llorente, ''La fundació del Banc de Tortosa (1881)'', [in:] ''Recerca'' 9 (2005), p. 261</ref> Cambra Agricola de Tortosa and the local Cambra de Comerç.<ref>Roc Salvadó Poy, ''L'Escola del Treball perilla'', [in:] ''Quaderns de l'Elbe'' 1 (2010), p. 11, ''Miquel Bau i Isern'' entry at ''ilercavonia'' service,</ref> One of his 16 children<ref>according to an anecdote, one of his children did some damage to his shop; Bau Isern summoned the culprit and commenced the interrogation by asking angrily "who is your father?". "You are, sir" – responded the frightened offender, referred after Monserrat Cavaller 2001, p. 20</ref> and Joaquin's father,<ref>some sources claim Jose Bau Verges was brother of Miguel Bau Isern, see Llorente 2005, p. 283</ref> [[José Bau Vergés]] (1868-1935), was an oil and vinegar trader and producer. He grew from a local merchant, transporting oil on his mules,<ref>Monserrat Cavaller 2001, p. 21</ref> to "el rei de l'oli",<ref>Llorente 2005, p. 283</ref> the owner of Aceites Bau S.A., a Tortosa-based company operating two factories,<ref>Monserrat Cavaller 2001, pp. 21-2</ref> selling on the national Spanish market and exporting to South America, especially to [[Argentina]]. Following the commercial success, Bau Vergés built an imposing family residence in Tortosa; he was also honorary consul of [[Uruguay]] and Argentina,<ref>Salvadó Poy 2010, p. 12</ref> member of local business organizations and a Catholic activist.<ref>Monserrat Cavaller 2001, p. 21</ref> In 1894 he married María Cinta Nolla Poy,<ref>''Josep Bau i Vergés'' entry at ''ilercavonia'' service</ref> a [[stonemason]]'s daughter.<ref>it is not clear whether she was anyhow related to the Carlist general and organizer of Carlist hospital network during the Third Carlist War, also a tortosino, [[Ramón Nolla Marti]]</ref> The couple had 4 children, all brought up in highly religious ambience; Joaquín was their second son.<ref>''Josep Bau i Vergés'' entry at ''ilercavonia'' service</ref>
Following his early education in Colegio de San Pedro Apóstol of the Hermanos de las Escuelas Cristianas in Tortosa,<ref>Monserrat Cavaller 2001, p. 22</ref> the young Joaquín obtained his bachillerato in [[:es:Colegio La Salle Bonanova|Colegio de la Bonanova de los Hermanos de La Salle]] in [[Barcelona]],<ref>Monserrat Cavaller 2001, p. 23</ref> to complete military service in Regimiento de guarnición of [[Tarragona]] in 1921.<ref>Monserrat Cavaller 2001, p. 27</ref> Encouraged by his father, he passed commercial [[broker]] exams and rose to president of Junta Central de Corredores de Commercio de España in 1935.<ref>Monserrat Cavaller 2001, p. 23</ref> In 1933 he commenced law studies as unenrolled student and graduated from Faculty of Law of [[University of Valencia|Universidad de Valencia]] in 1935.<ref>Monserrat Cavaller 2001, p. 23-4</ref> In 1920 Joaquín Bau married Pilar Elisa Carpi Esteller.<ref>''Joaquín Bau Nolla, 1. Conde de Bau'' entry at ''geneallnet'' service, available [http://geneall.net/es/name/2177898/joaquin-bau-nolla-1-conde-de-bau/ here]</ref> The couple had 5 children;<ref>''Joaquín Bau Nolla, 1. Conde de Bau entry'' at ''geneallnet''</ref> the oldest son Joaquín as a 16-year-old volunteered to the Carlist [[requeté]] unit, survived the [[Spanish Civil War|Civil War]]<ref>Monserrat Cavaller 2001, p. 222</ref> and later became an engineer; José Luis served in the army as a lieutenant colonel and military judge, while Fernando practiced as a lawyer and a conservative politician. Between 1967 and 1977 he served in the Francoist [[Cortes Españolas|Cortes]];<ref>See the official Cortes service available [http://www.congreso.es/portal/page/portal/Congreso/Congreso/SDocum/ArchCon/SDHistoDipu/SDIndHistDip?_piref73_1340024_73_1340023_1340023.next_page=/wc/servidorCGI&CMD=VERLST&BASE=DIPH&FMT=DIPHXLDA.fmt&DOCS=1-25&DOCORDER=FIFO&OPDEF=Y&QUERY=%2813190%29.NDIP. here]</ref> in 1991 he published ''Crònica de veinte años. 1957-1977''.<ref>Compare abebooks service, available [http://www.abebooks.com/Cr%C3%B3nica-veinte-a%C3%B1os-1957-1977-Bau-Carpi/7915667420/bd here]</ref>
==Mayor== [[File:Ebrostraßenbrücke.JPG|thumbnail|left|[[Ebro]] in Tortosa]] Though Joaquín's paternal grandfather was a [[Liberal Party (Spain, 1880)|Liberal]]<ref>''Miquel Bau i Isern'' entry at ''ilercavonia'' service</ref> his father was already reported as [[Traditionalism (Spain)|Traditionalist]]<ref>Monserrat Cavaller 2001, p. 24</ref> and it was in his footsteps that Joaquín followed. As a youngster and teenager Bau engaged in local Traditionalist juvenile organisations. He became head of the Tortosa section of Requeté, a formation established in 1909 as a sporting and outdoor grouping for the Carlist youth.<ref>Monserrat Cavaller 2001, pp. 24-5</ref> He seemed particularly fond of social and charity initiatives, organising Christmas for the poor, working in Patronato Escolar Obrero de la Sagrada Familia and co-founding Sindicatos Católicos Obreros.<ref>Monserrat Cavaller 2001, p. 24</ref> In the early 1920s he already emerged as a dynamic local politician. Once [[Primo de Rivera]] replaced the liberal [[Restoration (Spain)|restauración]] with dictatorship, Bau enthusiastically engaged in the nascent primoderiverista structures; in 1924 he co-founded the Tortosa branch of [[Spanish Patriotic Union|Unión Patriótica]] and became its jefe provincial.<ref>Monserrat Cavaller 2001, p. 77</ref>
During the period called "Bauisme" in the history of Tortosa,<ref>Joan Sabaté Borràs, ''Els Ajuntaments republicans i els anys del Bauisme (1915 - 1930)'', [in:] ''Cent anys de crònica de Tortosa des del Centre de Comerç'', Tortosa 2001, {{ISBN|846072851X}}, pp. 77-85</ref> in 1925 Bau was unanimously elected mayor of the city,<ref>Monserrat Cavaller 2001, p. 29</ref> re-elected in 1928 and holding the post until 1930.<ref>Monserrat Cavaller 2001, p. 33</ref> His contribution was multifold; during 5 years the Bau-led [[ayuntamiento]] executed the plan of public works, consisting of modernization of city streets, refurbishment of public schools and hospitals and setting up regular fire brigade services.<ref>Monserrat Cavaller 2001, pp. 29-30</ref> He inaugurated [[Instituto Nacional de Segunda Ensenanza]] and [[Escuela de Trabajo]],<ref>Salvadó Poy 2010, p. 3</ref> expanded local railway line and enhanced the county road network.<ref>Monserrat Cavaller 2001, pp. 30, 39-40</ref> Much of his activity was about tackling [[Ebro]]-related issues, like floods, navigation, bridges or land re-cultivation.<ref>Monserrat Cavaller 2001, pp. 30-31</ref> Largely successful and sort of celebrated by [[Alfonso XIII of Spain|Alfonso de Borbón]] and the dictator as one of the youngest mayors,<ref>Monserrat Cavaller 2001, p. 36</ref> he nevertheless failed in his attempt to elevate Tortosa - since 1833 part of the [[Tarragona province]] - to the provincial capital range, the new unit to be carved out from these of Tarragona, [[Castellón Province|Castellón]] and [[Teruel Province|Teruel]].<ref>Monserrat Cavaller 2001, pp. 40, 45</ref> [[File:FFR.98.4.JPG|thumbnail|Bau as alcalde (1st from L), 1925]] Though dictatorship was initially welcomed by the Carlists as a stepping stone towards a Traditionalist monarchy, in 1925 the claimant [[Jaime, Duke of Madrid|Don Jaime]] switched to opposition. Bau decided not to follow suit and went on contributing to the regime; in literature he is usually listed along [[Víctor Pradera Larumbe|Victor Pradera]] and [[Esteban de Bilbao Eguía|Esteban Bilbao]] as one of those Carlists who abandoned their king and joined the primoderiverista version of the [[Alfonsism|Alfonsine]] monarchy.<ref>Robert Vallverdú i Martí, ''El Carlisme Català Durant La Segona República Espanyola 1931-1936'', Barcelona 2008, {{ISBN|9788478260805}}, p. 18, Jordi Canal i Morell, ''El carlismo: dos siglos de contrarrevolución en España'', Madrid 2000, {{ISBN|8420639478}}, pp. 285-6</ref> In 1927 he was appointed to the quasi-parliament, [[:es:Asamblea Nacional Consultiva|Asamblea Nacional Consultiva]], standing as representative of Organizaciones provinciales de Unión Patriótica<ref>see official Cortes service available [http://www.congreso.es/portal/page/portal/Congreso/Congreso/Iniciativas?_piref73_2148295_73_1335437_1335437.next_page=/wc/servidorCGI&CMD=VERLST&BASE=DIPH&FMT=DIPHXD1S.fmt&DOCS=1-1&DOCORDER=FIFO&OPDEF=Y&NUM1=&DES1=&QUERY=%2813200%29.NDIP. here]</ref> and representative of the Ayuntamientos;<ref>See official Cortes service available [http://www.congreso.es/portal/page/portal/Congreso/Congreso/Iniciativas?_piref73_2148295_73_1335437_1335437.next_page=/wc/servidorCGI&CMD=VERLST&BASE=DIPH&FMT=DIPHXD1S.fmt&DOCS=2-2&DOCORDER=FIFO&OPDEF=Y&NUM1=&DES1=&QUERY=%2813200%29.NDIP here].</ref> in the chamber he became one of the youngest members. He kept supporting the dictator by staging welcome celebrations in Tortosa and organizing manifestations of tortosinos in Madrid in 1928.<ref>Monserrat Cavaller 2001, pp. 34-5</ref> In 1929 Bau was re-elected jefe of the local Unión Patriótica, engaged in [[:es:Somatén|Somatén]],<ref>Monserrat Cavaller 2001, p. 38</ref> animated the youth branch named Juventud Patriótica<ref>Monserrat Cavaller 2001, pp. 38-9</ref> and until 1930s financed a local Tortosa periodical, ''Unión Patriótica''.<ref>Monserrat Cavaller 2001, p. 77</ref> He is deemed responsible for 1929 expulsion from the city of [[:es:Marcelino Domingo|Marcelino Domingo]], at that time a [[Republicanism in Spain|Republican]] activist in serious health condition.<ref>Josep Sànchez i Cervelló (ed.), ''El republicanisme a les Terres de l'Ebre'', Tarragona 2007, {{ISBN|8461165705}}, p. 28</ref>
==Deputy== [[File:Flag of Cross of Burgundy.svg|thumbnail|220px|left|Carlist standard]] Bau ceased as Tortosa mayor in 1930;<ref>Sànchez i Cervelló 2007, p. 28; there are no details provided on termination of Bau's service as mayor</ref> in 1931 he was accused of financial irregularities, though none of the charges raised has been concluded.<ref>Monserrat Cavaller 2001, pp. 47-50</ref> As three Traditionalist branches united in 1932 Bau resumed his service to the legitimist king rejoining the Carlist organization, [[:es:Comunión Tradicionalista|Comunión Tradicionalista]]. Within its structures he was heading the local Tortosa Requeté;<ref>Vallverdú 2008, p. 148</ref> as member of the Tarragona branch he had to accept leadership of the provincial jefe, Juan Maria Roma.<ref>Antonio Manuel Moral Roncal, ''La cuestión religiosa en la Segunda República española. Iglesia y carlismo'', Madrid, 2009, {{ISBN|9788497429054}}, p. 78</ref> In the [[Spanish general election, 1933|1933 elections]] he represented Carlism within the local Tarragonese [[Unió Ciutadana]] alliance<ref>Vallverdú 2008, p. 147</ref> and was successfully elected.<ref>see 1933 entry at the official Cortes service, available [http://www.congreso.es/portal/page/portal/Congreso/Congreso/Iniciativas?_piref73_2148295_73_1335437_1335437.next_page=/wc/servidorCGI&CMD=VERLST&BASE=DIPH&FMT=DIPHXD1S.fmt&DOCS=3-3&DOCORDER=FIFO&OPDEF=Y&NUM1=&DES1=&QUERY=%2813200%29.NDIP. here]. He was second-last on the Unió Ciutadana list elected, Vallverdú 2008, p. 151</ref> As a result, he emerged one of key figures in the [[Levante, Spain|Levantine]] Carlism,<ref>''El Siglo Futuro'' 18.12.34, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000534141&page=2 here]</ref> especially in the comarcas of [[Terres de l'Ebre]],<ref>Vallverdú 2008, p. 149</ref> though following the death of [[Jaime Chicharro Sánchez-Guió|Jaime Chicharro]] also in Castellón.<ref>"Chicharro ha muerto. Viva Bau! Ya tenemos jefe", quoted after Monserrat Cavaller 2001, p. 56</ref>
Voicing his support for the Catalan identity<ref>"Cataluna, señores diputados, siente y quiere un regimen de autonomia", quoted after Monserrat Cavaller 2001, p. 54</ref> Bau has nevertheless opposed the adopted [[:ca:Estatut d'Autonomia de Catalunya de 1932|autonomous statute]]<ref>''Joaquim Bau i Nolla'' at ''Gran Enciclopédia Catalana'' online service, available [http://www.enciclopedia.cat/EC-GEC-0008374.xml#.UwTaqWJ5PIA here]</ref> as irreconcilable with the Spanish raison d'etat and produced by "traidores a su Patria y a su honor".<ref>Vallverdú 2008, pp. 202-3</ref> He demanded its derogation<ref>according to Bau, the autonomy served "el mas duro de los centralismos y la mas fuerte de la tiranias", probably a reference to the unitarian nature of Catalan autonomy, neglecting the provincial differences, quoted after Vallverdú 2008, pp. 202-3</ref> and replacement with a new autonomous statute, constructed along Traditionalist lines and properly reflecting the genuine personality of Catalonia.<ref>Vallverdú 2008, pp. 202-3, Monserrat Cavaller 2001, pp. 54-5</ref> He sided with [[Francesc Cambó]] against the Catalan left-wing autonomism<ref>Monserrat Cavaller 2001, p. 54</ref> and supported Catalan landowners in the notorious [[Catalan Leases Act]] case.<ref>Martin Blinkhorn, ''Carlism and Crisis in Spain 1931-1939'', Cambridge 2008, {{ISBN|9780521207294}}, 9780521086349, p. 186</ref> He also encouraged new Christian syndicates of the Tarragona province, confederated in [[Agrupacion Gremial de Trabajadores]].<ref>Bau claimed he was the founder of the unions, Monserrat Cavaller 2001, p. 78; other sources point to [[Tomàs Caylà]] as their moving spirit, see Joan Guinovart i Escarré, ''Tomàs Caylà, un home de la terra'', Valls 1997, {{ISBN|8492147679}}, 9788492147670</ref> In October 1934 he was active mounting local opposition to the [[October 1934 Revolution|revolutionary sway]];<ref>Sànchez i Cervelló 2007, p. 43</ref> his close collaborator, [[:es:José María Sentís Simeón|Jose Maria Sentis Simeon]], co-ordinated action against the rebels in the province and was later appointed governors' delegate for Public Order.<ref>Monserrat Cavaller 2001, p. 79</ref> In 1935 Bau arranged for [[Guardia de Asalto]] detachment to be stationed in Tortosa.<ref>Monserrat Cavaller 2001, p. 59</ref> [[File:LLO.98.13.JPG|thumbnail|150px|[[José Calvo Sotelo|Calvo Sotelo]]]] By many Carlists Bau was viewed with suspicion. This was due to his enthusiasm when engaging in alliance talks with the Alfonsinos<ref>Compare Vallverdú 2008, pp. 278, 281, Canal i Morell 2000, p. 318. Bau did not take part in common Catalan Right-wing initiatives, as he is not listed in José Fernando Mota Muñoz, ''"Precursores de la unificación": el España Club y el voluntariado español, una experiencia unitaria de la extrema derecha barcelonesa (1935-1936)'', [in:] ''Historia y politica'' 28 (2012), pp. 273-303</ref> and personal friendship with their leader, [[José Calvo Sotelo]];<ref>Blinkhorn 2008, p. 190, Vallverdú 2008, p. 192, Monserrat Cavaller 2001, p. 105. In 1935, after the death of Bau's father, the family moved to Madrid; as Calvo's close friend Bau and his family lived in the very same building, Monserrat Cavaller 2001, p. 75</ref> though new Traditionalist jefe [[Manuel Fal Conde|Manuel Fal]] approached [[Bloque Nacional (Spanish alliance of 1930s)|Bloque Nacional]] as tactical option to be eventually abandoned, Bau was suspected of pushing for a dynastical compromise. In the spring of 1935 [[Alfonso Carlos, Duke of San Jaime|Don Alfonso Carlos]] and Fal considered Bau's activity in the Bloque intolerable and semi-rebellious.<ref>Valverdú 2008, pp. 190-192. In December 1935 Bau was notably absent during a meeting of Fal and the Catalan executive, Valverdú 2008 p. 193. On the other hand, Monserrat Cavaller 2001, p. 58-59 claims that when Fal left the regional Catalan gathering in June 1935 it was Joaquín Bau taking over the presidency</ref> Also present-day scholars name his position as "conspiration",<ref>Vallverdú 2008, p. 281</ref> while others claim that he was loyal to Calvo rather than to Traditionalism.<ref>Colin M. Winston, ''Workers and the Right in Spain, 1900-1936'', Princeton 2014, {{ISBN|9780691612164}}, p. 305</ref> However, he was allowed to speak at massive Carlist meetings in [[Poblet]]<ref>in June 1935, Valverdú 2008, p. 267; Bau claimed credit for staging the event, noting only that "mis amigos los señores Bru y Caylá, que tan bien me han ayudado y han cooperado a la realización de la gran concentración do Poblet", see ''El Siglo Futuro'' 20.06.35, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000546803&page=2 here], see also Monserrat Cavaller 2001, pp. 57-8</ref> and at [[Santa Maria de Montserrat Abbey|Montserrat]];<ref>in October 1935, Valverdú 2008, p. 272</ref> he was also appointed to the Carlist Council of Economy.<ref>In the spring of 1935; the council was an 8-member body called to manage Carlist financial issues, Valverdú 2008, p. 276</ref>
Prior to the [[Spanish general election, 1936|1936 elections]] Bau advocated the strategy of a [[Electoral Carlism (Second Republic)|broad Right-wing alliance]],<ref>Valverdú 2008, p. 286</ref> an option which has never materialized; himself he competed on the list of [[Front Català d'Ordre]]<ref>Josep Santesmases i Ollé, ''De les eleccions del 16 de febrer de 1936 a l'entrada dels "nacionals". Notícies de les actes municipals de Vila-rodona'', [in:] ''La Resclosa'' 7 (2003), p. 102; Monserrat Cavaller 2001, p. 69</ref> and was elected from Tarragona.<ref>See 1936 Bau entry at the official Cortes service, available [http://www.congreso.es/portal/page/portal/Congreso/Congreso/Iniciativas?_piref73_2148295_73_1335437_1335437.next_page=/wc/servidorCGI&CMD=VERLST&BASE=DIPH&FMT=DIPHXD1S.fmt&DOCS=4-4&DOCORDER=FIFO&OPDEF=Y&NUM1=&DES1=&QUERY=%2813200%29.NDIP. here] Bau could have boasted a symbolic success, since he was the sole monarchist deputy from all the Levantine provinces, Monserrat Cavaller 2001, p. 53</ref> Shortly after the [[Popular Front (Spain)|Frente Popular]] triumph was declared Bau and Calvo visited the prime minister [[Manuel Portela Valladares|Portela Valladares]] urging him to call the military and rule by decree; this was probably the most charged moment in his entire career.<ref>Monserrat Cavaller 2001, pp. 93-4, Paul Preston, ''Franco. A biography'', London 2011, {{ISBN|9780006862109}}, p. 118</ref> Once [[Lorenzo Maria Alier]] resigned as Carlist Catalan jefe in February 1936 one of the options considered was a triumvirate including Bau,<ref>other members of the triumvirate suggested were Joaquin Roma and Joaquin Gomis; this proposal was put forward by the Carlist provincial Girona council, Vallverdú 2008, p. 300</ref> but eventually it was [[Tomàs Caylà]] appointed the new regional leader.
==Commissioner== [[File:JoséSanjurjo.jpg|160px|thumbnail|left|[[José Sanjurjo|general Sanjurjo]]]] Though until the summer of 1936 Bau was active in the Cortes,<ref>sponsoring a motion to make Ebro navigable around [[Flix]] on June 26, 1936, Monserrat Cavaller 2001, p. 72</ref> he was heavily engaged in anti-Republican conspiracy, serving as a Carlist link to [[Renovación Española]].<ref>Blinkhorn 2008, pp. 238, 247, Vallverdú 2008, p. 310. Possibly Bau has even communicated with Franco, at that time stationed time on Canary Islands; Bau's personal archive contains a Spanish-English dictionary serving as key to encrypted correspondence with Franco, Monserrat Cavaller 2001, p. 115</ref> Following the death of Calvo Sotelo he travelled to [[Portugal]]<ref>he travelled by train on July 15 and narrowly escaped detention quoting his parliamentarian immunity, Monserrat Cavaller 2001, p. 76</ref> to negotiate details of the rebellion with [[José Sanjurjo]], personally witnessing the crash of general's aircraft.<ref>Blinkhorn 2008, p. 354; one of the factors usually quoted as cause of the crash was overloading of the small aircraft, as Sanjurjo insisted on taking his massive luggage containing uniforms and other garment; Bau lent Sanjurjo his sombrero, collected from the crash site and returned to Bau by Sanjurjo's widow 30 years later, Monserrat Cavaller 2001, p. 20</ref> Since Bau was originally scheduled to communicate uprising orders to requeté units in southern Catalonia, his departure impaired Carlist insurgent structures in Terres de l'Ebre.<ref>Vallverdú 2008, p. 332</ref> Shortly after the [[Spanish coup of July 1936|hostilities broke out]] he returned from Portugal to [[Burgos]] in the [[Nationalist faction (Spanish Civil War)|Nationalist zone]].
Early September 1936<ref>on September 4, 1936, Monserrat Cavaller 2001, p. 121</ref> the supreme governing body of the rebels, [[:es:Junta de Defensa Nacional|Junta de Defensa Nacional]], constituted [[Comisión de Industria y Comercio]], a substitute for Ministry of Economy. Bau, considered by [[Francisco Franco|Franco]] one of the more collaborative Carlists,<ref>Blinkhorn 2008, p. 272</ref> was appointed one of its seven members;<ref>Monserrat Cavaller 2001, p. 122</ref> his high nomination was allegedly related to ability to arrange finance through Catalan contacts who had fled abroad.<ref>Michael Richards, ''A Time of Silence: Civil War and the Culture of Repression in Franco's Spain, 1936-1945'', Cambridge 2006, {{ISBN|9780521025065}}, p. 107; Paul Preston, ''Coming of the Spanish Civil War'', Routledge 2003, {{ISBN|9781134923274}}, p. 278, claims that within a "motley band of aristocrats, diplomats and politicians" Joaquín Bau "played a vital role in organizing the purchase of arms and other supplies, propaganda and financial assistance for the rebel cause", claiming also that Bau was Franco's friend</ref> A month later<ref>On October 7, 1936, Monserrat Cavaller 2001, p. 125</ref> the newly established [[:es:Junta Técnica del Estado|Junta Técnica del Estado]] set up [[Comisión de Industria, Comercio y Abastos]] with Bau appointed its president,<ref>Monserrat Cavaller 2001, pp. 123-124</ref> the de facto minister of economy in the Nationalist zone. As head of 7 commissions formed and one of 16 members of the Junta Técnica, he rapidly grew to top Nationalist executive.<ref>Carlos Pulpillo Leiva, ''Orígenes del Franquismo: la construcción de la "Nueva España" (1936–1941)'', [PhD thesis], Madrid 2013, p. 767</ref>
Bau's primary task was to keep production running and to build the gold deposit reserve of the Nationalists;<ref>Monserrat Cavaller 2001, pp. 126-7</ref> he was subsequently involved in currency reform, first organizing the stamping of pre-War notes and then arranging for a new Nationalist [[Spanish peseta|peseta]] to be printed in [[Nazi Germany|Germany]].<ref>Monserrat Cavaller 2001, pp. 128-130</ref> The next objective was to control foreign trade and direct the flow of deficient components accordingly, which was attempted by numerous regulatory means. At that time Bau considered himself an advocate of the "directed" economy;<ref>Monserrat Cavaller 2001, pp. 130-134, 156-157. Bau spoke in favor of rapid industrialization, declaring respect for private property, though within the limits of social usefulness, Monserrat Cavaller 2001, p. 154</ref> as an economist he was considered a disciple of Calvo Sotelo.<ref>Monserrat Cavaller 2001, p. 156</ref> Heavily involved in dealings with semi-official Nazi companies, [[Sociedad Hispano-Marroquí de Transportes|HISMA]] and [[ROWAK]],<ref>involving also talks on German role in the Spanish mining industry, Christian Leitz, ''Economic Relations Between Nazi Germany and Franco's Spain: 1936-1945'', Oxford 1996, 0198206453, 9780198206453, p. 81</ref> he objected to increase of German stakes,<ref>Monserrat Cavaller 2001, p. 143</ref> though key decisions were probably beyond his capacity.<ref>Monserrat Cavaller 2001, pp. 139-145</ref> He hugely contributed to the Nationalist logistics by closing international deals covering 600 [[Fiat]] cars and 1,000 [[Studebaker]] chassis.<ref>Monserrat Cavaller 2001, pp. 146, 234-5</ref>
Bau's relations with Carlism are not clear. According to one source, he took advantage of his position by procuring arms designed specifically for the requetés;<ref>Javier Ugarte Tellería, ''El carlismo en la guerra del 36. La formación de un cuasi-estado nacional-corporativo y foral en la zona vasco-navarra'', [in:] ''Historia contemporánea'' 38 (2009), p. 67. The author claims that Bau procured arms for the Pamplona-based Junta Central Carlista de Guerra de Navarra; the body assumed a semi-rebellious stance pushing for unconditional collaboration with Franco against the cautious policy adopted for the official Carlist executive, the Burgos-based Junta Nacional Carlista de Guerra</ref> according to another, starting late 1936 he assisted in organization of [[Terç de Requetès de la Mare de Déu de Montserrat]],<ref>Monserrat Cavaller 2001, p. 206-208</ref> the requeté battalion consisting of Carlist refugees from Catalonia. On the other hand, he is not known to have protested against Franco's measures against Manuel Fal;<ref>Maximiliano Garcia Venero, ''Historia de la Unificacion'', Madrid 1970, p. 79</ref> even detailed studies dealing with amalgamation of Carlism within Francoism in 1936-7 do not mention Bau,<ref>compare Mercedes Peñalba Sotorrío, ''Entre la boina roja y la camisa azul. La integración del carlismo en Falange Española Tradicionalista y de las JONS (1936-1942)'', Estella 2013,{{ISBN|978-84-235-3365-7}}, Juan Carlos Peñas Bernaldo de Quirós, ''El Carlismo, la República y la Guerra Civil (1936-1937). De la conspiración a la unificación'', Madrid 1996, {{ISBN|8487863523}}, 9788487863523</ref> which suggests that at that time he was already hardly involved in Traditionalism. It seems that he unconditionally accepted [[:es:Decreto de Unificación|Decreto de Unificación]] and was leading Catalan Carlists co-operating with Franco;<ref>Robert Vallverdú Martí, ''La metamorfosi del carlisme català: del "Déu, Pàtria i Rei" a l'Assamblea de Catalunya (1936-1975)'', Montserrt 2014, {{ISBN|9788498837261}}, p. 50; the author claims that Franco intended to use Bau as counterweight to Fal</ref> some scholars compare the role he played in Catalonia to the role played by [[Tomás Domínguez Arévalo]] in Vasco-Navarrese area.<ref>Manuel Martorell Pérez, ''La continuidad ideológica del carlismo tras la Guerra Civil'' [PhD thesis], Valencia 2009, p. 216</ref> Considered rebellious by Manuel Fal and the new regent-claimant [[Prince Xavier of Bourbon-Parma|Don Javier]], at an unspecified date he was expulsed from Carlism.<ref>Vallverdú 2014, p. 42; the author does not give exact date and mentions the expulsion when discussing late 1936 events</ref>
==Outcast== [[File:Bundesarchiv Bild 121-1010, Berlin-Lichterfelde, Suner, Himmler.jpg|thumbnail|left|[[Ramón Serrano Suñer]], 1940]] Bau's influence started to decline once [[Ramón Serrano Suñer]] arrived in Burgos. Upon arrival he was already averse towards Bau as late 1936 Franco decided that it would be the family of Bau, not the family of Serrano, to be exchanged with the Republicans for the family of general [[José Miaja|Miaja]].<ref>Bau's left his wife and children on July 15, 1936 in Benicasim, when leaving for Portugal; they were detained and kept in custody by the Republicans and exchanged in December 1936, Garcia Venero 1970, p. 47, Monserrat Cavaller 2001, pp. 183, 334. One of the exchanged, Bau's oldest son Joaquin, immediately volunteered to the requeté. Two Serrano's brothers were in the meantime executed by the Republicans</ref> The animosity grew during 1937, when Bau opposed totalitarian designs pursued by Franco's cuñado.<ref>Monserrat Cavaller 2001, p. 184</ref> When the first regular Francoist government was created early 1938 Bau was not even considered.<ref>Bau was released as president of Comision de Industria on January 30, 1938, Monserrat Cavaller 2001, p. 160</ref> In the spring of 1938 he left Burgos, settling in [[San Sebastián]].<ref>Monserrat Cavaller 2001, p. 219</ref>
Together with many Catalan industry tycoons taking refuge in the [[Gipuzkoa]]n capital, Bau engaged in plans to re-create regional economic institutions once Catalonia would be retaken by the Nationalist troops. He was offered presidency of [[:ca:Institut Agrícola Català de Sant Isidre|l'Institut Catala de Sant Isidre]], the regional agricultural organization, but declined quoting his hostile relations with Serrano.<ref>Vallverdú 2014, p. 68</ref> Indeed, the internal [[Falangist]] document denounced him as one of the leaders of local "plutocratas y alta burguesia" who conspired against the national-syndicalist state.<ref>Vallverdu 2014, p. 68, Martorell Pérez 2009, p. 129</ref>
Bau kept supporting the [[Terç de Requetès de la Mare de Déu de Montserrat|Catalan Montserrat battalion]].<ref>since early 1937 Bau was helping Catalan requetés from this tercio to enter military courses enabling promotion to alfereces provisionales; theoretically candidates should have been at least 4 months serving at the frontline, Monserrat Cavaller 2001, pp. 197-8, 200-202</ref> He remained involved in numerous charity projects, like [[:es:Auxilio Social|Auxilio de Invierno]].<ref>Monserrat Cavaller 2001, pp. 217-218</ref> The most important of Bau's ventures of that period was probably helping the Catalan Republican POWs. Personal acquaintance of officers commanding [[Francoist concentration camps|Campos de Concentración]] and [[Comisíon Clasificadora]],<ref>Monserrat Cavaller 2001, p. 226</ref> Bau did his best to release Catalan prisoners and enlist them either in the Carlist tercios or in the Falangist banderas.<ref>Monserrat Cavaller 2001, pp. 224-229</ref> Following the end of the war he returned to Tortosa, though he is not listed as taking part in the Carlist-Falangist competition for power in Catalonia.<ref>Bau is hardly mentioned in Joan Maria Thomas, ''Falangistes i carlins catalans a la «zona nacional» durant la Guerra civil (1936-1939)'', [in:] ''Recerques: Història, economia i cultura'' 31 (1995), pp. 7-18</ref> [[File:RequeteViladot.JPG|thumbnail|160px|''S. M. Javier I'', 1959]] Bau was not invited to the victory parade of May 19, 1939.<ref>Monserrat Cavaller 2001, p. 232</ref> Though sidetracked in great national politics, he remained engaged in clandestine and extremely sensitive Francoist business schemes. In 1941-42 he managed the deal with [[Nazi]] [[Oberkommando der Marine]], supervising construction of 20 wooden ships intended to supply [[Afrika Korps|German troops]] fighting the [[North African Campaign (World War II)|British in Africa]].<ref>Leitz 1996, p. 145. The delivery was delayed as Spanish shipyards proved inefficient and because the British, who got wind of the scheme due to increased traffic of wood from Spanish Guinea, intervened with Franco. Eventually only 2 ships entered the German service as late as 1944.</ref> Later on he kept exchanging courteous but purely formal correspondence with Franco.<ref>or rather with his secretariat, Monserrat Cavaller 2001, pp. 337-338</ref> In the 1940s Bau dedicated himself to family issues, various Catholic organizations and business; he became the first post-war president of Banco de Tortosa<ref>Llorente 2005, p. 257</ref> and later multiplied his wealth by trading shares of the bank,<ref>''Joaquim Bau i Nolla'' at ''Gran Enciclopédia Catalana'' online service</ref> going on also with the inherited Aceites Bau business.<ref>he transferred the company from Tortosa to Madrid in 1942, Salvadó Poy 2010, p. 12</ref> Privately he pursued his interest in [[organ music]].<ref>Monserrat Cavaller 2001, p. 235</ref>
Bau led one of 3 competing Traditionalist Tarragona factions, namely the one opposing [[Carloctavismo|Carloctavistas]]<ref>at least temporarily; one work claims that Bau supported Carlos VIII, Iker Cantabrana Morras, ''Lo viejo y lo nuevo: Diputacion-FET de las JONS: la convulsa dinámica política de la "leal" Álava (1938-1943)'', [in:] ''Sancho el Sabio'' 22 (2005), p. 158</ref> and [[Xavier, Duke of Parma and Piacenza|javieristas]] and promoting rapprochement with the Alfonsist claimant, [[Juan de Borbon|Don Juan]].<ref>an internal Falangist document describing Tarragona in the early 1940s divided Carlists into 3 groups: 1) "Una parte bastante considerable está firmemente unida a Falange y la campaña de Carlos VIII ha aumentado bastante la fracción. Son los Tradicionalistas del grupo auténtico que siguió a Caylá. Gente sana y ruda que constituye un grupo excelente por su españolismo decidido"; 2) "Otra parte del carlismo autentico, algo superior en número al anterior, forma el núcleo rebelde. Su jefe provincial es un pobre diablo de Reus llamado Sugrañes [...] pero su jefatura no la acatan mis que en su pueblo y en alguna localidad vecina. Se mueven dentro del Falcondismo y andan de capa caida" 3) "existe el núcleo que sigue a la trilogia Bau, Sentis, Prat. Los carlistas puros están en contra porque les acusan de haberse vendido al juanismo franquisme tarragona". In another paragraph of the same document Bau is presented as leading "una fracción moderada frente al integrismo del Sr. Caylá de Valls", quoted after Joan Maria Thomàs, ''El Franquisme des de dins: un informe sobre Tarragona'', [in:] ''Butlletí de la Societat Catalana d'Estudis Històrics'' 9 (1998), pp. 152-153</ref> The Tortosa javierista Carlists distributed leaflets presenting him as Francoist traitor who ignored the lot of requetés detained by the Francoist administration.<ref>"Los carlistas hemos visto con indignación cómo eran borrados y ridiculizados nuestros símbolos queridos y servía de irrisión y burla a todo el mundo. La Tradición ha pasado por muchas vicisitudes pero jamás nos habían podido acusar de cobardes como hacen ahora a pesar del sacrificio del Requeté. ¿Quiénes son los culpables de lo ocurrido? ¿Dónde están los Prat, los Sentís, los Bau?", quoted after Martorell Pérez 2009, p. 216</ref> He apparently acknowledged that a future kingdom must encompass Francoist structures.<ref>Monserrat Cavaller 2001, pp. 311-319. In 1951 he wrote: "La Monarquía no puede ser conservadora, ni de "revancha". Ha de recoger lo social en su justo medio y estudiar lo corporativo y sindical", quoted after Monserrat Cavaller 2001, p. 321</ref> His private papers from mid-1950s suggest that Bau, though with hesitation, tended to support what seemed a long-distance Franco's plan for crowning prince [[Juan Carlos]].<ref>see his analysis, possibly intended also for some political friends, and dated September 1954; in the document he seems to have accepted that Juan Carlos would be a better option than Don Juan, Monserrat Cavaller 2001, pp. 316-319</ref> However, when in 1957 he joined the Carlists who abandoned the regent-claimant Don Javier, Bau declared Juan Carlos' father, [[Juan de Borbon|Don Juan]], the legitimate heir<ref>Francisco Javier Caspistegui Gorasurreta, ''El naufragio de las ortodoxias. El carlismo, 1962-1977'', Pamplona 1997; {{ISBN|9788431315641}}, 978843131564, pp. 24-25, Josep Carles Clemente, ''Historia del Carlismo Contemporaneo 1935-1972'', Barcelona 1977, {{ISBN|8425307597}}, 8425307600, p. 299</ref> and continued to approach him as a king.<ref>e.g. he addressed his 1959 lecture, intended for Don Juan, "por su Majestad el Rey", Monserrat Cavaller 2001, p. 323; his mid-1960s correspondence with Don Juan contains the "S.M." invocation, see, Monserrat Cavaller 2001, p. 328.</ref>
==Francoist dignitary== [[File:Francisco Franco 1959 (cropped).jpg|160px|left|thumbnail|Francisco Franco, 1959]] As in mid-1950s Franco shelved totalitarian plans and opted for a hybrid line of development, he started looking for loyal individuals not associated with Falangism; 1958 produced huge turnover of [[:es:Procurador en Cortes|procuradores]] nominated to the quasi-parliament, [[Cortes Españolas]].<ref>Stanley G. Payne, ''The Franco Regime'', Madison 2011, {{ISBN|0299110745}}, 9780299110741, p. 517</ref> The dictator appointed Bau member of [[National Council of the Movement|Consejo Nacional of the Falange]],<ref>Bau entered the VIII Consejo, Monserrat Cavaller 2001, p. 243</ref> which automatically ensured the Cortes mandate.<ref>see the 1958 record at the official Cortes service, available [http://www.congreso.es/portal/page/portal/Congreso/Congreso/Iniciativas?_piref73_2148295_73_1335437_1335437.next_page=/wc/servidorCGI&CMD=VERLST&BASE=DIPH&FMT=DIPHXD1S.fmt&DOCS=5-5&DOCORDER=FIFO&OPDEF=Y&NUM1=&DES1=&QUERY=%2813200%29.NDIP. here]</ref> He got his seat confirmed in 5 successive legislatives,<ref>either as member of Consejo Nacional, or as personal Jefe del Estado appointee or as member of the highest state bodies</ref> appointed also in 1961,<ref>see the 1961 record at the official Cortes service, available [http://www.congreso.es/portal/page/portal/Congreso/Congreso/Iniciativas?_piref73_2148295_73_1335437_1335437.next_page=/wc/servidorCGI&CMD=VERLST&BASE=DIPH&FMT=DIPHXD1S.fmt&DOCS=6-6&DOCORDER=FIFO&OPDEF=Y&NUM1=&DES1=&QUERY=%2813200%29.NDIP. here]</ref> 1964,<ref>see the 1964 record at the official Cortes service, available [http://www.congreso.es/portal/page/portal/Congreso/Congreso/Iniciativas?_piref73_2148295_73_1335437_1335437.next_page=/wc/servidorCGI&CMD=VERLST&BASE=DIPH&FMT=DIPHXD1S.fmt&DOCS=7-7&DOCORDER=FIFO&OPDEF=Y&NUM1=&DES1=&QUERY=%2813200%29.NDIP. here]</ref> 1967<ref>see the 1967 record at the official Cortes service, available [http://www.congreso.es/portal/page/portal/Congreso/Congreso/Iniciativas?_piref73_2148295_73_1335437_1335437.next_page=/wc/servidorCGI&CMD=VERLST&BASE=DIPH&FMT=DIPHXD1S.fmt&DOCS=9-9&DOCORDER=FIFO&OPDEF=Y&NUM1=&DES1=&QUERY=%2813200%29.NDIP. here]</ref> and 1971.<ref>see the 1971 record at the official Cortes service, available [http://www.congreso.es/portal/page/portal/Congreso/Congreso/Iniciativas?_piref73_2148295_73_1335437_1335437.next_page=/wc/servidorCGI&CMD=VERLST&BASE=DIPH&FMT=DIPHXD1S.fmt&DOCS=11-11&DOCORDER=FIFO&OPDEF=Y&NUM1=&DES1=&QUERY=%2813200%29.NDIP. here]</ref> As his career was re-launched, Bau kept assuming higher and higher posts.<ref>Bau was also gaining importance within Falange/Movimiento; in 1964 he was appointed member of [[Comisión Permanente del Consejo Nacional del Movimiento]], a 10-15 member executive body, Monserrat Cavaller 2001, p. 243; in 1967 he was appointed permanent (until 75 years of age) member of the Consejo; in 1971, shortly before completing 75 years, Bau stepped down as member of the Concejo, Monserrat Cavaller 2001, p. 244. He served also in some state-controlled business executive bodies like [[FEVE|Ferrocarriles de Vía Estrecha FEVE]], the narrow-gauge state railway company, see ''BOE'' 24.01.69, available [http://www.boe.es/boe/dias/1969/01/24/pdfs/A01133-01133.pdf here]</ref> In 1963 he started leading various parliamentary committees,<ref>e. g. Comisión de Leyes Fundamentales, Monserrat Cavaller 2001, p. 268</ref> formally nominated president of the internal affairs committee in 1964,<ref>Comisión de Gobernación, Monserrat Cavaller 2001, p. 249</ref> president of Leyes Fundamentales committee in 1965<ref>Monserrat Cavaller 2001, p. 262</ref> and then other committees working on new constitutional laws. In 1965 he was appointed president of [[:es:Consejo de Estado de España|Consejo de Estado]],<ref>Monserrat Cavaller 2001, p. 283, ''BOE'' 30.10.65, available [http://www.boe.es/boe/dias/1965/10/30/pdfs/A14853-14853.pdf here]. He was re-appointed in 1971, ''BOE'' 09.11.71, available [http://www.boe.es/boe/dias/1971/11/09/pdfs/A17965-17965.pdf here]</ref> a body adding to extreme complexity of Francoist power structures and being part of Franco's recipe for political balance.<ref>see massive statistics on its sessions and work, Monserrat Cavaller 2001, pp. 287-8</ref> The appointment produced his nomination to [[:es:Consejo del Reino|Consejo del Reino]],<ref>''BOE'' 06.08.70, available [http://www.boe.es/boe/dias/1970/08/06/pdfs/A12558-12558.pdf here]</ref> another body with some competencies related to monarchical establishments.<ref>Payne 2011, pp. 372-3</ref> In 1970 Bau was nominated its vice-president.<ref>Monserrat Cavaller 2001, p. 310, see ''BOE'' 06.09.70, available [http://www.boe.es/boe/dias/1970/08/06/pdfs/A12558-12558.pdf here]</ref> As one of the regime's highest dignitaries in the late 1960s he became one of faces of Francoism.<ref>also in the newly born audiovisual media like TV, see for instance Radiotelevision Española service available [http://www.rtve.es/filmoteca/no-do/not-1193/1469179/ here] (starting 1:44)</ref> Shortly before his death he was made [[:es:Condado de Bau|Conde de Bau]].<ref>''BOE'' 21.05.73, available [http://www.boe.es/boe/dias/1973/05/21/pdfs/A10181-10181.pdf here]</ref>
Bau's rise from political non-existence to president of Consejo de Estado in just 7 years was possible as he proved acceptable to most groupings competing for power within Francoism. Deprived of own political background, he posed no threat and might have been considered as sympathetic to their cause by Carlists, monarchists, [[:es:Planes de Desarrollo de España|technocrats]] (by virtue of his business activities and friendship with [[Laureano López Rodó|López Rodó]]<ref>Monserrat Cavaller 2001, p. 335</ref>), the Church and even the military (maintained friendly relations with many high-ranking generals); it was only the Falangist syndicalists that he remained at odds with.<ref>see his 1966 complaints about Solis, Monserrat Cavaller 2001, p. 344</ref> Bau, always impeccably elegant,<ref>Monserrat Cavaller 2001, p. 19</ref> boosted his career by oratory skills and non-belligerent,<ref>"era amigo de todos", quoted after Monserrat Cavaller 2001, pp. 279-280</ref> silky presiding style in numerous bodies of the regime,<ref>"el señor Bau tiene una firme flexibilidad, una caballera blanca como una aureola y una amable ironía de gran señor", opinion of one of the contemporaries quoted after Monserrat Cavaller 2001, p. 260; "empezaba a hablar sin saber lo que iba a decir", Monserrat Cavaller 2001, p. 279</ref> excelling in conflict management and demonstrating sort of impartiality, combined with perfect loyalty to Franco.<ref>E.g. he is not even mentioned in Mercedes Vázquez de Prada, ''La oposición monárquica y su aproximación al franquismo a partir de 1954'', [in:] ''Memoria y civilización: anuario de historia'', 13 (2010), pp. 35-53; a biographer describes his stance as "lealtad hasta el extreme al Caudillo", Monserrat Cavaller 2001, p. 279</ref> [[File:Juan Carlos de Borbón, Prince of Spain.jpg|160px|thumbnail|[[Juan Carlos I of Spain|''Prince of Spain'']], 1971]] Bau's own political outlook may be summarised as a watered-down [[Authoritarianism|authoritarian]], non-dynastical monarchism based on diehard (marchamartillo) Catholicism.<ref>Monserrat Cavaller 2001, p. 233</ref> Following his return to great politics in 1958 he emerged as one of the most prominent monarchists, contributing to shaping of late Francoism in course of works on various key legal structures of the system.<ref>like Ley de Asociaciones, new Ley Orgánica del Estado, Ley Orgánica del Movimiento y de su Consejo Nacional, Ley de la Representación Familiar en Cortes, Ley Sindical, Ley de Libertad Religiosa and successive laws on Plan de Desarrollo Económico y Social, Monserrat Cavaller 2001, p. 253-280</ref> Far from political militancy, starting mid-1960s Bau began to press the monarchical cause by advocating adoption of [[:es:Ley Orgánica del Estado|Ley Orgánica]] and [[:es:Príncipe de España|Ley de Designación]].<ref>Monserrat Cavaller 2001, p. 275, see also his letters to Franco, Monserrat Cavaller 2001, pp. 344-350</ref> Mocked by some critics as himself the best successor to Franco,<ref>Julian Cerón Ayuso staged a mocked casting for Franco's succession and concluded that "Don Joaquín Bau es mi favorito. Lo tiene todo! Cumple ocho leyes, lleva más de un año preparándose (desde hace más tiempo apuesto yo por él), no cae mal ni bien que es muy importante, ocupa el cargo ideal, es de Tortosa – ciudad perfecta como símbolo" (the last piece was probably a reference to the Francoist Battle of Ebro monument in Tortosa), see filosofia.org service available [http://www.filosofia.org/ave/001/a233.htm here]</ref> Bau could have considered his efforts crowned when Juan Carlos was officially confirmed as Franco's successor in 1969,<ref>asked by the ''ABC'' correspondent, Bau explained that he supported Ley de Designación because "con ello hago honor a mis convicciones políticas de toda la vida", Monserrat Cavaller 2001, p. 276</ref> though as late as 1970 he kept fighting the regentialistas, first headed by [[Agustín Muñoz Grandes|Muñoz Grandez]] and than by [[:es:Alejandro Rodríguez de Valcárcel|Valcárcel]].<ref>Monserrat Cavaller 2001, p. 337, see his 1970 letter to Franco, denouncing those who intended to take advantage of "inconsciencia o bondada ignorancia del general Muñoz Grandez, los señores republicanos encubiertos y demás compañeros, que ahora pretenden alcanzar con la ayuda de Valcárcel", Monserrat Cavaller 2001, p. 352</ref> When in the early 1970s advising Juan Carlos on prospective course to be adopted, he suggested [[:es:Federico Silva Muñoz|Federico Silva Muñoz]] as the man for future.<ref>Monserrat Cavaller 2001, p. 361</ref> He retained Catalan identity taking part in a number of regional initiatives and bodies, always perfectly within the limits permitted by the regime.<ref>Monserrat Cavaller 2001, p. 277</ref>
==Legacy== Joaquín Bau is commemorated by a very short street in Madrid, a parking-lot-plaza in the [[Ferreries district]] of Tortosa (until 2017) and a long backyard drive in the resort town of [[Benicasim]], where the family owns a summer residence purchased by Bau in the 1950s;<ref>named Villa Elisa, see ''La ruta de las villas de Benicassim, un paseo con historia'', [in:] ''enelmundoperdido'' service 08.10.14, available [http://www.enelmundoperdido.com/2014/10/la-ruta-de-las-villas-de-benicassim-un-paseo-con-historia/ here]; see also Beatriz de Rojas, ''Villas de Benicasim'', [in:] ''Antropología – Castellón de la Plana y su entorno'', available [http://mayores.uji.es/blogs/antrop/2012/02/05/1881/ here]</ref> some of them are subject to various initiatives aiming at purging public space from Francoist<ref>see ''simbologia.cat'' service available [http://simbologia.cat.mialias.net/fitxasimbol.php?num=95&ord=0&pg=0 here]</ref> or Fascist<ref>see [https://apaguemlesnuclears.files.wordpress.com/2010/02/mocio-popular.pdf here] or [http://terresdelebreantifeixistes.blogspot.com/2010/02/qui-era-joaquin-bau.html here]</ref> symbols. No trace of Bau having been named "hijo predilecto" of Tortosa in 1966<ref>Monserrat Cavaller 2001, pp. 366-9</ref> can be found on the official ayuntamiento web page.<ref>compare [http://www.tortosa.cat/ here]</ref> Since 1956 until 2018 one of Tortosa [[college]]s was named "Institut Joaquín Bau"<ref>see the Institut home page, available [http://agora.xtec.cat/iesjbau/ here]</ref> (today ''Institut Dertosa''), though there was a failed attempt to change the patron in 1983.<ref>see history section of the IJB service, available [http://agora.xtec.cat/iesjbau/linstitut/historia/ here]</ref> Bau's biography, in large part a hagiographical compilation of his correspondence from the private archive, was published in 2001; the author defined Bau as a conservative monarchist and played down Carlist threads, ignoring also most controversial episodes from his lifetime.<ref>Bau's shuttling between Carlist and Alfonsist claimants is ignored; there is no note of his harsh stance on Marcelino Domingo in 1929, on his war dealings with the Nazis in 1941-42 or on his "traitor" image among the Carlists in the 1940s</ref> Condado de Bau is still functional and currently remains held by Bau's grandson.<ref>see ''BOE'' 06.05.99, availavle [http://www.boe.es/boe/dias/1999/05/06/pdfs/A17072-17072.pdf here]</ref>

Historical Index of Deputies] * [http://www.institutjbau.com/ Bau college official site] * [http://www.rtve.es/filmoteca/no-do/not-1193/1469179/ Bau in the 1965 RTE footage (01:44)] * {{YouTube|6s2OhwAqZ4c|Terç de Montserrat roll of the dead video (in Catalan)}}
