{{advert|date=June 2016}} '''Juraj Vaculík''' has over twenty years’ experience of working as a leader with very broad experiences from political revolution<ref>{{Cite web|title = Student veterans recall 1989|url = http://spectator.sme.sk/c/20052647/student-veterans-recall-1989.html|website = spectator.sme.sk|access-date = 2016-02-24|first = Petit Press|last = a.s.}}</ref> to international media and advertising industry.<ref>{{Cite web|title = MADE BY VACULIK|url = http://www.vaculik.com/en|website = www.vaculik.com|access-date = 2016-02-24}}</ref> In 2010, Juraj co-founded [[AeroMobil s.r.o. AeroMobil|AeroMobil]] and manages the company as its CEO.<ref>{{Cite web|title = SXSW 2015: AeroMobil Says It Will Put Its Flying Car On The Market In 2017|url = http://www.popsci.com/sxsw-2015-forget-self-driving-cars-future-self-flying-cars|website = Popular Science|access-date = 2016-02-24}}</ref> He also acts as an angel investor with investments into successful start-up projects<ref>{{Cite web|url = https://pexe.so|title = Pexeso: storm makers of entertainment|date = |access-date = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = 5 Slovak startups to watch in 2015 {{!}} EU-Startups|url = http://www.eu-startups.com/2015/02/5-slovak-startups-to-watch-in-2015/|access-date = 2016-02-24|first = Pavel|last = Curda}}</ref> in the media content, IT, and alternative transport sectors throughout Europe and the US.<ref>{{Cite news|title = AeroMobil — the incredible flying car|url = http://www.ft.com/cms/s/2/2fced540-e930-11e4-a71a-00144feab7de.html?siteedition=uk|newspaper = Financial Times|date = 2015-04-24|access-date = 2016-02-24|issn = 0307-1766|first = Henry|last = Foy}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = A Slovakian Startup Is Building a Flying Car|url = https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2014-10-31/a-slovakian-startup-is-building-a-flying-car.html|website = Bloomberg|access-date = 2016-02-24|first = Alexander|last = Weber}}</ref>
== Velvet Revolution == {{BLP unsourced section|date=May 2016}} During [[Velvet Revolution]] in 1989 which ends communist era in former [[Czechoslovakia]] Juraj Vaculík was one of the key persons in Student Movement which has started process of democratization and established new post-revolution government in Slovakia.
== Advertising Industry == At the beginning of the 90’s he started his career as a creative director for major global advertising agencies which started their operations in Czech and Slovak republics. In 1996 Juraj founded MADE BY VACULIK - one of the leading independent advertising agencies<ref>{{Cite web|title = Agentúrou roka 2015 je MADE BY VACULIK|url = http://strategie.hnonline.sk/spravy/reklama/agenturou-roka-2015-je-made-by-vaculik|website = Strategie.sk|access-date = 2016-02-24}}</ref> in the CEE region, extending its reach to over 30 countries.
== Revolution in personal transportation == In 2010 Juraj co-founded [[AeroMobil s.r.o. AeroMobil|AeroMobil]] and manages the company as its CEO.<ref>{{Cite web|title = AeroMobil: Flying car|url = http://aeromobil.com/#s-people|website = aeromobil.com|access-date = 2016-02-24}}</ref> In 2013, together with the inventor and co-founder Stefan Klein, he unveiled the pre-prototype of AeroMobil 2.5 at the SAE Conference in Montreal.<ref>{{Cite web|title = The amazing flying car with a top speed of 124mph and fold-able wings|url = http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sciencetech/article-2487058/Flying-car-AeroMobil-2-5-speed-124mph.html|website = Mail Online|access-date = 2016-02-24}}</ref> A year later, an experimental prototype of AeroMobil 3.0 was developed under his lead with the team of 12 people and presented at the [[Pioneers festival]] in Vienna.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Watch the Aeromobil 3.0 flying car take to the skies (Wired UK)|url = https://www.wired.co.uk/news/archive/2014-10/29/aeromobil-3-0|website = Wired UK|access-date = 2016-02-24}}</ref> At the beginning of 2015, AeroMobil successfully attracted the attention of visitors and potential customers at the most prestigious supercars show, Top Marques Monaco<ref>{{Cite web|title = Flying Car Lands Spot at Top Marques Monaco|url = http://www.topmarquesmonaco.com/en/nwl/4987e7de76ac845c47ff34dbb355f65f.html|website = www.topmarquesmonaco.com|access-date = 2016-02-24}}</ref> alongside the prestigious sports vehicles from around the world. Later in June, AeroMobil was presented at the [[Founders Forum]] event in the UK,<ref>{{Cite web|title = Founders Forum tech roundup - FT Business - Companies & Management Video - FT.com|url = http://video.ft.com/4306183904001/Founders-Forum-tech-roundup/Companies|website = Financial Times Video|access-date = 2016-02-24}}</ref> where it caught the attention of many visitors and the Financial Times. In October, the public experienced the prototype at the [[Expo 2015|EXPO]] in Milan,<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.wired.it/lifestyle/mobilita/2015/10/16/aeromobil-dalla-slovacchia-arriva-macchina-volante%E2%80%A8/|title = Wired Italy: AeroMobil Dalla Slovacchia Arriva Macchina Volante|date = |access-date = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> where it was part of the Slovak exposition. Renowned magazine, Popular Science,<ref>{{Cite web|title = A Plane That Folds Into a Car|url = http://www.popsci.com/plane-folds-car|website = Popular Science|access-date = 2016-02-24}}</ref> presented AeroMobil with Invention of the Year 2015 award and UK edition od [[Wired (magazine)|Wired magazine]] ranked the project among the top 10 rule breakers<ref>{{Cite web|title = Meet the Rule Breakers (Wired UK)|url = https://www.wired.co.uk/magazine/archive/2015/03/features/meet-the-rule-breakers|website = Wired UK|access-date = 2016-02-24}}</ref> in 2014r.

{{EngvarB|date=April 2016}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2016}} {{Infobox officeholder |name=Kim Cham | native_name={{nobold|湛佑森}} | native_name_lang = zh | honorific-suffix = [[Order of the British Empire|CBE]], [[Justice of Peace|JP]] |image= |birth_date={{Birth date and age|df=yes|1946|4|16}} |birth_place= Hong Kong |office=Member of the [[Legislative Council of Hong Kong|Legislative Council]] |appointed= [[Sir Edward Youde]] |term_start=4 October 1984 |term_end= 25 August 1988 |predecessor= |successor= |alma_mater= [[St. Paul's Co-Educational College]]
[[University of Hong Kong]] ([[Bachelor of Arts|BA]])
[[Queen's University]] ([[MBA]])
[[University of Bath]] (PhD)
[[Harvard Business School]]
[[University of New England (Australia)|University of New England]] |occupation= Company director |party= |death_place = |citizenship = |spouse = Winnie Ho Woon-kwan |relations = |children = 2 |portfolio = |religion = }} '''Kim Cham Yau-sum''' [[Justice of Peace|JP]] (born 16 April 1946, Hong Kong) is a Hong Kong businessman, accountant and politician. He studied at the [[St. Paul's Co-Educational College]] and graduated from the [[University of Hong Kong]] with bachelor's degree in Economics in 1968. He continued his master's degree at the [[Queen's University]] in Canada and later the doctoral degree at the [[University of Bath]] in England. He also obtained a certificate in Business Education at the [[Harvard Business School]] and a diploma in financial management at the [[University of New England (Australia)|University of New England]] in Australia.{{cite web|title=Database on LegCo members|url=http://app.legco.gov.hk/member_front/english/library/member_detail.aspx?id=20|accessdate=6 May 2013|work=Legislative Council of Hong Kong}} He is the fellow of the [[British Institute of Management]], Institute of Canadian Bankers (FICB), associate member of the Australian Society of Accountants and [[Hong Kong Society of Accountants]]. He came to politics when he was appointed as a member of the [[Urban Council of Hong Kong|Urban Council]]. He was later appointed to the [[Legislative Council of Hong Kong|Legislative Council]] in 1984 by Governor [[Edward Youde]]. He served as the chairman of the Hong Kong Future Exchanges. ==References== {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Cham, Kim Yau-sum}} [[Category:1946 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Hong Kong politicians]] [[Category:Hong Kong accountants]] [[Category:Hong Kong businesspeople]] [[Category:District councillors of Eastern District]] [[Category:Members of the Legislative Council of Hong Kong]] [[Category:Members of the Urban Council of Hong Kong]] [[Category:Alumni of the University of Hong Kong]] [[Category:Queen's University alumni]] [[Category:Alumni of the University of Bath]] [[Category:Harvard Business School alumni]] [[Category:University of New England (Australia) alumni]] [[Category:HK LegCo Members 1985–88]]

page.title: Louisiana Center for Women in Government and Business Hall of Fame

revision.comment: Remove 1 stray access-date. ([[User:GreenC bot/Job 5|GreenC bot job #5]])
revision.text:
[[File:Mary Ann Vial Lemmon.jpg|thumb|District Judge Mary Ann Vial Lemmon]] The '''Louisiana Center for Women in Government and Business Hall of Fame''' recognizes women natives or residents of the [[U.S. state]] of [[Louisiana]] for their significant achievements or statewide contributions. Among the inductees are men whose contributions to supporting strong women were deemed significant. The Center is headquartered at [[Nicholls State University]] in [[Thibodaux, Louisiana|Thibodaux]] and was established in 1991 to promote and encourage government and public service leadership of women. The first Hall of Fame inductions occurred in March 1994 during [[Women's History Month]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Louisiana Center for Women in Government and Business Hall of Fame|url=http://louisianawomen.org/|accessdate=January 6, 2016}}</ref>

Wilkerson}} | |(1948–2000) |2007 |Former [[Louisiana State Legislature|Louisiana State Representative from District 11 (Claiborne and parts of Bienville, Lincoln, and Union parishes)]] |<ref>{{cite web|title=State Rep. Wilkinson Killed in Auto Accident |url=http://house.legis.state.la.us/pubinfo/Press_Releases/wilkerson_auto_accident.htm |publisher=Louisiana House of Representatives |accessdate=August 13, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110306100010/http://house.legis.state.la.us/pubinfo/Press_Releases/wilkerson_auto_accident.htm |archivedate=March 6, 2011 |df= }}</ref> |- |scope="row"|{{sortname|Mary Ellen|Wisham|Mary Ellen Wisham}} | |(1916–2012 ) |1999 |Undersecretary of Management and Finance for the Louisiana Department of Labor |<ref>{{cite web|title=Democratic Stalwart Mary Ellen Wisham has died|url=https://louisianademocrats.org/?s=Mary+Ellen+Wisham|publisher=Louisiana Democrats|accessdate=August 14, 2012}}</ref> |- |scope="row"|{{sortname|Donnell|Zeringue|Donnell Zeringue}} | | |2015 |Outstanding Activists for The Center for Women, chair of the Public Service Project for The Center's Louisiana Girls Leadership Academy. Lafourche Commission on Women, National Leaders Summit and The Louisiana Leaders Conference | |- |}

{{Infobox person/Wikidata | fetchwikidata=ALL | dateformat = dmy | occupation=shipbuilder }} '''Martin Garlieb Amsinck''' (born 23 September 1831 in [[Hamburg]], died 10 April 1905 in Hamburg) was a German shipbuilder and ship-owner. He was one of the major ship-owners of [[Hamburg]]. He was a member of Hanseatic [[Amsinck]] family and the son of Johannes Amsinck and Emilie [[Berenberg-Gossler|Gossler]]. Unlike his four brothers, he did not join the family company, but started his own shipbuilding company.<ref name="Hauschild-Thiessen">Renate Hauschild-Thiessen: ''Amsinck, Martin Garlieb.'' In: Franklin Kopitzsch, Dirk Brietzke (Hrsg.): ''Hamburgische Biografie. Personenlexikon.'' Bd. 2. Wallstein, Göttingen 2003, {{ISBN|3-7672-1366-4}}, S. 28–29.</ref>
== Literature == * Renate Hauschild-Thiessen: ''Amsinck, Martin Garlieb.'' In: Franklin Kopitzsch, Dirk Brietzke (Hrsg.): ''Hamburgische Biografie. Personenlexikon.'' Bd. 2. Wallstein, Göttingen 2003, {{ISBN|3-7672-1366-4}}, S. 28–29. * Paul Schroedter, Gustav Schroedter (Hrsg.): ''100 Jahre Schiffahrt, Schiffbau, Häfen.'' Schiffahrtsverlag Hansa, Hamburg 1964. * Erik Verg, Martin Verg: ''Das Abenteuer, das Hamburg heißt. Der weite Weg zur Weltstadt.'' 4., überarbeitete und ergänzte Auflage. Ellert & Richter, Hamburg 2007, {{ISBN|978-3-8319-0137-1}}.
== References == <references />

{{about|the building in Chicago, Illinois|other subjects|Merchandise Mart (disambiguation)}} {{Infobox building |name = Merchandise Mart |image = Merchandise Mart.jpg |image_size = 275px |location = 222 Merchandise Mart Plaza, [[Chicago]], Illinois |coordinates = {{coord|41.8884|-87.6355|region:US-IL|display=inline,title}} |status = |start_date = August 16, 1928 |completion_date = 1930 |opening = May 5, 1930 |building_type = Mixed | architectural_style = [[Art Deco]] |antenna_spire = |roof = {{convert|340|ft|m|abbr=on}} |top_floor = |floor_count = 18 base, 25 tower |floor_area = {{convert|4000000|sqft|m2|-3}} |architect = [[Graham, Anderson, Probst and White]] with the firm's [[Alfred P. Shaw]] as chief architect |main_contractor = John W. Griffiths & Sons |developer = |owner = [[Vornado Realty Trust]] }}
The '''Merchandise Mart''' (or the '''Merch Mart''', or the '''Mart''') is a commercial building located in [[Chicago Loop|downtown]] [[Chicago]], [[Illinois]]. When it was opened in 1930, it was the [[List of largest buildings in the world|largest building in the world]], with {{convert|4000000|sqft|m2|-3}} of floor space.<ref name=Marchitecture>{{cite web| url=http://www.merchandisemart.com/marchitecture/| accessdate=2007-07-10| title=Marchitecture| publisher=merchandisemart.com |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070205155045/http://www.merchandisemart.com/marchitecture/ |archivedate=February 5, 2007}}</ref><ref name=Architects>{{cite web| url=http://www.merchandisemart.com/marchitecture/architects.html|accessdate=2007-07-10| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061024235006/http://www.merchandisemart.com/marchitecture/architects.html| archivedate=October 24, 2006| title=Architects| publisher=merchandisemart.com}}</ref> The [[art deco]] structure is located at the junction of the [[Chicago River]]'s branches. The building is a leading [[retailing]] and wholesale destination, hosting 20,000 visitors and tenants per day as of the late 2000s.{{Update inline|date=November 2018}}<ref name=Building>{{cite web| url=http://www.merchandisemart.com/marchitecture/building.html| accessdate=2007-07-10| title=Building of the Mart| publisher=merchandisemart.com}}</ref><ref name=Beyer>{{cite web| url=http://www.merchandisemart.com/marchitecture/beyer.html| accessdate=2007-07-10| title=Architects - Beyer| publisher=merchandisemart.com}}</ref>
Built by [[Marshall Field & Co.]] and later owned for over half a century by the [[Kennedy family]], the Mart centralized Chicago's [[wholesale]] goods business by consolidating architectural and interior design vendors and trades under a single roof.<ref name="Architects"/> It has since become home to several other enterprises, including the [[Shops at the Mart]], the Chicago campus of the [[Illinois Institute of Art – Chicago|Illinois Institute of Art]], [[Motorola Mobility]], and the Chicago tech startup center 1871.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.nbcchicago.com/blogs/inc-well/How-1871-Has-Changed-Chicagos-Startup-World-One-Year-Later-205989051.html| date=2013-05-13| accessdate=2014-06-08| title=How 1871 Has Changed Chicago’s Startup World One Year Later| publisher=[[WMAQ-TV]]}}</ref>
The Merchandise Mart is so large that it had its own [[ZIP code]] (60654) until 2008, when the Postal Service assigned it to part of the surrounding area.<ref>{{cite book| url=https://books.google.com/?id=TDd6Vfsz6XAC&pg=PA63&lpg=PA63&dq=does+Merchandise+Mart+have+its+own+area+code#v=onepage&q&f=false| title=Chicago City Guide| isbn=978-1741047677| first1=Karla| last1=Zimmerman| first2=Lisa| last2=Dunford| first3=Nate| last3=Cavalieri| publisher=Lonely Planet| year=2008| page=63}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| title=ZIP It, ZIP It Good| url=http://chicagoist.com/2008/04/25/zip_it_zip_it_g.php| first=Margaret| last=Lyons| date=April 25, 2008| publisher=Chicagoist| deadurl=yes| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160106103104/http://chicagoist.com/2008/04/25/zip_it_zip_it_g.php| archivedate=January 6, 2016| df=}}</ref> In 2010, the building opened its Design Center showrooms to the public for the first time.<ref>{{cite journal| title=A Guide to Shopping the Merchandise Mart| url=http://www.chicagomag.com/Chicago-Magazine/March-2011/A-Guide-to-Shopping-the-Merchandise-Mart/| first=Barri Leinier| last=Grant| work=[[Chicago (magazine)|Chicago]]| date=March 10, 2011}}</ref>
==History==
===Construction and context===
[[Image:Merchandise mart construction 1929.jpg|thumb|left|Merchandise Mart under construction, 1929]] [[File:Photography by Victor Albert Grigas (1919-2017) 00389 Chicago Loop Christmas time - developed March 1970 (37458766170).jpg|thumb|left|Merchandise Mart in late 1969]]
In 1926, a westward extension of double-deck [[Wacker Drive]] increased development on the south [[Bank (geography)|riverbank]]. In 1927, Marshall Field & Co. announced its plans to build on the north bank opposite Wacker Drive. The site, bordered by Orleans Street, [[Wells Street (Chicago)|Wells Street]], Kinzie Street and the [[Chicago River]], was formerly a [[Native Americans in the United States|Native American]] trading post and the site of [[Chicago and North Western Railway]]'s former [[Wells Street Station (Chicago)|Wells Street Station]], abandoned in 1911 in favor of the [[Chicago and North Western Passenger Terminal]].<ref name="Marchitecture"/> With the railroad's [[air rights]], the site was large enough to accommodate "the largest building in the world".<ref name=History>{{cite web| url=http://www.merchandisemart.com/marchitecture/history.html| accessdate=2007-07-10| title=History of the Mart| publisher=merchandisemart.com| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070602052539/http://www.merchandisemart.com/marchitecture/history.html |archivedate=2007-06-02}}</ref> Removing the train yard supported the [[Chicago Plan Commission]]'s desire to develop and beautify the riverfront.
James Simpson, president of Marshall Field & Co. from 1923 to 1930 and chairman of the Chicago Plan Commission from 1926 to 1935, turned the first shovels of dirt at [[groundbreaking]] on August 16, 1928, along with architect Ernest Graham. [[General contractor]] John W. Griffiths & Sons brought building construction into the [[machine age]] through the use of techniques "ordinarily used in the construction of big [[dam]]s."<ref name="Building"/> [[Concrete]] arriving by boat was lifted by [[Pneumatics|compressed air]] to bins {{convert|75|ft|m|-1}} above the ground, with [[gravel]] and [[sand]] delivered by railroad cars to [[conveyor belt]]s and transfer elevators. Giant [[Concrete mixer|mixers]] provided wet [[concrete]] to skip hoists in vertical towers that were extended as the building rose. Continuously employing 2,500 men and as many as 5,700 men altogether, the construction project lasted a year and a half into the early months of the [[Great Depression]]. With a foundation [[surface area|footprint]] of nearly two square [[city block]]s, the building required 29 million [[brick]]s, {{convert|40|mi|km|0}} of [[plumbing]], {{convert|380|mi|km|-1}} of wiring, nearly {{convert|4000000|cuyd|m3}} of concrete, {{convert|200000|cuft|m3}} of stone, and 4,000 [[window]]s.<ref name="Marchitecture"/><ref name="OfficeRetail"/> [[Bethlehem Steel]] fabricated much of the 60,000 tons of [[steel]].<ref name=Bethlehem>{{cite web|url=http://www.hsp.org/default.aspx?id=945 |accessdate=2007-07-22 |title=Bethlehem Steel: The Rise and Fall of an Industrial Giant |publisher=The Historical Society of Pennsylvania |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080127192659/http://www.hsp.org/default.aspx?id=945 |archivedate=2008-01-27 |df= }}</ref> An estimated {{convert|7.5|mi|km|-1}} of corridors and over 30 [[elevator]]s were included in the construction.<ref name="Marchitecture"/><ref name="Lot">{{cite news| title=A lot of Merchandise Series: 20TH CENTURY CHICAGO| url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-4518645.html| date=October 22, 1999| last=Kennedy| first=Christopher G.| work=[[Chicago Sun-Times]]| subscription=yes}}</ref> The total cost of construction was estimated to be $26 million.<ref name = Langton>James Langton, "End of the house that Joe built". ''[[The Sunday Telegraph]]'' via the ''[[Ottawa Citizen]]'', March 22, 1998: A10.</ref>
===Ownership=== The Merchandise Mart opened on May 5, 1930, just east of Chicago's original [[trading post]], [[Wolf Point, Chicago|Wolf Point]].<ref name=OfficeRetail>{{cite web| url=http://www.merchandisemart.com/officeretail/about.html| accessdate=2007-07-19| title=Merchandise Mart Office Retail| publisher=merchandisemart.com| deadurl=yes| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061025004147/http://www.merchandisemart.com/officeretail/about.html| archivedate=2006-10-25| df=}}</ref>
The building realized Marshall Field’s dream of a single wholesale center for the entire nation and consolidated 13 different warehouses. It was purchased in 1945 or 1946, depending on the source,<ref name=NPNLFtO>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1988/06/16/garden/new-pieces-new-looks-for-the-office.html?|title=New Pieces, New Looks For the Office|accessdate=July 13, 2010|date=June 16, 1998|author=Giovannini, Joseph|work=[[The New York Times]]}}</ref><ref name=CKCTPTWOTOFB>{{cite news|author=Feuerstein, Phyllis|title=Christopher Kennedy Chicago's The Place To Work On The Other Family Business|date=August 22, 1993|page=8|work=[[Chicago Tribune]]}}</ref> by the [[Kennedy family]] through Merchandise Mart Properties, Inc., and managed by [[Sargent Shriver]]. The purchase price was $13 million, roughly half of what it had cost to construct the complex twenty years earlier.<ref name=Langton/> The building revenues became a principal source of Kennedy family wealth, including being a source of political campaign funding.<ref name=Langton/>
The Kennedy family sold much of the complex center property to [[Vornado Realty Trust]] in 1998 as part of a larger $625 million (${{formatnum:{{Inflation|US|625|1998|r=1}}}} million in current dollars) transaction,<ref>{{cite news|title=Kennedy Family Selling Merchandise Mart To Vornado Realty|date=January 26, 1998|work=[[Chicago Tribune]]|page=3}}</ref> That year, MMPI was acquired by Vornado for $450 million cash and a $100 million-plus stake in Vornado.<ref>{{cite web| date=January 26, 1998| url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1998-01-26/news/9801270086_1_vornado-realty-trust-kennedy-family-showroom-space| title=Kennedy Family Selling Merchandise Mart To Vornado Realty| work=[[Chicago Tribune]]| agency=[[Bloomberg News]]}}</ref><ref name=Emporis>{{cite web| url=http://www.emporis.com/en/wm/bu/?id=merchandisemart-chicago-il-usa| accessdate=2007-07-19| title=Merchandise Mart, Chicago| publisher=emporis.com}}</ref> As of early 2007, the building was valued at $917 million.<ref name=crains1>{{cite web| first=Thomas A.| last=Corfman| date=February 21, 2007| url=http://www.chicagobusiness.com/article/20070221/NEWS12/200023946/merchandise-marts-value-soars-in-9-years| accessdate=2016-02-17| title=Merchandise Mart’s value soars in 9 years| work=[[Crain Communications|Crain's Chicago Business]]}}</ref>
===Expansions and renovations=== [[File:Chicago River from Lake Street bridge.jpg|left|thumb|Night view of the building's surroundings along the [[Chicago River]]: Among the buildings and structures shown are (left to right) Left Bank at K Station (300 North Canal), 333 North Canal, [[Kinzie Street railroad bridge]], [[350 West Mart Center]], Merchandise Mart, [[300 North LaSalle]], [[Franklin Street Bridge]] and part of [[333 Wacker Drive]].]]
The Merchandise Mart was modernized in the late 1950s and 1960s. The Indian chiefs were removed and replaced with concrete plates in 1961, of minimal note to onlookers as skyscrapers did not rise on the north side of the river as predicted. Some of the carvings were later found in a suburban backyard and auctioned in 2014.<ref>{{cite web| title=Lost Pieces of Merchandise Mart Found in a Suburban Garden| url=http://www.chicagoarchitecture.org/2014/05/22/lost-pieces-of-merchandise-mart-found-in-a-suburban-garden/| publisher=Chicago Architecture| date=May 22, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| title=Suburban Woman Selling Indian Heads That Once Adorned Merchandise Mart| url=http://chicago.cbslocal.com/2014/05/26/for-sale-two-indian-heads-which-used-to-adorned-merchandise-mart/| work=[[WBBM-TV|WBBM News]]| date=May 26, 2014}}</ref> In 1962, an entrance [[canopy (building)|canopy]] was constructed over the south for vehicle use.
In 1977, [[Skidmore, Owings & Merrill]] designed the [[350 West Mart Center|Chicago Apparel Center]], located on the west side of Orleans Street, which increased the Merchandise Mart’s total floor space to {{convert|6200000|sqft|m2}}. Making use of plazas, [[esplanade]]s and overlooks employed the waterfront location for pedestrian pleasure. In 1988, [[Helmut Jahn]] designed an enclosed pedestrian walking bridge over Orleans Street connecting the Mart and the Apparel Center.<ref name="History"/>
After a 10-year, $100 million modernization in the late 1980s that included [[public utility]] upgrades, [[Beyer Blinder Belle]]'s commission in 1989 was to create additional perimeter entrances and restore the display windows, main entrance and lobby.<ref name="Beyer"/><ref name="ChicagoL">{{cite web| url=http://www.chicago-l.org/stations/merchandise_mart.html| title=Merchandise Mart| date=May 15, 2006|publisher=chicago-l.org}}</ref> On the south facade, the drive-through canopy was removed and two smaller doorways aside the main entrance were added. Display windows, [[paint]]ed over during the earlier modernization campaign, were restored with clear glass to showcase merchant's wares. New main and corner entrances were added to the rear [[facade]], and the [[loading dock]] that occupied the north portion of the first floor of the river level was removed in order to use the bottom deck of North Bank Drive. Improvements to the lobby included restoration of the original glass [[curtain wall (architecture)|curtain wall]] over the entrance, shop fronts and reception desk using terrazzo floors and wall sconces influenced by the original design.<ref name="Building"/><ref name="Beyer"/> The project was completed in 1991.
In November 2007, the building received [[Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design|LEED]] for Existing Buildings Silver recognition.<ref>[http://www.greenprogress.com/green_building_article.php?id=1408 The Merchandise Mart Chicago Receives LEED Silver Certification] greenprogress.com.</ref>
==Building== [[File:2007-09-13 2400x1800 chicago merchandise mart.jpg|thumb|right|From the [[Chicago River]], looking west]] [[File:The Merchandise Mart Photo Walk Chicago September 2, 2013-4874.jpg|thumb|right|The sign on the building]]
The Merchandise Mart was designed by the Chicago architectural firm of [[Graham, Anderson, Probst and White]] to be a "city within a city".<ref name="Emporis"/> Second only to [[Holabird & Roche|Holabird & Root]] in Chicago art deco architecture, the firm had a long-standing relationship with the Field family. Started in 1928, completed in 1931, and built in the same [[art deco]] style as the [[Chicago Board of Trade Building]], its cost was reported as both $32 million and $38 million. The building was the largest in the world in terms of floorspace, but was surpassed by the [[The Pentagon|Pentagon]] in 1943,<ref name=MarshallField>{{cite web| url=http://www.merchandisemart.com/marchitecture/marshall_field.html| accessdate=2007-07-19| title=Marchitecture Marshall Field| publisher=merchandisemart.com}}</ref> and now stands forty-fourth on the [[list of largest buildings in the world]]. Once the largest commercial space in the world, [[New Century Global Center]] in China is now recognized by [[Guinness World Records]] as holding the record.<ref name=AmericanWay>{{cite web|url=http://americanwaymag.com/aw/travel/feature.asp?archive_date=4/15/2005 |author=Pope, Elizabeth |date=2005-04-15 |accessdate=2007-08-16 |title=Wall Street of Flowers |publisher=American Airlines |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927043449/http://americanwaymag.com/aw/travel/feature.asp?archive_date=4%2F15%2F2005 |archivedate=2007-09-27 |df= }}</ref>
===Architecture=== Designer Alfred Shaw integrated art deco stylings with influences from three building types—the [[warehouse]], the [[department store]] and the [[skyscraper]].<ref name="Building"/> A warehouse block stands as the 18-story bulk of the building. Ribbon [[Pier (architecture)|piers]] define the windows, and the building's chamfered corners, minimal setbacks, and corner [[pavilions]] disguise the edges of the mass and visually reduce bulk.<ref name="Building"/> The south corner pavilions are of greater height than the north corner pavilions. The building is open at the pedestrian level with bronzed framed [[display window]]s, typical of a department store, on the south, west and east boundaries. The 25-story central tower ascends with a peak in the form of a skyscraper, and rests in the southern half of the building. Deeply recessed [[Portal (architecture)|portals]] occur between raised panels, and are adorned with [[medallions]] featuring the interlocked initials of the Merchandise Mart. The same [[logo]] occurs throughout the building. Fifty-six [[Native Americans in the United States|American Indian]] [[tribal chief|chiefs]] circled the tower's crown, a reference to the site's history and Chicago's early trade activities. Three and a half feet wide by seven feet tall, the [[terra cotta]] figures were barely visible from the street, meant to be viewed from the upper floors of the skyscrapers planned to rise along the riverbank.<ref name="Building"/>
The lobby of The Merchandise Mart is defined by eight square [[marble]] piers, with storefronts in side aisles framed in embossed [[bronze]] trim. The green and orange [[terrazzo]] floor was conceived as a [[carpet]]: a pattern of squares and stripes bordered by overscaled chevrons inlaid with The Mart's [[initials]]. The [[Chevron (insignia)|chevron]] theme is continued in the column [[Sconce (light fixture)|sconce]]s lighting an ornamented [[cornice]] overhead. Referred to as "business boulevards", two wide {{convert|650|ft|m}} long corridors with [[terrazzo]] floors in the upper levels featured six and one-half miles of display windows. Building regulations specified identical entrances along corridors but tenants could personalize the individual floor space. Excepting the corridors, elevator halls, and exhibition space on the fourth floor, the {{convert|5|acre|m2}} of each upper floor was "raw space" with concrete floors.<ref name="Building"/>
===Artwork=== [[Jules Guerin]]'s [[frieze]] of 17 [[murals]] is the primary feature of the lobby and graphically illustrate [[commerce]] throughout the world, including the countries of origin for items sold in the building.<ref name="Emporis"/> The murals depict the industries and products, the primary mode of transportation and the architecture of 14 countries. Drawing on years as a stage set designer, Guerin executed the murals in red with [[gold leaf]] using techniques producing distinct image layers in successive planes. In a panel representing [[Italy]], [[Venice, Italy|Venetian]] [[glassware]] appears in the foreground with fishing boats moored on the Grand Canal and the facade of the Palazzo Ducale rises above the towers of the Piazza San Marco.<ref name=Mural>{{cite web| url=http://www.merchandisemart.com/marchitecture/mural.html| accessdate=2007-07-19| title=Marchitecture Murals| publisher=merchandisemart.com}}</ref>
"To immortalize outstanding American merchants", Joseph Kennedy in 1953 commissioned eight bronze [[Bust (sculpture)|busts]], four times life size, which would come to be known as the Merchandise Mart Hall of Fame:<ref name="OfficeRetail"/><ref name="Lot"/> * retail magnates [[Frank Winfield Woolworth]], [[Marshall Field]] and [[Aaron Montgomery Ward]] * [[Julius Rosenwald]] and [[Robert Elkington Wood]] of [[Sears, Roebuck and Company]] fame * advertiser [[John Wanamaker]], merchandiser [[Edward Albert Filene]], and [[The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company|A&P]] grocery chain founder [[George Huntington Hartford]]. All of the busts rest on white pedestals lining the Chicago River and face north toward the gold front door of the building.
===Surroundings=== [[Image:Behind the Merch Mart.jpg|thumb|left|Plaza in front of the Merchandise Mart]]
Dominating the skyline in the south end of the [[Near North Side, Chicago|Near North Side]], the Mart lies just south of the gallery district on the southern terminus of Franklin Street. Eateries and nightclubs abound on [[Hubbard Street]] one block to the north. The [http://www.kinziechophouse.com Kinzie Chophouse], popular with [[politicians]] and celebrities, stands on the northwest corner of Wells and Kinzie, across from the Merchandise Mart. The [[Chicago Varnish Company Building]], listed on the [[National Register of Historic Places]] and now housing [[Harry Caray]]'s restaurant, is located east on Kinzie Street. Across the street to the east is 325 N. Wells Street, home to [[The Chicago School of Professional Psychology]] and DIRTT Environmental Solutions.
The Mart is not rectangular in shape due to being constructed after the [[bascule bridge]]s over the Chicago River. The control house for the double decked [[Wells Street Bridge (Chicago)|Wells Street Bridge]] stands between the lower level and the southeast corner of the building. The [[Franklin Street Bridge]] stands at the southwest corner of the building, at the junction of Orleans Street and Franklin Street. The building slants at the same angle as Franklin Street, from southeast to northwest along Orleans Street.
===Exterior lighting=== A heritage of lighting the structure finds the central and corner towers, along with the columns between each window on the setbacks, bathed nightly in an upwardly focused white light. [[Tradition]] dictates annual changes to green in mid-March for [[St. Patrick's Day]] and orange during the fall months around [[Halloween]] and [[Thanksgiving]]. Prominent events have found the [[behemoth]] lit in pink for [[Cancer]] Awareness Month. To note the [[2006 Chicago Bears season]], highlighted by reaching [[Super Bowl XLI]], the building was lit with team colors, orange floodlights for the setbacks and blue floodlights for the towers. Red and green lights are used during the [[Christmas]] season. During the [[Art Chicago]] 2008 the American artist [[Jenny Holzer]] illuminated the facade of the building with a poem by the Polish winner of the [[Nobel Prize]] in Literature [[Wisława Szymborska]]. In 2018, a large projection screen will begin displaying images and videos across the structure's riverfront side.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://urbanmatter.com/merchandise-mart-projection-screen/|title=A Giant Projection Screen Will Light Up the Merchandise Mart {{!}} UrbanMatter|date=2017-03-13|work=UrbanMatter|access-date=2017-03-16|language=en-US}}</ref>
Nighttime lighting on the Mart typically matches the colors of [[Antenna (radio)|antenna]] lighting on the [[Sears Tower]] and [[John Hancock Center]], as well as the colors used on the top floors of the [[Aon Center (Chicago)|Aon Center]].
===Green building practices=== Under [[Christopher G. Kennedy|Chris Kennedy]]'s leadership of the Mart, it was the largest building in the world to be awarded LEED (Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design) Certification in 2007<ref name="greenprogress.com">[http://www.greenprogress.com/green_building_article.php?id=1408/ World's Largest LEED-EB Certified Building<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> from the [[United States Green Building Council]] (USGBC). The Mart has long been implementing sustainable practices. The Mart Center began operating a thermal storage facility in 1986, capable of building {{convert|2000000|lb}} of ice per night, cooling 71 buildings in the surrounding neighborhood, and saving $200,000 in electricity costs in the first year.{{Citation needed|date=July 2009}}
In 1990, the Mart Center began using [[Green Seal]]-approved green cleaning products and the next year implemented a recycling program, which today includes all forms of paper products, glass, light bulbs, batteries, aluminum and construction materials. In 1996, the Mart Center became one of the first major property owners in downtown Chicago to enter into an agreement with the district cooling system now known as [[Thermal Chicago]], thus contributing to the national effort to reduce the discharge of ozone-damaging [[Chlorofluorocarbon|CFC]]s.
In 2006, MMPI joined [[Clean Air Counts]], a voluntary initiative to reduce smog forming pollutants and energy consumption in the Chicago area. Part of the campaign strategies included utilizing only low VOC cleaning products, paints and building materials, as well as energy efficient lighting and alternative workplace transportation options. To date, the Mart Center has reduced pollution by {{convert|264018|lb}}, the largest reduction by a commercial building.{{Citation needed|date=July 2009}}
That same year, the Mart Center recycling program saved over 13,000 trees and recycled nearly 11 million pounds of waste, while water conservation efforts saved {{convert|5.5|e6USgal|m3}} of water. More than eight percent of the estimated 10,000 people working at the Mart walk, bike or take public transportation; to encourage greener methods of transportation, the Mart expanded bicycle storage capacity to more than 200. In 2009, MMPI converted all stationery to a one hundred percent post-consumer recycled product. {{Citation needed|date=July 2009}}
The Mart has nine LEED-certified showrooms, with five others on their way to LEED certification.
==Uses==
===Commerce=== [[Image:A Display inside the Merchandise Mart.jpg|thumb|right|A display inside the Merchandise Mart]] Wholesale showrooms occupy 50% of the usable floor space,<ref name="Marchitecture"/> and the [[Sultan of Brunei]] once spent $1.6 million at the Mart to furnish his entire palace, claiming the location was the only place where the task could be completed in one week.<ref name="Emporis"/> Select showrooms are open only to wholesalers, with others accessible to the general public. Unlike stores with traditional shelf and rack displays, entire usable rooms are created, providing consumers an opportunity to compare form and function between applications and manufacturers. A portion of the stores offer items for purchase singly or as a collection, while others offer design services, preservation, renovation, or installation. In addition to being a resource for architects and decorators, the Mart also has featured award-winning designs as selected by the [[American Institute of Architects]]. Catering to suppliers, on-site firms specialize in providing professional services for market research projects.
In 1931, Marshall Field and Company lost five million dollars, followed by eight million in 1932.<ref name="MarshallField"/> The wholesale division was greatly reduced and Field's reduced its space in the Mart from four floors to one and half. The Mart continued to display the latest trends in home furnishings within the showrooms and trade shows. The company recovered late in the decade, but did not return to all previously occupied space.
In 1942, [[Skaggs family|L. L. Skaggs]] formed a partnership with three other men and named the partnership the Owners Service Company, hence [[Osco Drug|Osco]]. The headquarters moved from Waterloo, Iowa, to the Merchandise Mart.
A retail shopping area, named The Shops at the Mart, opened in 1991 and includes apparel shops, beauty services, bookstores and [[newsagent|newsstands]], financial services, telecommunication services, travel services, specialty food and [[wine]] stores, photo services, a [[dry cleaning|dry cleaner]], [[shoe polish|shoe shine]] stand, and a [[food court]]. A [[United States Postal Service|U.S. Post Office]] is located on the first floor and a [[FedEx]] location is on the second floor.<ref name="Metromix"/>
The Apparel Center houses the 521-room Holiday Inn Chicago Mart Plaza River North hotel, the offices of the ''Chicago Sun-Times'' and the Chicago campus of the [[Illinois Institute of Art – Chicago]], as well as the Chicago office of the [[Ogilvy & Mather]] advertising agency. [[GoHealth]] occupies {{convert|93000|sqft|m2|-2}} on the 5th floor of Merchandise Mart, the [[Potbelly Sandwich Works]]' corporate offices are located in the tower.<ref name="newsletter">{{cite web|url=http://www.mmart.com/officeretail/tenant_newsletter.html |title=Tenant Newsletter |date=2007-08-08 |publisher=Merchandise Mart Properties, Inc. |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070814015036/http://www.mmart.com/officeretail/tenant_newsletter.html |archivedate=2007-08-14 |df= }}</ref> [[Motorola Mobility]] moved its headquarters to the Merchandise Mart in 2014.<ref>{{cite news| work=[[The Wall Street Journal]]| url=https://online.wsj.com/news/articles/SB10001424052702304281004579222442197428538| title=Companies Say Goodbye to the 'Burbs| last=Weber| first=Lauren| date=December 3, 2013| accessdate=February 17, 2016| subscription=yes}}</ref>
===Trade fairs=== {{Redirect-synonym|NeoCon|[[Neoconservatism]]}}
Since 1969, the Merchandise Mart has been home to the annual National Exposition of Contract Furnishings, known as '''NeoCon'''. With over 1,000 exhibitors of contract and commercial furnishings, and 50,000 attendees, it is the largest trade show of its kind in North America.<ref name=NeoCon>{{cite web| title=Show Info| url=http://www.neocon.com/about/show-info| publisher=NeoCon| accessdate=February 17, 2016}}</ref>
Since 2006 the Merchandise Mart has played host to the [[Art Chicago]] international art fair.<ref>{{cite news| first=Misha| last=Davenport| title=On With the Art Show -- At the Mart| work=[[Chicago Sun-Times]]| date=April 27, 2006| page=8| url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-1625480.html| subscription=yes}}</ref>
<ref>CC</ref>
===Mass media===
====Radio==== Before the location even opened, [[NBC]] announced plans to build studios in the Mart. When opened on October 20, 1930, the nineteenth floor location covered {{convert|65000|sqft|m2|-2}} and supported a variety of live broadcasts including those requiring orchestras. [[WLS-TV|WENR]] and [[WMAQ (AM)|WMAQ]] broadcast from the location. Expanded in 1935, with office space in the previously unoccupied tower, the additional {{convert|11500|sqft|m2|-1}} provided room for an [[Organ (music)|organ]] chamber, two echo rooms, and a total of 11 studios. A staff of more than 300 produced up to 1,700 programs each month, including ''[[Amos 'n' Andy]]''.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.richsamuels.com/nbcmm/studiof.html |title=WMAQ Studio F| publisher=Samuels| accessdate=April 25, 2010}}</ref><ref name="Tour">{{cite web| url=http://www.richsamuels.com/nbcmm/trguide.html |title=A Tour of the 1930 NBC Studios|publisher=Samuels| accessdate=April 25, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.richsamuels.com/nbcmm/birdseye.html| title=Birdseye, cut-away view of the NBC studios| publisher=Samuels| accessdate=25 April 2010}}</ref>
[[Hugh Downs]] contributed to the [[Burr Tillstrom]] children's show ''[[Kukla, Fran and Ollie]]'' from the NBC studios after the network picked up the program from [[WBBM-TV|WBKB]]. The ''[[Captain Midnight]]'' radio program was broadcast from the Mart from 1942 until 1945.
WMAQ and WMAQ-TV moved to the [[NBC Tower]] in 1990 (even though the radio station had been sold to [[Westinghouse Broadcasting]] two years earlier). (Today, the former NBC space is being utilized by [[Tribeca Flashpoint Media Arts Academy]] as a learning site for Film + Broadcast productions.) WMAQ's former sister FM station, WKQX, stayed at the Merchandise Mart; renamed [[WIQI]], as of May 2012 it still occupies space on the west side of the second floor, along with co-owned [[WCKL-FM|WLUP]]. As of 2014 [[WKQX (FM)|WKQX]] has returned to its former Merchandise Mart location, however the station is expected to move to a new facility at [[NBC Tower]] by summer 2016.{{citation needed|date=February 2016}}
====Television==== On January 7, 1949, [[NBC]] station WNBQ commercially debuted its [[television]] broadcast schedule on channel 5, with a minimum of two hours of programming per day. April 15, 1956, is remembered as "C-Day" at [[WMAQ-TV]], and was described by Broadcasting-Telecasting magazine as "a daring breakthrough the black-and-white curtain." With Mayor [[Richard J. Daley]] looking on, NBC President [[David Sarnoff]] operated the controls as Channel 5 became the world's first [[Color television|all-color TV station]] as "Wide, Wide World" was broadcast to 110 NBC-TV affiliated stations across the country. The color conversion project cost more than $1,250,000 with advertising costing $175,000. On "C-Day", three [[skywriting]] planes flew over the city, trailing streams of red, green and blue smoke.
WMAQ-TV first installed color equipment in late 1953, with the [[Tournament of Roses Parade|Rose Bowl parade]] of 1954 as the first major broadcast. Introduced in March 1955, the first local color program was [[John Ott]]'s "How Does Your Garden Grow?", featuring the use of [[time-lapse]] color film.
Although WMAQ-TV has since moved to [[NBC Tower]] about a mile away, and for the most part the 19th floor of the Mart has been turned into office space, one former tenant (Bankers Life and Trust Company) maintained a remnant of the original studios as their video and multimedia department. The former WMAQ space is currently being redeveloped by Flashpoint Academy as a full modern soundstage facility as well as a screening room, backlot, and classroom space over the 19th and 20th floors.
Local [[regional sports network]] [[CSN Chicago|Comcast SportsNet Chicago]] has their control room, and broadcasts their live studio programming from the Apparel Center expansion; the studios had been home to previous RSNs [[FSN Chicago]] and [[SportsChannel|SportsChannel Chicago]].<ref name="newsletter"/>
==Chicago 'L' station== [[Image:Merchandise Mart CTA 060805.jpg|right|thumb|[[Merchandise Mart (CTA station)|Merchandise Mart]] 'L' station]] Built in under four months and opened on December 5, 1930, the [[Merchandise Mart (CTA station)|Merchandise Mart]] elevated train station served the [[North Side Main Line (CTA)|Main Line of the North Side Division]].<ref name="ChicagoL"/> The station is now noted for being one of two commercial locations to have its own station on the [[Chicago Transit Authority]]'s (CTA) [[Chicago 'L'|'L' system]].<ref name="Marchitecture"/> The station is now served by the [[Brown Line (Chicago Transit Authority)|Brown]] and [[Purple Line (Chicago Transit Authority)|Purple Lines]].<ref name="ChicagoL"/> An ADA accessible station, the [[turnstile]]s are located within the building on the second floor, while the platforms are connected to the east side of the building. The northbound platform is accessed by an overhead bridge or elevator. It was rebuilt in 1988, prior to the Wells Street Bridge reconstruction in 1989.
The Merchandise Mart housed the CTA's headquarters on the 7th floor from 1947 to 2004.<ref name="Emporis"/><ref name="ChicagoL"/>
==Cultural involvement== {{Prose|section|date=August 2016}} * Owing to the expanding postwar economy and family, the owners began offering tours in 1948. Architecture and design interest groups continue to offer scheduled tours.<ref name="Metromix">{{cite news|url=http://metromix.chicagotribune.com/events/31950,0,6253745.location?Merchandise%20Mart|title=Merchandise Mart in Chicago|date=2007-07-20|work=|publisher=chicagotribune.com}} </ref> * The Mart hosts the annual Art Chicago activities.<ref name=ArtChicago>{{cite web| url=http://www.merchandisemart.com/artchicago/showInfo.html| title=Art Chicago 2007| date=2007-07-19| publisher=merchandisemart.com}}</ref> * [[Chicago Marathon]] routes have taken runners past the structure, typically on Wells Street.
===In popular culture=== * The 1948 film ''[[Call Northside 777]]'', was made in Illinois and the Mart is seen from newspaper offices on Wacker Drive.<ref name="MoviePoster">{{cite web|url=http://www.learnaboutmovieposters.com/NewSite/INDEX/COUNTRIES/US/Illinois-movies.asp |title=Movies Made in Illinois |date=2007-07-10 |publisher=learnaboutmovieposters.com |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070512215536/http://www.learnaboutmovieposters.com/NewSite/INDEX/COUNTRIES/US/Illinois-movies.asp |archivedate=2007-05-12 |df= }}</ref> * The lobby appeared in the movie ''[[The Hudsucker Proxy]]'' as the interior of the Hudsucker Company headquarters.<ref name="Emporis"/><ref name="ChicagoBusinessNews">{{cite web| url=http://www.chicagobusiness.com/cgi-bin/mag/article.pl?article_id=23984| title=Filming at the intersection of culture and commerce| date=July 9, 2005| publisher=Crain's Chicago Business| first=Mark| last=Scheffler}}</ref> * In 1956, the eight-minute short subject film ''The Merchandise Mart'' used the Mart's name and covered in detail the building's interior and operations.<ref name="MoviePoster"/> * [[David Letterman]] once called the Merchandise Mart Hall of Fame "the [[Pez]] Hall of Fame" because the combination of busts atop the tall vertical pedestals resembled the candy's dispensers.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.frommers.com/destinations/chicago/attractions/872812| title=Chicago Architecture Foundation| publisher=[[Frommer's]]| accessdate=February 17, 2016}}</ref> * In the 1993 film ''[[The Fugitive (1993 film)|The Fugitive]]'', U.S. Marshals pinpoint the location of Dr. Richard Kimble when they hear a [[Chicago Transit Authority|CTA]] train conductor announce, "Next stop, Merchandise Mart" in the background of a recorded phone call.<ref name="ScriptORama">{{cite web| url=http://www.pages.drexel.edu/~ina22/splaylib/Screenplay-Fugitive.pdf| title=Script: The Fugitive - Dialogue Transcript| publisher=Script-o-rama| date=May 10, 1993}}</ref> * Used as the Candor headquarters in the 2012 novel [[Insurgent (novel)]].

R. }}</ref> | academic_advisors = | doctoral_students = | notable_students = | known_for = [[Autonomy Corporation]] | influences = | influenced = | awards = {{Plainlist| * [[Order of the British Empire|OBE]] * [[Royal Academy of Engineering|FREng]] (2008)<ref name=listoffellows>{{cite web|title=List of Fellows|url=http://www.raeng.org.uk/about-us/people-council-committees/the-fellowship/list-of-fellows}}</ref> * [[Fellow of the Royal Society|FRS]] (2014)<ref name="royal">{{cite web|url=https://royalsociety.org/people/fellowship/2014/michael-lynch/|title=Dr Michael Lynch OBE FREng FRS|archivedate=2014-05-02|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140502071426/https://royalsociety.org/people/fellowship/2014/michael-lynch/}}</ref>}} | signature = <!--(filename only)--> | signature_alt = | website = <!-- {{URL|www.example.com}} --> | footnotes = | spouse = }}
'''Michael Richard Lynch''' {{post-nominals|country=GBR||OBE|DL|FRS|FREng}} (born 16 June 1965)<ref name="whoswho"/> is an entrepreneur with a scientific background. He is the co-founder of [[Autonomy Corporation]] and the founder of Invoke Capital, and has several other roles, including membership of the Council for Science and Technology which advises the UK government. His entrepreneurship is associated with [[Silicon Fen]]. Lynch is known for his work applying techniques from signal processing and pattern recognition to unstructured information, and Autonomy is a leader in this area. In October 2011, Autonomy was sold to [[Hewlett-Packard]] for $11bn.<ref name="Profile: Mike Lynch">[https://www.theguardian.com/business/2011/aug/19/profile-mike-lynch-autonomy Profile: Mike Lynch] The Guardian, 19 August 2011</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.director.co.uk/MAGAZINE/2011/5_May/mike-lynch_64_09.html|title=Good Listener|date=May 2011|work=Director magazine|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111025053845/http://director.co.uk/MAGAZINE/2011/5_May/mike-lynch_64_09.html|archivedate=25 October 2011|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.salon.com/tech/view/2000/07/10/autonomy|title=Britain's first software billionaire|date=July 2000|work=[[salon.com]]}} (interview)</ref>
==Early life and education== Lynch was born in [[Ilford]], [[Essex]] in 1965 and grew up near [[Chelmsford, Essex]]. His mother was a nurse and his father a fireman.<ref name="business.timesonline.co.uk">[http://business.timesonline.co.uk/tol/business/movers_and_shakers/article4289418.ece Business big shot: Mike Lynch of Autonomy] The Times, 8 July 2008</ref>
In 1976, aged 11, he won a scholarship to [[Bancroft's School]], [[Woodford, London|Woodford]].<ref>[http://www.bancroftians.net/UserFiles/File/obaagmdocs.pdf OBA President's Report - 2009]</ref> From there he went to [[Christ's College, Cambridge]] to study [[Natural Sciences (Cambridge)|Natural Sciences]]. He combined mathematics, biological and physical sciences, taking the combination of advanced physics, mathematics and biochemistry in the IB [[Tripos]]. For part II, he chose electrical sciences where he first met Peter Rayner,<ref name="wired"/><ref name=rayner2/><ref name=rayner3/><ref name=raynerswho>{{Who's Who | surname = RAYNER| othernames = Prof. Peter John Wynn | id = U41852 | volume = 2015 | edition = online edition via [[Oxford University Press]]}} {{subscription required}}</ref> his mentor in the signal processing laboratory of the engineering department. After graduating he went on to do a [[PhD]] in [[signal processing]]<ref name="lynchphd">{{cite thesis |degree=DPhil |first=Michael Richard|last=Lynch |title=Adaptive techniques in signal processing and connectionist models |publisher=University of Cambridge |date=1990 |url=http://ulmss-newton.lib.cam.ac.uk/vwebv/holdingsInfo?bibId=11028|authorlink=Michael Richard Lynch}}</ref> and communications research at the [[University of Cambridge]], and then undertook a research fellowship in adaptive pattern recognition.<ref name="BBC Press Office">{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/pressoffice/pressreleases/stories/2006/12_december/14/directors.shtml|title=BBC - Press Office - BBC appoints Executive Board|publisher=|accessdate=16 December 2015}}</ref>
==Entrepreneurial career== In the late 1980s Lynch formed Lynett Systems Ltd, producing designs and audio products for the music recording industry including the first ever sampler for the Atari ST, the Lynex, which was followed by the ADAS sampler for Atari, Mac & PC. This led to the offshoot D2D Systems which produced a software-only hard disk recording system for the Atari Falcon.
In 1991 he set up ''Cambridge Neurodynamics'', which specialized in computer-based finger print recognition.<ref>[http://www.cl.cam.ac.uk/research/security/seminars/1995/95-11-14.html Security Group Seminar] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121202211844/http://www.cl.cam.ac.uk/research/security/seminars/1995/95-11-14.html |date=2 December 2012 }} University of Cambridge</ref>
In 1996 Lynch co-founded [[Autonomy Corporation]].<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20060628201313/http://www.vnunet.com/networkitweek/features/2058993/kindness-strangers The Kindness of Strangers] VNU Net</ref> and he served Autonomy as CEO. During this time Autonomy acquired Dremedia, Virage ($13m), Verity ($500m), Zantaz ($375m) and Interwoven ($606m).<ref>[https://www.reuters.com/article/technology-media-telco-SP/idUSL0322638020070703 Autonomy to buy Zantaz for $375m, place shares] Reuters, 3 July 2007</ref>
In October 2011 Autonomy was sold to Hewlett-Packard for $11 billion.<ref name="Profile: Mike Lynch"/>
In May 2012, HP fired Mike Lynch.<ref>[http://www.pcr-online.biz/news/read/hp-fires-mike-lynch/028388 HP fires Mike Lynch] PCR, 25 May 2012</ref>
In February 2013, Lynch raised $1 billion through his Invoke Capital fund to invest in up and coming British technology companies.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/newsbysector/banksandfinance/9859582/Mike-Lynch-raises-1bn-for-technology-investment.html| title=Mike Lynch raises $1bn for technology investment | author=Ben Martin | publisher=Telegraph | date=9 February 2013}}</ref>
In September 2013, Lynch announced Invoke had made its first investment, putting up to $20m into [[Darktrace]] (alongside Hoxton Ventures and Talis Capital) which describes itself as "the world's first behavioural cyber defence platform."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/newsbysector/mediatechnologyandtelecoms/digital-media/10314823/British-tech-entrepreneur-Lynch-invests-in-cybersecurity-firm-backed-by-ex-MI5-boss.html|title=British tech entrepreneur Lynch invests in cybersecurity firm backed by ex-MI5 boss|date=17 September 2013|work=Telegraph.co.uk|accessdate=16 December 2015}}</ref><ref name="The Economist">{{cite web|url=https://www.economist.com/news/britain/21586555-technology-entrepreneurs-new-venture-makes-its-first-investment-after-autonomy|title=After Autonomy|work=The Economist|accessdate=16 December 2015}}</ref><ref name="dark_Dark">{{Cite web | title = Darktrace {{!}} Investors | author = | work = darktrace.com | date = | accessdate = 2016-05-24 | url = https://www.darktrace.com/investors/ | quote = }}</ref> In July 2015, Summit Partners invested a further $22.5 million in Darktrace, valuing the company at $120million.<ref name="The Guardian">{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2015/jul/22/mike-lynch-darktrace-valued-at-more-than-60m-pounds|title=Mike Lynch's cybersecurity startup Darktrace valued at more than £60m|author=Juliette Garside|work=the Guardian|accessdate=16 December 2015}}</ref>
==Other interests==
He is a member of the board of Cambridge Enterprise,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.enterprise.cam.ac.uk/news/2010/9/one-britains-leading-entrepreneurs-joins-cambridge/|title=News Archive - Cambridge Enterprise|author=Your Name Here|work=Cambridge Enterprise|accessdate=16 December 2015}}</ref> and a member of the Council for Science and Technology.<ref>[http://www.number10.gov.uk/news/members-appointed-to-the-council-for-science-and-technology-2/ Members appointed to Council for Science & Technology] 10 Downing Street</ref> He is also a member of the Council of the Foundation for Science and Technology<ref>[http://www.foundation.org.uk/about/council/default.htm Foundation for Science and Technology] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20131011235551/http://www.foundation.org.uk/about/council/default.htm |date=11 October 2013 }}</ref> and a Hub Mentor in the Enterprise Hub of the Royal Academy of Engineering.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://enterprisehub.raeng.org.uk/mentors/|title=Enterprise Hub - Mentors|publisher=|accessdate=16 December 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151222110407/http://enterprisehub.raeng.org.uk/mentors/|archivedate=22 December 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Lynch is a trustee of the [[Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew]],<ref>[http://www.kew.org/support-kew/about-kew-foundation/board-of-trustees/ Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140106040434/http://www.kew.org/support-kew/about-kew-foundation/board-of-trustees/ |date=6 January 2014 }}</ref> and a member of the board of the Create the Change Campaign at the Crick Institute, for Cancer Research UK.<ref>[http://support.cancerresearchuk.org/support-us/donate/become-a-major-donor/how-you-can-give/create-the-change/meet-the-team Meet the team] Cancer Research UK</ref>
He was a non executive director of Blinkx plc.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.blinkx.com/corporate/investors/shareholder-information|title=Shareholder Information|publisher=Blinkx|accessdate=5 August 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140923103830/http://www.blinkx.com/corporate/investors/shareholder-information|archivedate=23 September 2014|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
He has previously served as a non-executive director to the board of the [[BBC]],<ref name="BBC Press Office"/> on the board of the [[British Library]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bl.uk/aboutus/governance/blboard/memberslist/drmlynch/|title=Mike Lynch|publisher=British Library|accessdate=6 August 2014}}</ref> and as a trustee of the National Endowment for Science Technology and the Arts (NESTA), where he was chairman of their investment committee.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wired-gov.net/wg/wg-news-1.nsf/0/3E8156AF783017E88025765E003CA045?OpenDocument|title=Mike Lynch|publisher=NESTA|accessdate=6 August 2014}}</ref>
==Awards, honours and media coverage== In September 2012 he was inducted into the Digital Hall of Fame, British Interactive Media Association.<ref>[http://www.digitalhalloffame.com/halloffamers Digital Hall of Fame] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130915011727/http://www.digitalhalloffame.com/halloffamers |date=15 September 2013 }}</ref>
He was named Entrepreneur of the Year in 1999 by the [[Confederation of British Industry]] and was awarded the [[Institution of Electrical Engineers]] medal for outstanding achievement.<ref>Institute of Engineering [http://www.theiet.org/about/scholarships-awards/achievement/recipients.cfm?type=pdf Recipients of the Achievement Awards] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090212134719/http://www.theiet.org/about/scholarships-awards/achievement/recipients.cfm?type=pdf |date=12 February 2009 }}</ref>
''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' magazine named Lynch in their 25 most influential technology people in Europe in 2000.<ref>[http://www.time.com/time/europe/digital/2000/12/lynch.html "Mike Lynch - Autonomy"] Time Europe</ref>
The World Economic Forum presented Lynch with an award for Autonomy as a technology pioneer in 2000.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.autonomy.com/content/News/Releases/2000/0201.en.html|title=Filter News Results - HP Newsroom Filter News Results|publisher=|accessdate=16 December 2015}}</ref> Lynch was awarded an [[Order of the British Empire|OBE]] in the [[2006 New Year Honours]].<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/cambridgeshire/4569802.stm MBE for Soham murders detective] BBC News, 31 December 2005</ref>
He is a Lady Margaret Beaufort fellow of [[Christ's College, Cambridge]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.christs.cam.ac.uk/college-life/people/fellows/lmb-fellows/|title=Lady Margaret Beaufort Fellows|publisher=|accessdate=16 December 2015}}</ref>
In 2007, he was awarded Technology Entrepreneur of the year by the European Technology Forum at their 2007 conference.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.innovationandgrowthforum.com/awards/previouswinners/|title=Innovation & Growth Forum|publisher=|accessdate=16 December 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090425001217/http://www.innovationandgrowthforum.com/awards/previouswinners/|archivedate=25 April 2009|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
In March 2008, he was chosen Innovator of the year at the European Business Leader of the year awards 'EBLA'.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ebla2008.com|title=European Business Leaders Awards website|publisher=|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080321185912/http://www.ebla2008.com/|archivedate=21 March 2008|df=dmy-all}}</ref> In June 2008, he was elected a [[Fellow]]<ref name=listoffellows/> of the [[Royal Academy of Engineering]].<ref name=RAE>[http://www.raeng.org.uk/about/fellowship/pdf/newsletter/Spring_News_2009.pdf Royal Academy of Engineering]</ref>
In October 2008, Silicon.com readers voted him one of the top five most influential people in technology along with [[Tim Berners-Lee]], [[Steve Jobs]], [[Jimmy Wales]] and [[Eric Schmidt]].<ref>[http://www.silicon.com/research/specialreports/agenda-setters-2008/ "Agenda Setters 2008"]</ref> In January 2009, ''[[Management Today]]'' chose him as entrepreneur of the year.<ref name=RAE/>
Lynch has twice been a finalist for Investor Relations award of the year.<ref>[http://www.prnewswire.co.uk/cgi/news/release?id=201949 Barclays, Cookson and Detica Grand Prix Winners at IR Magazine Awards] PR Newswire, 29 June 2009</ref> In 2009 he was voted one of the top 25 best [[CEO]]s pan sector in Europe by fund managers in the annual Extel survey.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.docstoc.com/docs/7488204/Extel-Survey-European-Investor-Relations-2009|title=Docstoc is Closed|publisher=|accessdate=16 December 2015}}</ref> He is Deputy Lieutenant of the County of Suffolk.<ref>[http://www.suffolk.gov.uk/your-council/lieutenancy-and-honours/deputy-lieutenants-of-the-county-of-suffolk/ Deputy Lieutenants of the County of Suffolk] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140330060121/http://www.suffolk.gov.uk/your-council/lieutenancy-and-honours/deputy-lieutenants-of-the-county-of-suffolk/ |date=30 March 2014 }}</ref> In October 2013 he accompanied the Chancellor, George Osborne, on a trade mission to China.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/china-business/10373854/London-will-offer-China-more-than-Singapore-can-says-Boris-Johnson.html|title=London will offer China more than Singapore can, says Boris Johnson|date=12 October 2013|work=Telegraph.co.uk|accessdate=16 December 2015}}</ref>
His nomination for the [[Royal Society]] reads {{centered pull quote|Distinguished as a world leader in the application of non-linear adaptive signal processing and pattern recognition to unstructured information. Founder of Autonomy the UKs largest software company which was sold to HP for $11Bn in 2011. Creator of the Bayesian framework and platform at the heart of Autonomy's products and CEO of the company for 15 years. An inspiration and role model for entrepreneurs particularly in the engineering and technology sectors providing mentoring, enthusiasm, and financing at scale. An advisor to the government and major organisations at the most senior levels.<ref name="royal"/>}}
The ''[[Financial Times]]'' has described Lynch as "the doyen of European software".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/60404cda-26eb-11d9-9157-00000e2511c8.html#axzz1atIbaUah|title=Dicom snaps up Neurascript|work=Financial Times|accessdate=16 December 2015}}</ref> PC Advisor has called him "Britain's most successful technology entrepreneur".<ref name="pcadvisor.co.uk">[http://www.pcadvisor.co.uk/news/software/3298219/the-thoughts-of-autonomy-ceo-mike-lynch/ The Thoughts of Autonomy CEO Mike Lynch] PC Advisor</ref> In a profile in the ''[[Sunday Times]]'', it was suggested in passing that Lynch is the nearest thing Britain has to [[Bill Gates]].<ref>James Ashton [http://business.timesonline.co.uk/tol/business/industry_sectors/technology/article5627459.ece "Autonomy is at the heart of a new data revolution"] ''Sunday Times'', 1 February 2009</ref><ref name="telegraph.co.uk">[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/newsbysector/industry/8710037/Profile-Mike-Lynch-Autonomy-founder.html Profile: Mike Lynch, Autonomy founder] The Telegraph, 16 October 2011</ref><ref>[http://realbusiness.co.uk/news/mike-lynch-sells-his-autonomy-to-hewlett-packard Mike Lynch sells his Autonomy to Hewlett-Packard] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111026045226/http://realbusiness.co.uk/news/mike-lynch-sells-his-autonomy-to-hewlett-packard |date=26 October 2011 }} Real Business</ref>
==Disputes== Larry Ellison, the CEO of [[Oracle Corporation|Oracle]], when dealing with Lynch and his colleagues said : "either Mr Lynch has a very poor memory or he is lying".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gizmodo.com.au/2011/09/larry-ellison-of-oracle-calls-autonomy-ceo-lying-liar/|title=Larry Ellison Of Oracle Calls Autonomy CEO Lying Liar|publisher=Gizmodo|date=30 September 2011| accessdate=8 August 2014}}</ref> However Lynch was proved right when [[Frank Quattrone]], Autonomy's advisor, confirmed the presentation at the center of the controversy had been his and not given by Lynch as Oracle had asserted.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theregister.co.uk/2011/09/30/quattrone_says_autonomy_is_right|title=Quattrone blasts Ellison, says Autonomy is right|publisher=The Register|date=30 September 2011|accessdate=8 August 2014}}</ref>
{{see also|Hewlett-Packard#Takeover of Autonomy}} On 20 November 2012, Hewlett-Packard announced a writedown of assets following the Autonomy purchase due to "disclosure failures and outright misrepresentations at Autonomy", which occurred before the acquisition.<ref name= "Open letter from Mike Lynch to the shareholders of Hewlett-Packard">{{cite web|url=http://www.opnlttr.com/letter/open-letter-mike-lynch-shareholders-hewlett-packard|title=Open letter from Mike Lynch to the shareholders of Hewlett-Packard|work=Open Letter|accessdate=16 December 2015}}</ref> The total writedown amounted to $8.8bn of the purchase cost of more than $10bn. <ref name= "Financial Times 20th Nov 2012">{{cite web|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/6d2dd40e-3311-11e2-aabc-00144feabdc0.html#axzz2ClrfUvAF|title=HP takes $8.8bn hit over Autonomy|work=Financial Times|accessdate=16 December 2015}}</ref> These irregularities have been contested.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/11/26/technology/mike-lynch-autonomys-founder-says-hes-baffled-by-hps-claims.html |title=Mike Lynch, Autonomy's Founder, Says He's Baffled by H.P.'s Claims - NYTimes.com |work= |accessdate=2012-11-26}}</ref> HP stated a major part of the issue was it was unaware that Autonomy sold hardware, and claimed that this was booked as software and hidden from the auditors.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www8.hp.com/us/en/hp-news/press-release.html?id=1334263#.U5g0-5SwLwg/|title=HP News - HP Issues Statement Regarding Autonomy Impairment Charge|publisher=}}</ref> <ref>{{cite web|url=https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2012/11/20/h-p-takes-big-hit-on-accounting-improprieties-at-autonomy/?_php=true&_type=blogs&_r=0|title=Hewlett's Loss: A Folly Unfolds, by the Numbers|first=Quentin Hardy and Michael J. de la|last=Merced|publisher=}}</ref> <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2012-11-20/hewlett-packard-profit-forecast-8-8-billion-charge.html/|title=HP Plunges on $8.8 Billion Charge From Autonomy Writedown|first1=Aaron|last1=Ricadela|first2=Amy Thomson-|last2=2012-11-20T22:03:35Z|publisher=}}</ref> An FT investigation unearthed documents that show that HP was in fact aware of Autonomy's hardware sales. They were booked as hardware and were fully disclosed to Deloitte, the Autonomy auditors.<ref name="ft.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/4b0e6140-97d3-11e3-8dc3-00144feab7de.html#slide0/|title=HP/Autonomy investigation: Tangled web of hardware and resellers|work=Financial Times|accessdate=16 December 2015}}</ref>
Lynch wrote an open letter to HP's shareholders, accusing HP of misleading them over the matter.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://autonomyaccounts.org/open-letter-from-mike-lynch-to-the-shareholders-of-hewlett-packard-2/|title=Open letter from Mike Lynch to the shareholders of Hewlett-Packard|publisher=|accessdate=16 December 2015}}</ref> Deloitte have also gone on the record supporting Lynch's opinion.<ref name="ft.com"/> Lynch and other ex-Autonomy executives have set up AutonomyAccounts.org to provide a platform to voice their rebuttal of criticism.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://autonomyaccounts.org/ | title=AutonomyAccounts.org|accessdate=2014-02-22}}</ref>
In August 2014, HP did a deal with law firms suing them on behalf of shareholders over the matter. HP would pay them and they would help HP sue Lynch and the former Autonomy CFO for [[fraud]]. HP's deal was objected to by a number of parties and was considered highly suspect as the lawyers were to be paid but not the shareholders. Judge Breyer threw the case out.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/moneybeat/2014/07/03/dealpolitik-more-evidence-of-broken-shareholder-litigation-system|title=Dealpolitik: More Evidence of Broken Shareholder Litigation System|accessdate=5 August 2014}}</ref> HP's claims were investigated at HP's request by the [[Serious Fraud Office (United Kingdom)|UK Serious Fraud Office]], however the SFO announced in January 2015 that it was ending its investigation with no action.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-30883288|title=Autonomy HP sale investigation by Serious Fraud Office closes|date=19 January 2015|publisher=BBC|accessdate=10 February 2015}}</ref>
On 29 November 2018 he was indicted for fraud in relation to the 2011 deal with HP.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-11-29/ex-autonomy-ceo-lynch-indicted-for-fraud-tied-to-2011-hp-deal?utm_source=google&utm_medium=bd&cmpId=google|title=Ex-Autonomy CEO Michael Lynch Indicted for Fraud Tied to 2011 HP Deal|publisher=Bloomberg|date=29 November 2018|accessdate=30 November 2018}}</ref>
==Personal life== He is married and has two daughters.<ref>[http://autonomyaccounts.org/biography/ Biography] AutonomyAccounts.org</ref> His entry in [[Who's Who (UK)]] lists his recreations as Jazz saxophone and preserving rare breeds.<ref name=whoswho/>
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
{{FRS 2014}} {{Authority control}}
{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2011}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Lynch, Michael Richard}} [[Category:1965 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People educated at Bancroft's School]] [[Category:Irish businesspeople]] [[Category:Officers of the Order of the British Empire]] [[Category:Deputy Lieutenants of Suffolk]] [[Category:Alumni of Christ's College, Cambridge]] [[Category:People from Chelmsford]] [[Category:Fellows of the Royal Society]] [[Category:British venture capitalists]]

revision.text:
{{for|usage in law|Miscarriage of justice}} {{Use mdy dates|date=May 2012}} {{Infobox medical condition (new) | name = Miscarriage | synonyms = Spontaneous abortion, early pregnancy loss | image = Anembryonic gestation.jpg | caption = An [[ultrasound]] showing a [[gestational sac]] containing a [[yolk sac]] but no [[embryo]]. | field = [[Obstetrics]] and [[gynecology]] | symptoms = [[Vaginal bleeding]] with or without pain | complications = Infection, bleeding,{{cite web|title=Spontaneous Abortion - Gynecology and Obstetrics|url=https://www.merckmanuals.com/en-ca/professional/gynecology-and-obstetrics/abnormalities-of-pregnancy/spontaneous-abortion|website=Merck Manuals Professional Edition|accessdate=5 May 2018|language=en-CA}} [[sadness]], [[anxiety]], [[guilt (emotion)|guilt]] | onset = Before 20 weeks of pregnancy | duration = | types = | causes = Chromosomal abnormalities | risks = Being an older parent, previous miscarriage, exposure to tobacco smoke, [[obesity]], [[diabetes mellitus|diabetes]], [[autoimmune disease]]s, drug or alcohol use | diagnosis = Examination, [[human chorionic gonadotropin]], [[ultrasound]] | differential = [[Ectopic pregnancy]], [[implantation bleeding]]. | prevention = [[Prenatal care]] | treatment = [[Expectant management]], [[misoprostol]], [[vacuum aspiration]], emotional support | medication = | prognosis = | frequency = 10–50% of pregnancies | deaths = }} '''Miscarriage''', also known as '''spontaneous abortion''' and '''pregnancy loss''', is the natural death of an [[embryo]] or [[fetus]] before it is [[fetal viability|able to survive independently]].{{cite web|title=What is pregnancy loss/miscarriage?|url=http://www.nichd.nih.gov/health/topics/pregnancyloss/conditioninfo/Pages/default.aspx|website=www.nichd.nih.gov/|accessdate=14 March 2015|date=2013-07-15|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402121055/http://www.nichd.nih.gov/health/topics/pregnancyloss/conditioninfo/Pages/default.aspx|archivedate=April 2, 2015|df=mdy-all}} Some use the cutoff of 20 weeks of [[gestation]], after which fetal death is known as a [[stillbirth]].{{cite web|title=Stillbirth: Overview|url=https://www.nichd.nih.gov/health/topics/stillbirth/Pages/default.aspx|website=NICHD|accessdate=4 October 2016|date=23 September 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161005085055/https://www.nichd.nih.gov/health/topics/stillbirth/Pages/default.aspx|archivedate=October 5, 2016|df=mdy-all}} The most common symptom of a miscarriage is [[vaginal bleeding]] with or without pain. [[Sadness]], [[anxiety]] and [[guilt (emotion)|guilt]] often occur afterwards.{{cite journal|last1=Robinson|first1=GE|title=Pregnancy loss|journal=Best Practice & Research. Clinical Obstetrics & Gynaecology|date=January 2014|volume=28|issue=1|pages=169–78|pmid=24047642|doi=10.1016/j.bpobgyn.2013.08.012}}{{Cite journal|last=Radford|first=Eleanor J|last2=Hughes|first2=Mark|date=2015-06-01|title=Women's experiences of early miscarriage: implications for nursing care|journal=Journal of Clinical Nursing|language=en|volume=24|issue=11–12|pages=1457–1465|doi=10.1111/jocn.12781|pmid=25662397|issn=1365-2702}} [[Tissue (biology)|Tissue]] and clot-like material may leave the uterus and pass through and out of the [[vagina]].{{cite web|title=What are the symptoms of pregnancy loss/miscarriage?|url=http://www.nichd.nih.gov/health/topics/pregnancyloss/conditioninfo/Pages/symptoms.aspx|website=www.nichd.nih.gov/|accessdate=14 March 2015|date=2013-07-15|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402113638/http://www.nichd.nih.gov/health/topics/pregnancyloss/conditioninfo/Pages/symptoms.aspx|archivedate=April 2, 2015|df=mdy-all}} When a woman keeps having miscarriages, [[infertility]] is present.{{Cite web|url=https://www.womenshealth.gov/glossary/|title=Glossary {{!}} womenshealth.gov|website=womenshealth.gov|language=en|access-date=2017-09-11}}{{PD-notice}} Risk factors for miscarriage include an older parent, previous miscarriage, exposure to tobacco smoke, [[obesity]], [[diabetes mellitus|diabetes]], thyroid problems, and drug or alcohol use. About 80% of miscarriages occur in the first 12 weeks of pregnancy (the [[first trimester]]). The underlying cause in about half of cases involves [[chromosomal abnormalities]].{{cite journal|last1=Vaiman|first1=Daniel|title=Genetic regulation of recurrent spontaneous abortion in humans|journal=Biomedical Journal|volume=38|issue=1|year=2015|pages=11–24|doi=10.4103/2319-4170.133777|pmid=25179715}} Diagnosis of a miscarriage may involve checking to see if the [[cervix]] is open or closed, testing blood levels of [[human chorionic gonadotropin]] (hCG), and an [[ultrasound]].{{cite web|title=How do health care providers diagnose pregnancy loss or miscarriage?|url=http://www.nichd.nih.gov/health/topics/pregnancyloss/conditioninfo/Pages/diagnosed.aspx|website=www.nichd.nih.gov/|accessdate=14 March 2015|date=2013-07-15}} Other conditions that can produce similar symptoms include an [[ectopic pregnancy]] and [[implantation bleeding]]. Prevention is occasionally possible with good [[prenatal care]]. Avoiding drugs, alcohol, infectious diseases, and [[radiation]] may decrease the risk of miscarriage.{{cite web|title=Is there a cure for pregnancy loss/miscarriage?|url=http://www.nichd.nih.gov/health/topics/pregnancyloss/conditioninfo/Pages/cure.aspx|website=www.nichd.nih.gov/|accessdate=14 March 2015|date=2013-10-21|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402181042/http://www.nichd.nih.gov/health/topics/pregnancyloss/conditioninfo/Pages/cure.aspx|archivedate=April 2, 2015|df=mdy-all}} No specific treatment is usually needed during the first 7 to 14 days. Most miscarriages will complete without additional interventions.
