{{For|the game|The Political Machine}} [[File:New York's New Solar System2.jpg|thumb|300px|In this 1899 [[Udo Keppler]] cartoon from ''[[Puck (magazine)|Puck]]'', all of New York City politics revolves around boss [[Richard Croker]].]] A '''political machine''' is a political group in which an authoritative boss or small group commands the support of a corps of supporters and businesses (usually [[Political campaign|campaign workers]]), who receive rewards for their efforts. The machine's power is based on the ability of the nuggets to [[get out the vote]] for their candidates on election day. Although these elements are common to most political parties and organizations, they are essential to political machines, which rely on hierarchy and rewards for political power, often enforced by a strong [[Whip (politics)|party whip]] structure. Machines sometimes have a [[political boss]], often rely on [[patronage]], the [[spoils system]], "behind-the-scenes" control, and longstanding political ties within the structure of a [[representative democracy]]. Machines typically are organized on a permanent basis instead of a single election or event. The term may have a pejorative sense referring to corrupt political machines.{{Cite encyclopedia | title = political machine | url = http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/467617/political-machine | encyclopedia = Encyclopædia Britannica | accessdate = December 6, 2008}} The term "political machine" dates back to the 20th century in the United States, where such organizations have existed in some municipalities and states since the 18th century. Similar machines have been described in [[Latin America]], where the system has been called ''[[:en:clientelism|clientelism]]'' or '''''political clientelism''''' (after the similar [[:Clientela|Clientela]] relationship in the [[Roman Republic]]), especially in rural areas, and also in some African states and other emerging democracies, like postcommunist Eastern European countries. Japan's [[Liberal Democratic Party (Japan)|Liberal Democratic Party]] is often cited as another political machine, maintaining power in [[suburb]]an and [[rural]] areas through its control of farm bureaus and road construction agencies.{{cite book | title = The American Journey, Reconstruction to the Present |edition=Student | year = 2005 | publisher = Glencoe/McGraw-Hill | ISBN=0078609801}} In Japan, the word ''jiban'' (literally "base" or "foundation") is the word used for political machines.{{cite book | last = Safire |first= Nicole |title = Safire's Political Dictionary | pages = 391–392 | chapter = "Machine politics" | edition = First | year = 1978 |publisher = Random House}} (although the book existed in an earlier version titled "The New Language of Politics"){{citation |url = https://books.google.com/books?id=Bo0KAAAAIAAJ&q=%22roman+republic%22+%22political+patronage%22&dq=%22roman+republic%22+%22political+patronage%22&lr=&pgis=1 | title = Editorial Research Reports| publisher = Congressional Quarterly | year = 1973 |volume= 1}} ==Definition== The ''Encyclopædia Britannica'' defines "political machine" as, "in U.S. politics, a party organization, headed by a [[political boss|single boss]] or small autocratic group, that commands enough votes to maintain political and administrative control of a city, county, or state". [[William Safire]], in his ''Safire's Political Dictionary'', defines "machine politics" as "the election of officials and the passage of legislation through the power of an organization created for political action". He notes that the term is generally considered pejorative, often implying corruption. Hierarchy and discipline are hallmarks of political machines. "It generally means strict organization", according to Safire. Quoting [[Edward J. Flynn|Edward Flynn]], a [[Bronx County]] Democratic leader who ran the borough from 1922 until his death in 1953,{{cite book | last = Glazer |first = Nathan |last2=Monyhan |first2=Daniel Patrick |title =Beyond the Melting Pot: The Negroes, Puerto Ricans, Jews, Italians and Irish of New York | chapter = The Irish | page = 226 |publisher = The MIT Press |year = 1963 |quote = Ed Flynn ran the Bronx from 1922 until his death in 1953.}} he wrote "[...] the so-called 'independent' voter is foolish to assume that a political machine is run solely on good will, or patronage. For it is not only a machine; it is an army. And in any organization as in any army, there must be discipline." Political patronage, while often associated with political machines, is not essential to the definition for either Safire or ''Britannica.'' == Function == A political machine is a party organization that recruits its members by the use of tangible incentives—money, political jobs—and that is characterized by a high degree of leadership control over member activity. Political machines started as [[grass roots]] organizations to gain the [[patronage]] needed to win the modern election. Having strong patronage, these "clubs" were the main driving force in gaining and getting out the "straight party vote" in the election districts.{{cite book | first = James Q. |last = Wilson | authorlink = James Q. Wilson | title = [[American Government]] | publisher = Houghton Mifflin Harcourt | year = 2005}} == In the United States == [[File:Boss tweed.jpg|right|thumb|1869 tobacco label featuring [[William M. Tweed]], 19th-century political boss of New York City]] In the late 19th century, large cities in the United States—[[Boston]], [[Chicago]], [[Cleveland]], [[Kansas City, Missouri|Kansas City]], [[New York City]], [[Philadelphia]], [[St. Louis, Missouri|St. Louis]]—were accused of using political machines.{{Cite book|title=The Americans: Reconstruction to the 21st Century: California Teacher's Edition |location=Evanston |publisher=McDougall Littell Inc |year=2006 |pages=267–268 |isbn= 978-0618184163}} During this time "cities experienced rapid growth under inefficient government". Each city's machine lived under a hierarchical system with a [[political boss|"boss"]] who held the allegiance of local business leaders, [[elected officials]] and their appointees, and who knew the proverbial buttons to push to get things done. Benefits and problems both resulted from the rule of political machines.{{Cite journal|journal=The American Journal of Sociology |volume=20 |year = 1914–1915|quote=The political machine is in fact an attempt to maintain, inside the formal administrative organization of the city, the control of a primary group. |page=603 |first=Herbert |last=Blumer | jstor = 2763406 | title = The City: Suggestions for the Investigation of Human Behavior in the City Environment | doi = 10.1086/212433 }}{{Cite journal|doi=10.1177/000271623316900104 |title=The Political Party versus the Political Machine |journal=Annals of the American Academy of Political and Social Science |first=Harold F. |last=Gosnell |volume=169 |date=September 1933 |pages=21–28 |quote=When the spoils element is predominant in a political organization, it is called a political machine.}} This system of political control—known as "[[bossism]]"—emerged particularly in the [[Gilded Age]]. A single powerful figure (the boss) was at the center and was bound together to a complex organization of lesser figures (the political machine) by reciprocity in promoting financial and social self-interest. One of the most infamous of these political machines was [[Tammany Hall]], the [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic Party]] machine that played a major role in controlling [[New York City]] and New York politics and helping immigrants, most notably the Irish, rise up in American politics from the 1790s to the 1960s. From 1872, Tammany had an Irish "boss". However, Tammany Hall also served as an engine for [[Graft (politics)|graft]] and political corruption, perhaps most notoriously under [[William M. Tweed|William M. "Boss" Tweed]] in the mid-19th century. [[Lord Bryce]] describes these political bosses saying: {{quote|An army led by a council seldom conquers: It must have a commander-in-chief, who settles disputes, decides in emergencies, inspires fear or attachment. The head of the Ring is such a commander. He dispenses places, rewards the loyal, punishes the mutinous, concocts schemes, negotiates treaties. He generally avoids publicity, preferring the substance to the pomp of power, and is all the more dangerous because he sits, like a spider, hidden in the midst of his web. He is a Boss.{{citation | work = Digital History | title = Urban Political Machines | url = http://www.digitalhistory.uh.edu/historyonline/us28.cfm | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080821152014/http://www.digitalhistory.uh.edu/historyonline/us28.cfm | archivedate = 2008-08-21 | df = }}}} When asked if he was a boss, [[James Pendergast]] said simply, {{quote|I've been called a boss. All there is to it is having friends, doing things for people, and then later on they'll do things for you... You can't coerce people into doing things for you—you can't make them vote for you. I never coerced anybody in my life. Wherever you see a man bulldozing anybody he don't last long.}} [[Theodore Roosevelt]], before he became president in 1901, was deeply involved in New York City politics. He explains how the machine worked:
The organization of a party in our city is really much like that of an army. There is one great central boss, assisted by some trusted and able lieutenants; these communicate with the different district bosses, whom they alternately bully and assist. The district boss in turn has a number of half-subordinates, half-allies, under him; these latter choose the captains of the election districts, etc., and come into contact with the common heelers.{{cite book|author=Theodore Roosevelt|title=The Works of Theodore Roosevelt: American ideals|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pqo3AQAAMAAJ&pg=PA132|year=1897|publisher=Collier|pages=132–33}}
===Voting strategy=== Many machines formed in cities to serve immigrants to the U.S. in the late 19th century who viewed machines as a vehicle for political [[enfranchisement]]. Machine workers helped win elections by turning out large numbers of voters on election day. It was in the machine's interests to only maintain a minimally winning amount of support. Once they were in the majority and could count on a win, there was less need to recruit new members, as this only meant a thinner spread of the patronage rewards to be spread among the party members. As such, later-arriving immigrants, such as Jews, Italians, and other immigrants from Southern and Eastern Europe between the 1880s and 1910s, saw fewer rewards from the machine system than the well-established Irish.{{cite book|author=Steven P. Erie|title=Rainbow's End: Irish-Americans and the Dilemmas of Urban Machine Politics, 1840-1985|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=NxrGXFRlbWgC&pg=PA7|year=1990|publisher=U of California Press|pages=7–8}} At the same time, the machines' staunchest opponents were members of the middle class, who were shocked at the malfeasance and did not need the financial help.Ari A. Hoogenboom, "An Analysis of Civil Service Reformers". ''Historian'' 23#1 (1960): 54–78. The corruption of [[urban politics in the United States]] was denounced by private citizens. They achieved national and state civil-service reform and worked to replace local patronage systems with [[civil service]]. By [[Theodore Roosevelt]]'s time, the [[Progressive Era]] mobilized millions of private citizens to vote against the machines.{{cite journal | last1 = Ruhil | first1 = Anirudh V.S. | year = 2003 | title = Urban Armageddon or politics as usual? The case of municipal civil service reform | url = | journal = American Journal of Political Science | volume = 47 | issue = 1| pages = 159–170 | doi=10.1111/1540-5907.00011}} In the 1930s, [[James A. Farley]] was the chief dispenser of the Democratic Party's patronage system through the [[United States Post Office Department|Post Office]] and the [[Works Progress Administration]] which eventually nationalized many of the job benefits machines provided. The [[New Deal]] allowed machines to recruit for the WPA and [[Civilian Conservation Corps]], making Farley's machine the most powerful. All patronage was screened through Farley, including presidential appointments. The [[New Deal]] machine fell apart after he left the administration over the third term in 1940. Those agencies were abolished in 1943 and the machines suddenly lost much of their patronage. The formerly poor immigrants who had benefited under Farley's national machine had become assimilated and prosperous and no longer needed the informal or extralegal aides provided by machines. In the 1940s most of the big city machines collapsed, with the exception of Chicago.{{citation | title = Political Machines | url = http://autocww.colorado.edu/~toldy2/E64ContentFiles/PoliticsAndGovernment/PoliticalMachines.htm | publisher = University of Colorado, Boulder}} A local political machine in [[Tennessee]] was forcibly removed in what was known as the [[Battle of Athens (1946)|1946 Battle of Athens]]. Smaller communities such as [[Parma, Ohio]], in the post–Cold War Era under Prosecutor Bill Mason's "Good Old Boys" and especially communities in the Deep South, where small-town machine politics are relatively common, also feature what might be classified as political machines, although these organizations do not have the power and influence of the larger boss networks listed in this article. For example, the "Cracker Party" was a Democratic Party political machine that dominated city politics in [[Augusta, Georgia]], for over half of the 20th century.{{cite news | url = http://chronicle.augusta.com/stories/110799/opi_124-1871.shtml | title = Newspapers helped end long rule of corrupt Cracker Party | date = August 29, 2010 | newspaper = The Augusta Chronicle}}{{cite news | url = http://search.augusta.com/fast-elements.php?type=standard&profile=augustachronicle&querystring=%22cracker+party%22&Go.x=0&Go.y=0&Go=Go | title = Search results for 'Cracker Party' | accessdate = 13 November 2012 | newspaper = The Augusta Chronicle}}{{cite web|url=http://www.augusta.com/leaders/slideshow_local/slide14.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=March 11, 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050212142225/http://www.augusta.com/leaders/slideshow_local/slide14.html |archivedate=February 12, 2005 }}{{cite web | url = http://www.georgiaencyclopedia.org/nge/Article.jsp?id=h-955 | title = Cites & Counties: Augusta | publisher = The New Georgia Encyclopedia | first = Edward J. |last = Cashin | date = 2007-02-19}}{{cite web|url=http://www.augusta.com/leaders/slideshow_local/slide10.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=March 11, 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050324073605/http://www.augusta.com/leaders/slideshow_local/slide10.html |archivedate=March 24, 2005 }} Political machines also thrive on Native American reservations, where the veil of sovereignty is used as a shield against federal and state laws against the practice.Fink, James (September 26, 2016). [http://www.bizjournals.com/buffalo/news/2016/09/26/gates-overtakes-snyder-r-in-seneca-nation-vote.html?ana=twt Gates overtakes Snyder in Seneca nation vote]. ''Business First''. Retrieved September 26, 2016. ==Evaluation== The phrase is considered derogatory "because it suggests that the interest of the organization are placed before those of the general public", according to Safire. Machines are criticized as undemocratic and inevitably encouraging corruption. Since the 1960s, some historians have reevaluated political machines, considering them corrupt but efficient. Machines were undemocratic but responsive. They were also able to contain the spending demands of special interests. In ''Mayors and Money'', a comparison of municipal government in Chicago and New York, [[Ester R. Fuchs]] credited the [[Cook County Democratic Organization]] with giving Mayor [[Richard J. Daley]] the political power to deny [[labor union]] contracts that the city could not afford and to make the state government assume burdensome costs like [[Welfare (financial aid)|welfare]] and courts. Describing New York, Fuchs wrote, "New York got reform, but it never got good government." At the same time, as Dennis R. Judd and Todd Swanstrom suggest in ''City Politics'' that this view accompanied the common belief that there were no viable alternatives. They go on to point out that this is a falsehood, since there are certainly examples of reform oriented, anti-machine leaders during this time. In his mid-2016 article "How American Politics Went Insane" in ''[[The Atlantic]]'', [[Jonathan Rauch]] argued that the political machines of the past had flaws but provided better governance than the alternatives. He wrote that political machines created positive incentives for politicians to work together and compromise – as opposed to pursuing "naked self-interest" the whole time.{{cite web|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/magazine/archive/2016/07/how-american-politics-went-insane/485570/|title=How American Politics Went Insane|author=[[Jonathan Rauch]]|publisher=''[[The Atlantic]]''|date=June 2016|accessdate=January 31, 2018}} ==See also== {{Portal|Political science}} * [[Clientelism]] * [[Cook County Democratic Party]] * [[County-unit system]] * [[Earmark (politics)|Earmarks]] * [[Byrd Organization|The Byrd Organization]] * [[E. H. Crump]] * [[Tammany Hall]] * [[Huey Long]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} == Further reading== * {{Cite book|title=The Political Machine: An American Institution |first=Thomas P |last = Clifford |publisher=Vantage Press |year=1975 |isbn=0-533-01374-7}} * {{Cite book|title=Machine Politics: Chicago Model |first=Harold Foote |last=Gosnell |publisher=University of Chicago Press |year=1968|isbn=0-226-30492-2}} * {{Cite book|title=Boss Platt and His New York Machine: A Study of the Political Leadership of Thomas C. Platt, Theodore Roosevelt and Others|first=Harold F |last = Gosnell |first2=Charles E |last2=Merriam |publisher=Lightning Source Inc |year=2007 |isbn=1-4325-8850-8}} * {{Cite book|title=Political Machine: What It Is, How It Works|first=Gerald |last=Kurland|publisher=Story House Corp |year=1972 |isbn=0-686-07238-3}} * Matlin, John S. "Political Party Machines of the 1920s and 1930s: Tom Pendergast and the Kansas City Democratic machine." (PhD Dissertation, University of Birmingham, UK, 2009) [http://etheses.bham.ac.uk/449/1/Matlin09PhD_A1a.pdf online]; Bibliography on pp 277–92. * {{Cite book|title=Tammany; the Evolution of a Political Machine, 1789-1865 |first=Jerome |last =Mushkat |publisher=Syracuse University Press |year=1971|isbn=0-8156-0079-8}} * {{Cite book|title=The Donegal Mafia: An Irish Political Machine |first=Paul Martin |last = Sachs |publisher=University of California |year=1974 |isbn=0-300-02020-1}} * {{Cite book|title=Shadow Shoguns: The Rise and Fall of Japan's Postwar Political Machine|first=Jacob M. |last =Schlesinger |publisher=Stanford University Press |year=1999 |isbn=0-8047-3457-7}} * {{cite journal | last = Tuckel | first= P. |last2= Maisel |first2= R. |year = 2008 | title = Nativity Status and Voter Turnout in Early Twentieth-Century Urban United States | journal = Historical Methods | volume = 41 | issue= 2 |pages = 99–107 | doi=10.3200/hmts.41.2.99-108}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Political Machine}} [[Category:Organized crime activity]] [[Category:Political concepts]] [[Category:Political corruption]] [[Category:Political whips]] [[Category:Public administration]] [[Category:Public choice theory]]

{{Infobox person | image = Richard John Kerry.jpg | birth_name = Richard John Kerry | birth_date = July 28, 1915 | birth_place = [[Brookline, Massachusetts]], U.S. | death_date = {{death date and age|2000|7|29 |1915|7|28 |mf=y}} | death_place = [[Boston]], [[Massachusetts]], U.S. | resting_place = [[Mount Auburn Cemetery]] | spouse = {{marriage|[[Rosemary Forbes Kerry|Rosemary Forbes]]|1941|2000|end=died}} | occupation = Diplomat, lawyer | children = Margaret, [[John Kerry|John]], Diana, and [[Cameron Kerry|Cameron]] | relations = [[Alexandra Kerry|Alexandra Forbes Kerry]] (granddaughter)
[[Vanessa Kerry|Vanessa Bradford Kerry]] (granddaughter) | education = [[Phillips Academy]] | alma_mater = [[Yale University]]
[[Harvard Law School]] }} '''Richard John Kerry''' (July 28, 1915 – July 29, 2000) was an American [[United States Foreign Service|Foreign Service]] officer and lawyer. He was the father of politicians [[John Kerry]] and [[Cameron Kerry]]. ==Early life== Kerry was born in [[Brookline, Massachusetts]], to Austrian-born shoe merchant Frederick A. "Fred" Kerry (May 11, 1873 – November 23, 1921) and Hungarian-born musician Ida Löwe (February 20, 1877 – January 19, 1960). He had an elder brother Eric (born c. 1901) and an elder sister Mildred (born 1910). Fred and Ida had changed their names from "Fritz and Ida Kohn" to "Frederick and Ida Kerry" in 1900 and converted from [[Judaism]] to [[Catholicism]] in 1901{{cite news|author1=Kranish, Michael |author2=Mooney, Brian C. |author3=Easton, Nina J. |title=John Kerry: The Complete Biography by ''The Boston Globe'' Reporters Who Know Him Best |newspaper=[[The Boston Globe]]|publisher=[[John W. Henry]]|date=April 27, 2004}}{{cite news |title=Hearing of roots, Czech village roots Kerry on |author=Whitmore, Brian |date=February 22, 2004 |newspaper=The Boston Globe|publisher=John W. Henry}} or 1902.{{cite news |url=http://boston.com/globe/nation/packages/kerry/061503.shtml |title=A privileged youth, a taste for risk |author=Kranish, Michael |newspaper=The Boston Globe|publisher=John W. Henry |date=June 15, 2003 |accessdate=January 8, 2008}} They were baptized at the same time as Eric. Fred's brother Otto also embraced Catholicism and took on the "Kerry" name.{{cite news |title=Kerry's Grandfather Left Judaism Behind in Europe |last=Berger|first=Joseph |date=May 16, 2004 |newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|publisher=[[Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, Jr.]]|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9E0CEEDF173FF935A25756C0A9629C8B63 |accessdate=January 8, 2008}} The "Kerry" name, widely misinterpreted as indicative of [[Ireland|Irish]] heritage, was reputedly selected arbitrarily: "According to family legend, Fritz and another family member opened an atlas at random and dropped a pencil on a map. It fell on County Kerry in Ireland, and thus a name was chosen." Leaving their hometown [[Mödling]], a suburb of [[Vienna]] where they had lived since 1896, Fred, Ida, and Eric emigrated to the United States in 1905, living at first in [[Chicago]] and eventually moving to [[Brookline, Massachusetts]], by 1915. For a time, Fred Kerry was prosperous and successful in shoe business. Because of his wealth, the family was able to afford to travel to Europe in the autumn of 1921, returning on October 21. A few weeks later, on November 15, Fred Kerry filed a will leaving everything to Ida and then, on November 23, walked into a washroom of the [[The Fairmont Copley Plaza Hotel|Copley Plaza]] Hotel in Boston and committed [[suicide]] by shooting himself in the head with a handgun. The suicide was front-page news in all of the Boston newspapers, reporting at the time that the motive was severe [[asthma]] and related health problems, but family members stated that the motive was financial trouble: "He had made three fortunes and when he had lost the third fortune, he couldn't face it anymore", according to Eric's daughter Nancy. John Kerry has said that although he knew his paternal grandfather had come from Austria, he did not know until informed by ''[[The Boston Globe]]'' in January 2003 on the basis of their genealogical research that Fred Kerry had changed his name from "Fritz Kohn" and converted from Judaism to Catholicism nor that Ida's brother Otto and sister Jenni had died in [[Nazi concentration camps]]. Richard Kerry attended [[Phillips Academy]], graduated from [[Yale University]] in 1937, and received his law degree from [[Harvard Law School]] in 1940.{{cite book|last1=Kranish|first1=Michael|last2=Mooney|first2=Brian C.|last3=Easton|first3=Nina J.|title=John F. Kerry: The Complete Biography By The Boston Globe Reporters Who Know Him Best|year=2004|publisher=The Boston Globe|pages=13|url=https://books.google.com/?id=NTBBcBYFs-8C&pg=PA13|isbn=9781586482732}} ==Career== Kerry joined the [[United States Army Air Corps]] in [[World War II]] and volunteered to become a [[test pilot]]. He flew [[Douglas C-47 Skytrain|C-47s]] and [[Boeing B-29 Superfortress|B-29s]] until contracting [[tuberculosis]], after which he was discharged. Upon returning to [[Massachusetts]] after convalescing in [[Colorado]], he became an [[Assistant United States Attorney]]. He moved to [[Washington, D.C.]], in 1949, where he worked in the office of the General Counsel for the [[United States Department of the Navy|Navy Department]].{{cite news|last=Purdum|first=Todd S.|title=Prep School Peers Found Kerry Talented, Ambitious and Apart|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2004/05/16/us/prep-school-peers-found-kerry-talented-ambitious-and-apart.html|accessdate=January 25, 2013|newspaper=The New York Times|publisher=Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, Jr.|date=May 16, 2004}} Richard significantly influenced his son John's political views, and the two frequently bonded over politics. However, he was often emotionally distant from his son when not discussing politics.{{cite news|last=Mohler Jr.|first=R. Albert|title=Like Father, Like Son—John Kerry's Dangerous Worldview|url=http://www.christianheadlines.com/columnists/al-mohler/like-father-like-son-john-kerrys-dangerous-worldview-1292846.html|accessdate=April 28, 2014|newspaper=Christian Headlines}} Kerry entered the American foreign service and served as a [[diplomat]] in positions both in the United States and at foreign embassies, including in [[Germany]] and [[Norway]]. He also served as a lawyer in the [[Bureau of United Nations Affairs]].Bruce Harrison, [https://books.google.com/books?id=ZNO3WVTokk0C&pg=PA3117& The Family Forest: Descendants of Lady Joan Beaufort], 1998, page 3117 Kerry authored ''The Star Spangled Mirror: America's Image of Itself and the World'' in 1990.Richard J. Kerry, [https://books.google.com/books?id=kxpx_IbNMQIC&printsec=frontcover&dq=%22kerry,+richard+j.%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=DBjVUKieG4je9ATz44GoCg&ved=0CDEQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=%22kerry%2C%20richard%20j.%22&f=false The Star Spangled Mirror: America's Image of Itself and the World], 1990 and 2004, title page In retirement Kerry engaged in his passion for sailing, making several [[Atlantic Ocean|Atlantic]] crossings, sailing the [[New England]] and [[Nova Scotia]] coasts solo, and racing [[sloop]]s.Evan Thomas, Newsweek magazine, [http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=NWEC&p_theme=nwec&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=10C2743DB08B6610&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM The Solitary Soldier], August 2, 2004 ==Personal life== Kerry met nurse [[Rosemary Forbes Kerry|Rosemary Isabel Forbes]] in 1938 in [[Saint-Briac-sur-Mer|Saint Briac]], France, where he was taking a course in the sculpture of ship models and she was training as a nurse. They married on February 8, 1941, in [[Montgomery, Alabama]], while he was a Cadet in the [[United States Army Air Corps|Army Air Corps]]. They had four children: Margaret (born 1941); [[John Kerry]] (born 1943); Diana (born 1947); and [[Cameron Kerry|Cameron]] (born 1950).Sarasota Herald-Tribune, [https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=2h4hAAAAIBAJ&sjid=lWQEAAAAIBAJ&pg=2880,3688348&dq=richard-john-kerry&hl=en Miss Forbes, Lieut. Kerry Are Married], February 16, 1941Boston Herald, [https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/bostonherald/access/57389785.html?dids=57389785:57389785&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Jul+31%2C+2000&author=&pub=Boston+Herald&desc=Obituary%3B+Richard+J.+Kerry%2C+at+85%2C+ex-Foreign+Service+officer&pqatl=google Obituary: Richard J. Kerry], July 31, 2000 Kerry died in at [[Massachusetts General Hospital]] on July 29, 2000 at age 85 from prostate cancer complications.Associated Press, [https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=kiRHAAAAIBAJ&sjid=s_MMAAAAIBAJ&pg=4801,5758839&dq=richard+kerry+died+prostate+cancer&hl=en Richard Kerry, Father of Sen. John Kerry, Dies], Lewiston Sun-Journal, July 31, 2000 He was buried in [[Mount Auburn Cemetery]].{{cite web|last=Trapp|first=Christie|title=Richard John Kerry|url=https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/64357795|work=Find a Grave|accessdate=April 5, 2014}} ==References== {{Reflist|2}} {{John Kerry|state=collapsed}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Kerry, Richard J.}} [[Category:1915 births]] [[Category:2000 deaths]] [[Category:American diplomats]] [[Category:American lawyers]] [[Category:American military personnel of World War II]] [[Category:American people of Austrian-Jewish descent]] [[Category:American people of Hungarian-Jewish descent]] [[Category:American Roman Catholics]] [[Category:Burials in Massachusetts]] [[Category:Deaths from prostate cancer]] [[Category:Dudley–Winthrop family]] [[Category:Forbes family]] [[Category:Harvard Law School alumni]] [[Category:Kerry family]] [[Category:Massachusetts lawyers]] [[Category:Phillips Academy alumni]] [[Category:Yale University alumni]]

{{Infobox person | image = | name = Robert A. Berman | image_size = | caption = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1959|12|08}} | birth_place = [[US]] | birth_name = | nationality = American | occupation = [[Businessman]] | salary = | notable works = [[Empire Resorts]], [[Monticello Raceway]] | spouse = Valerie J Berman | years_active = 1995-present | residence = [[Washington, D.C.]], U.S. | children = 2 }}
'''Robert A. Berman''' (born December 8, 1959) is an American [[businessman]]<ref>{{cite web|work = Forbes |title = Cancer And The Presidency: Why This CEO Says Each Candidate Needs A Plan |url = https://www.forbes.com/sites/arleneweintraub/2016/03/30/cancer-and-the-presidency-why-this-ceo-says-each-candidate-needs-a-plan/#484024672927 }}</ref> known for his contributions to the [[casino industry]] in the [[US]].<ref>{{cite web|work = New York Times |title = In Catskills, the Long Wait for a Casino Nears an End |url = https://www.nytimes.com/2014/12/19/nyregion/in-the-catskills-the-long-wait-for-a-casino-is-over.html?_r=0 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|work = Indianz |title =Donald Trump tried to bully his way into New York tribe's casino bid |url = http://www.indianz.com/IndianGaming/2016/04/18/donald-trump-tried-to-bully-hi.asp }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|work = Sullivan County Post |title =Comedy Hall of Fame a Brilliant Idea |url = http://www.sullivancountypost.com/2012/07/27/comedy-hall-of-fame-a-brilliant-idea/ }}</ref> He has owned and directed several prominent organizations and companies including [[Empire Resorts]] and [[Monticello Raceway]].<ref>{{cite web|work = Business Wire |title =Empire Resorts Announces Departure of Robert Berman |url = http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20051012005967/en/Empire-Resorts-Announces-Departure-Robert-Berman}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|work = Times Union |title =James Odato: If state is to blame, we'll pay price |url = http://www.timesunion.com/local/article/James-Odato-If-state-is-to-blame-we-ll-pay-price-5709744.php}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|work = Village Voice |title =The New Dealer |url = http://www.villagevoice.com/news/the-new-dealer-6425312}}</ref> He has also formed partnerships with numerous institutional investors, which led to the acquisition of hotel properties across the [[US]].<ref>{{cite web|work = New York Times |title =In Catskills, the Long Wait for a Casino Nears an End |url = https://www.nytimes.com/2014/12/19/nyregion/in-the-catskills-the-long-wait-for-a-casino-is-over.html?_r=0}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|work =Wall Street Journal |title =Catskills Poised for Casinos |url = https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052702303936904579176201715452682}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|work =Times Union |title =James Odato: If state is to blame, we'll pay price |url = http://www.timesunion.com/local/article/James-Odato-If-state-is-to-blame-we-ll-pay-price-5709744.php}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|work =Brown University (New York Times) |title =Now Appearing in Borscht Belt, Developers Betting on a Casino |url = http://www.brown.edu/Research/Catskills_Institute//news/casino.shtml}}</ref> Berman’s plans to develop a casino 90 miles from [[New York City]] led to a contentious battle with [[Donald Trump]]<ref>{{cite web|work =LA Times |title =Trump was once so involved in trying to block an Indian casino that he secretly approved attack ads |url = http://www.latimes.com/politics/la-na-pol-trump-anti-indian-campaign-20160630-snap-story.html}}</ref> that later led to Trump receiving the largest fine in the history of [[New York (state)|New York]] State’s lobbying commission.<ref>{{cite web|work =NY Daily |title = Trump, Atlantic City could lose big |url = http://www.nydailynews.com/archives/news/catskill-casino-plan-war-trump-atlantic-city-lose-big-article-1.514367}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|work =The Boston Globe |title = Casino case raises issues of money, politics |url = http://cache.boston.com/globe/nation/packages/gaming/casino_case_raises_issues_of_money_politics.htm}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|work =New York Times |title = Against All Odds, a Complicated Casino Proposal Advances |url = https://www.nytimes.com/2000/04/17/nyregion/against-all-odds-a-complicated-casino-proposal-advances.html?pagewanted=all}}</ref> He was involved in several projects concerning the development of [[Native American gaming]] in the [[New York (state)|New York]] and [[Idaho]] area.<ref>{{cite web|work =The Spokesman |title = Investors Line Up For Piece Of Tribe’s Action National Indian Lottery Needs Big Stake For Set-Up Costs |url = http://www.spokesman.com/stories/1995/apr/02/investors-line-up-for-piece-of-tribes-action/}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|work =New York Times |title = Against All Odds, a Complicated Casino Proposal Advances |url = https://www.nytimes.com/2000/04/17/nyregion/against-all-odds-a-complicated-casino-proposal-advances.html}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|work =New York Times |title = Spitzer Backs Plan for Indian Casino in Catskills |url = https://www.nytimes.com/2007/02/20/nyregion/20casino.html}}</ref>
==Early life ==
Robert A. Berman’s father, Pip Berman, was a [[building contractor]] known for expanding the [[Concord Resort Hotel]] and the [[Imperial Room]] nightclub where [[Milton Berle]], [[Sid Caesar]], [[Buddy Hackett]], [[Joan Rivers]] and [[Jerry Seinfeld]] performed.<ref>{{cite web|work =New York Times |title=The Long Wait For A Casino Is Over|url =https://www.nytimes.com/2014/12/19/nyregion/in-the-catskills-the-long-wait-for-a-casino-is-over.html?_r=0}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|work =Barbra Archives |title=Concord Hotel |url =http://barbra-archives.com/live/60s/concord_hotel_streisand.html}}</ref> At 19 years of age, Robert A. Berman received the first mass gathering permit to operate an outdoor music festival in [[Sullivan County, New York]] where a decade earlier the 1969 [[Woodstock Music Festival]] was held. Collaborating with music impresario [[Sid Bernstein]] on the site of the former Avon Lodge Hotel in Woodridge, [[New York (state)|New York]], Berman opened Music Mountain hosting artists including [[The Doobie Brothers]], members of the Grateful Dead as the Jerry Garcia band and Bobby and the Midnights, [[Ozzy Osbourne]], [[The Allman Brothers]] Band, [[Carlos Santana]] and various others.<ref>{{cite web|work =New York Times |title=Complicated Casino Proposal Advances |url =https://www.nytimes.com/2000/04/17/nyregion/against-all-odds-a-complicated-casino-proposal-advances.html?pagewanted=all}}</ref>
==Career==
From 1995 to 2000, Berman co-founded and served as chairman and chief executive officer of Hospitality Worldwide Services (HWS), a publicly traded platform that became one of the most prominent service providers in the [[Hospitality Industry]]. By 1998, HWS had several thousand employees with offices around the world.<ref>{{cite web|work =The Free Library |title= Hospitality Worldwide Establishes Divisional Structure |url =http://www.thefreelibrary.com/Hospitality+Worldwide+Services+establishes+divisional+structure+to...-a019251629}}</ref>
From 1995 to 2000, Berman formed partnerships with institutional investors including [[ING]] and [[Apollo Global Management]], which led to the acquisition of more than $100M worth of hotel properties including the Warwick Hotel in [[Philadelphia]] and the Radisson Hotel at [[Chicago]]’s [[O’Hare International Airport]], amongst others.<ref>{{cite web|work =New York Times |title= In The Castskill Region The Long Wait For A Casino Is Over |url =https://www.nytimes.com/2014/12/19/nyregion/in-the-catskills-the-long-wait-for-a-casino-is-over.html?_r=0}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|work =Times Union |title= If State Is To Blame We’ll Pay The Price |url =http://www.timesunion.com/local/article/James-Odato-If-state-is-to-blame-we-ll-pay-price-5709744.php}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|work =The Free Library |title= Hospitality Worldwide Services To Establish Divisional Structure |url =http://www.thefreelibrary.com/Hospitality+Worldwide+Services+establishes+divisional+structure+to...-a019251629}}</ref> In 1996 he formed Catskill Development, LLC and purchased [[Monticello Racetrack]].<ref>{{cite web|work = New York Times |title = In Catskills, the Long Wait for a Casino Nears an End |url = https://www.nytimes.com/2014/12/19/nyregion/in-the-catskills-the-long-wait-for-a-casino-is-over.html?_r=0 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|work = Times Union |title =James Odato: If state is to blame, we'll pay price |url = http://www.timesunion.com/local/article/James-Odato-If-state-is-to-blame-we-ll-pay-price-5709744.php}}</ref> During this time Berman worked towards building a Casino in partnership with the [[St. Regis Mohawk Reservation]] Tribe of [[New York (state)|New York]].<ref>{{cite web|work =New York Times |title = Against All Odds, a Complicated Casino Proposal Advances |url = https://www.nytimes.com/2000/04/17/nyregion/against-all-odds-a-complicated-casino-proposal-advances.html?pagewanted=all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|work =NY Daily News |title= Castkill Casino Plan War with Trump Lose Big |url =http://www.nydailynews.com/archives/news/catskill-casino-plan-war-trump-atlantic-city-lose-big-article-1.5143670}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|work =LA Times|title= Casino Project |url =http://articles.latimes.com/1998/apr/05/local/me-36103}}</ref> In 2002 Stanley Tollman, founder o [[The Travel Corporation]], assigned Berman to manage Alpha Hospitality, a public company directed by Tollman that aimed at administering a Casino for the [[Mohawk tribe]]. In 2003 he merged Catskill Development with Alpha Hospitality, creating [[Empire Resorts]].
From 2002 to 2005, Berman served as Chairman and Chief Executive Officer for [[Empire Resorts]], a publicly traded [[NASDAQ]] (“NYNY”) gaming company.<ref>{{cite web|work =Businesswire |title= Empire Resorts Announces Departure of Robert Berman |url =http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20051012005967/en/Empire-Resorts-Announces-Departure-Robert-Berman }}</ref> Berman is also General Partner of Avon Road Partners, LP a private entity that owns Real Estate and broadcast assets including [[WVOS (AM)]] & FM.<ref>{{cite web|work =Record Online |title= News |url =http://www.recordonline.com/article/20120408/biz/204080314}}</ref> In March 2016, Berman and James (Jim) McCarthy founded KeyStone Solutions, Inc.<ref>{{cite web|work =Village Voice |title= Casino Project |url =http://www.villagevoice.com/news/the-new-dealer-6425312}}</ref>
==Donald Trump controversy== In 1993 Berman began a project involving an Internet lottery venture in collaboration with the [[Coeur d'Alene people]] tribe in [[Idaho]].<ref>{{cite web|work =The Boston Globe |title = Casino case raises issues of money, politics |url = http://cache.boston.com/globe/nation/packages/gaming/casino_case_raises_issues_of_money_politics.htm}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|work =NY Daily News |title= Castkill Casino Plan War with Donald Trump |url =http://www.nydailynews.com/archives/news/catskill-casino-plan-war-trump-atlantic-city-lose-big-article-1.514367}}</ref> The project campaigned towards bringing [[Native Americans in the United States|Native American]] gaming to the [[Catskill Mountains|Catskill]] area.<ref>{{cite web|work =LA Times |title =Trump was once so involved in trying to block an Indian casino that he secretly approved attack ads |url = http://www.latimes.com/politics/la-na-pol-trump-anti-indian-campaign-20160630-snap-story.html}}</ref> This led to federal approval to build the [[St. Regis Mohawk]] casino at [[Monticello Raceway]] in 2000, which caused rivalry with other regional casino owners, particularly [[Donald Trump]].<ref>{{cite web|work = Forbes |title = Cancer And The Presidency: Why This CEO Says Each Candidate Needs A Plan |url = https://www.forbes.com/sites/arleneweintraub/2016/03/30/cancer-and-the-presidency-why-this-ceo-says-each-candidate-needs-a-plan/#484024672927 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|work =Record Online |title= News |url =http://www.recordonline.com/article/20120408/biz/204080314}}</ref> Trump funded an ad campaign to block the casino from being built by targeting the [[Mohawk people|Mohawk]] tribe.<ref>{{cite web|work = New York Times |title =In Catskills, the Long Wait for a Casino Nears an End |url = https://www.nytimes.com/2014/12/19/nyregion/in-the-catskills-the-long-wait-for-a-casino-is-over.html?_r=0}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|work =Wall Street Journal |title =Catskills Poised for Casinos |url = https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052702303936904579176201715452682}}</ref> Anti-Mohawk ads appeared in various newspapers suggesting the negative impact a [[Native Americans in the United States|Native American]] casino would have on the region. This resulted in [[Donald Trump]] receiving an unprecedented fine of $250,000 for secretly funding a lobbying campaign against Native American casinos.<ref>{{cite web|work =NY Daily News |title= Castkill Casino Plan War with Trump Lose Big |url =http://www.nydailynews.com/archives/news/catskill-casino-plan-war-trump-atlantic-city-lose-big-article-1.5143670}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|work =LA Times|title= Casino Project |url =http://articles.latimes.com/1998/apr/05/local/me-36103}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|work =Indianz |title= Donald Trump tried to bully his way into New York tribe's casino bid |url =http://www.indianz.com/IndianGaming/2016/04/18/donald-trump-tried-to-bully-hi.asp}}</ref>
==Native American gaming==
In 1994 Berman worked with the [[Coeur d'Alene people]] to device the National Indian Lottery via the [[Indian Gaming Regulatory Act]].<ref>{{cite web|work = Spokesman |title = Investors Line Up For Piece Of Tribe’s Action National Indian Lottery Needs Big Stake For Set-Up Costs |url = http://www.spokesman.com/stories/1995/apr/02/investors-line-up-for-piece-of-tribes-action/ }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|work = Reference for Business |title = Empire Resorts |url = http://www.referenceforbusiness.com/history/De-En/Empire-Resorts-Inc.html }}</ref> The project led to the creation of the [[Coeur d’Alene Casino]] in [[Idaho]] on land donated in trust to the tribe for the project.<ref>{{cite web|work = New York Times |title = Against All Odds, a Complicated Casino Proposal Advances |url = https://www.nytimes.com/2000/04/17/nyregion/against-all-odds-a-complicated-casino-proposal-advances.html }}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last=Davidson |first=Kirk |date=2003 |title= Selling Sin: The Marketing of Socially Unacceptable Products, 2nd Edition |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=-qQhMYLT7tgC&pg=PA77&dq=Coeur+D%27Alene+Casino+history&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwisopLr0MbQAhXEtxoKHSQzAvIQ6AEIOjAE#v=snippet&q=coeur%20d'alene&f=false |location= |publisher=Praege |page= |isbn=978-1567206456 }}</ref> Berman also worked with the [[Mohawk people]] to develop a casino in the [[Catskill Mountains|Catskill]] region, [[New York (state)|New York]].<ref>{{cite web|work = New York Times |title = Against All Odds, a Complicated Casino Proposal Advances |url = https://www.nytimes.com/2000/04/17/nyregion/against-all-odds-a-complicated-casino-proposal-advances.html }}</ref> In 1998 the [[National Indian Gaming Commission]] approved the project to develop and operate a gaming facility on tribal lands. In 1999 the [[Mohawk people]] signed the deal with [[Caesars Entertainment Corporation]] instead.<ref>{{cite web|work = Indian Country Today |title =Mohawk Catskills casino plans advance, backers survive a legal gauntlet |url = http://indiancountrytodaymedianetwork.com/2001/04/11/mohawk-catskills-casino-plans-advance-backers-survive-legal-gauntlet-86681 }}</ref> This led to a multibillion-dollar lawsuit that was eventually dismissed.<ref>{{cite web|work = Law Justicia |title = Catskill Development v. Park Place Entertainment, 144 F. Supp. 2d 215 (S.D.N.Y. 2001) |url = http://law.justia.com/cases/federal/district-courts/FSupp2/144/215/2316194/ }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|work = Gamber’s Corner |title = Park Place Entertainment Announces Filing of Sullivan County Casino Application |url = http://ww.gamblerscorner.com/read_article.php?site=Casinos&section=News&id=1417}}</ref>
==Personal life== Robert Berman has been married to Valerie J Berman since 2011. His previous spouse is Debbie N Berman, with whom he had two children, Alan Michael Berman and Jena Beth Berman. He and his family currently reside in Washington DC, US.
==See also==
* [[Monticello Raceway]] * [[Empire Resorts]] * [[Coeur d’Alene Casino]] * [[Native American gaming]]
==References==

revision.comment: Updating URL format for [[The New York Times]]
revision.text:
{{other people|Robert Livingston Gerry}} {{Infobox person | name = Robert L Gerry III | caption = | birth_name = Robert Livingston Gerry III | birth_date = {{birth date|1937|9|20}} | birth_place = [[New York City|New York]], [[New York (state)|New York]] | residence = [[Houston, TX]] | education = [[Brooks School]] | occupation = Petroleum industry executive | parents = [[Robert L. Gerry, Jr]]
Martha Leighton Kramer | spouse = Sandra Smith Judy Miller Gerry | children = Robert L. Gerry IV
Lloyd H. Gerry }} '''Robert Livingston "Bobby" Gerry III''' The first letter of his last name is pronounced with a hard "G" and sounds like "Gary". His father, [[Robert L. Gerry, Jr]], also went by Bobby Gerry. (born 20 September 1937) is a businessman and [[petroleum industry]] executive. ==Early life== Robert Livingston Gerry was born in New York City on September 20, 1937. He is the son of [[Robert L. Gerry, Jr]] (1911–1979) and Martha Leighton Kramer. His paternal grandparents were prominent [[thoroughbred]] horse breeders, [[Robert L. Gerry, Sr.]] (1877–1957) and Cornelia Averell Harriman (1884-1966). Gerry graduated [[Brooks School]], class of 1956. He is the nephew of horse breeder, [[Martha F. Gerry]], the great-nephew of U.S. Senator [[Peter G. Gerry]], Governor [[W. Averell Harriman]], and [[E. Roland Harriman]]. Gerry is the great-grandson of railroad baron [[Edward Henry Harriman]] as his paternal grandmother was E. H. Harriman's daughter, Cornelia. He is also the 3x-great grandson of [[Elbridge Gerry]], signer of the [[United States Declaration of Independence|Declaration of Independence]] and the [[List of Vice Presidents of the United States|5th]] [[Vice Presidents of the United States]]. ==Career== Gerry served two years of service in [[United States Army]].[https://www.nytimes.com/1963/10/06/archives/sandra-k-smith-bride-in-houston-of-broker-here-exaide-of-uogue-wed.html New York Times, October 6, 1963] Gerry was the COO of Nuevo Energy, Co. from March 1990 to 1994, and vice chairman until 1997.{{cite web|last1=Inc.|first1=VAALCO Energy,|title=VAALCO Names Robert L. Gerry, III Chairman and Chief Executive Officer|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/vaalco-names-robert-l-gerry-iii-chairman-and-chief-executive-officer-74861557.html|website=www.prnewswire.com|accessdate=28 February 2017|language=en}} Nuevo was eventually sold to [[Plains Exploration & Production|Plains Exploration & Production Co.]]{{cite web|title=Robert L. Gerry III|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/people/person.asp?personId=512466&privcapId=416628|website=Bloomberg.com|publisher=[[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]]|accessdate=28 February 2017}} From 1997 to October 2013, he served as the Chief Executive Officer of [[Vaalco Energy Inc.]], a public oil company.{{cite news|last1=Haines|first1=Leslie|title=Chatting With Bobby Gerry|url=http://www.oilandgasinvestor.com/chatting-bobby-gerry-801196|accessdate=28 February 2017|work=Oil and Gas Investor|date=June 1, 2015|language=en}} Vaalco's primary source of revenue is from the Etame field located offshore Gabon in West Africa. Members of Board of Vaalco at the time he was executive include former Ambassador [[William Stamps Farish III|Will Farish]] and Robert H. Allen. He is a member of the Board of Directors of [[Plains Exploration & Production Company]] since 2004. He has been a Trustee of [[Texas Children's Hospital]], Houston from 1991 until c. 2006. ==Personal life== In 1963, Gerry married Sandra Isabel Lloyd Smith,{{cite news|last1=Times|first1=Special To The New York|title=Sandra K. Smith Bride in Houston Of Broker Here; Ex-Aide of Uogue Wed to Robert Gerry 3d of Sullivan Co.|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9F02EFDF133CEF3BBC4E53DFB6678388679EDE&legacy=true|accessdate=28 February 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=6 October 1963}} the daughter of oil executive Lloyd Hilton Smith (1905–1999) and Elizabeth Keith Wiess,{{cite news|title=Paid Notice: Deaths SMITH, LLOYD HILTON|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1999/11/03/classified/paid-notice-deaths-smith-lloyd-hilton.html|accessdate=28 February 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=3 November 1999}}{{cite news|title=Sandra K. Smith Engaged to Wed Robert Gerry 3d; Staff Member of Vogue and a Brooks School Alumnus Affianced|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9A07EED9123DE63BBC4952DFB0668388679EDE&legacy=true|accessdate=28 February 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=11 June 1963}} and the granddaughter of Harry Wiess, a founder of [[Humble Oil]]. Before their divorce, they had two children: * Robert Livingston "Bobby" Gerry IV{{cite web|title=Alumni US {{!}} Austin, Texas Area|url=http://alumnius.net/the_university_of_te-9519-1416|website=alumnius.net|publisher=[[The University of Texas at Austin]]|accessdate=28 February 2017|language=en}} * Lloyd Harriman Gerry{{cite web|title=Lloyd Gerry {{!}} Leaders {{!}} WWF|url=http://www.worldwildlife.org/leaders/lloyd-gerry|website=World Wildlife Fund|accessdate=28 February 2017|language=en}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== *[http://images.businessweek.com/ss/06/05/hot_growth/source/2.htm?campaign_id=msnbc_Growth Profile of Robert L. Gerry III at BusinessWeek] *[http://info.hartwick.edu/library/archives/gerry/moreinfo.html Gerry family archive] at Hartwick College {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Gerry, Robert}} [[Category:1937 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Livingston family|Robert Livingston Gerry III]] [[Category:American chief operating officers]] [[Category:Gerry family]] [[Category:Brooks School alumni]]

revision.comment: Updating URL format for [[The New York Times]]
revision.text:
{{other people|Robert Livingston Gerry}} {{Infobox person | caption = | birth_name = Robert Livingston Gerry Jr. | birth_date = {{birth date|1911|12|5}} | birth_place = [[New York City|New York]], [[New York (state)|New York]] | death_date = {{death date|1979|12|21}} | death_place = [[New York City|New York]], [[New York (state)|New York]] | occupation = Businessman, polo player | parents = [[Robert L. Gerry Sr.]]
Cornelia Averell Harriman | spouse = Martha Leighton Kramer
Harriet Wells | children = Nancy Gerry
[[Robert L. Gerry, III]] | relations = [[Elbridge Thomas Gerry|Elbridge T. Gerry]] (grandfather)
[[E. H. Harriman]] (grandfather)
[[Mary Williamson Averell|Mary W. Averell]] (grandmother)
[[Peter G. Gerry]] (uncle)
[[W. Averell Harriman]] (uncle) }} '''Robert Livingston Gerry Jr.''' (December 5, 1911 – December 21, 1979) was an American [[polo]] player.{{cite news|last1=Times|first1=Special To The New York|title=Deaths|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1979/12/23/archives/obituary-3-no-title.html|accessdate=29 November 2016|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=23 December 1979}} ==Early life== Gerry was born in New York City on December 5, 1911 to [[Robert L. Gerry Sr.]] and Cornelia Harriman.{{cite news|last1=Times|first1=Special To The New York|title=Cornelia Harriman Gerry Bride|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1970/05/10/archives/cornelia-harriman-gerry-bride.html?_r=0|accessdate=29 November 2016|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=10 May 1970}} His eldest brother was [[Elbridge T. Gerry Sr.]] and his younger twin brothers were [[Henry Averell Gerry]] and [[Edward Harriman Gerry]]. Robert's father, a successful real estate developer, died at the family's estate, Aknusti, at the age of 81 on October 31, 1957,http://www.mi-harness.com/SBreds/Memor60.html just a few hours after his brother, former U. S. Senator [[Peter G. Gerry|Peter Goelet Gerry]], died in Providence, Rhode Island.{{cite news|last1=Times|first1=Special To The New York|title=Peter G. Gerry, Ex-Senator, Dies Hours Before His Brother Robert; Rhode Island Democrat, 78, Was a Foe of New Deal-- Supported Strong Navy|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1957/11/01/archives/peter-g-gerry-exsenator-dies-hours-before-his-brother-robert-rhode.html|accessdate=29 November 2016|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=1 November 1957}} ===Family=== Robert L. Gerry Jr. was the nephew of U.S. Senator [[Peter G. Gerry|Peter Goelet Gerry]], Governor [[W. Averell Harriman]], [[Junior League]] founder [[Mary Harriman]], and [[E. Roland Harriman]]. His maternal grandfather was railroad baron [[E.H. Harriman]] and his paternal great-great grandfather was [[Thomas Russell Gerry]], his great-great grandfather was [[Elbridge Gerry]], a signer of the [[United States Declaration of Independence|Declaration of Independence]] and [[Vice President of the United States]]. ==Sporting career== ===Polo career=== In 1929, he won the [[United States Polo Association|USPA]] Open National Interscholastic Championship. In 1933, he won the [[United States Polo Association|USPA]] Junior Championship and in 1938, he won the [[United States Polo Association|USPA]] Twenty Goal Championship. In 1938, he won the [[Monty Waterbury Cup|Monty Waterbury Memorial Cup]]. Gerry was a renowned [[polo]] player. He won the [[US Open Polo Championship]] twice, first in 1939 playing the #2 position for the Bostwick Field team, and second, in 1940 playing the #2 position for the Aknusti team. He lost in finals of 1941 championship while playing for the Aknusti team. From 1923 to 1941, all [[U.S. Open Polo Championship]] were played at Meadow Brook on [[Long Island]], New York.{{cite web |url=http://www.polomuseum.com/files/attachments/2015_historical_tournament_pages_0.pdf |title=USPA Historical Tournament Results |accessdate=2016-01-09 |quote=USPA Historical Tournament Results. |publisher=USPA }} The 1939 Bostwick Field team included [[Pete Bostwick]], Robert L. Gerry Jr., [[Elbridge T. Gerry Sr.]], [[Eric Horace Tyrrell-Martin]]. In the 1940 [[U.S. Open Polo Championship]] final, the Aknusti team beat Great Neck. The final score was a close 5 to 4. Playing for Aknusti that year were Gerald Smith, Robert L. Gerry Jr., [[Elbridge Gerry]], and [[Alan Corey Jr.]] The 1941 Aknusti team was composed of [[Elbridge T. Gerry Sr.]], Robert L. Gerry Jr., [[Edward H. Gerry]], and [[Pete Bostwick]]. In the U.S. Open finals, they played against Gulf Stream whose riders were [[Michael Grace Phipps]], [[John H. H. Phipps|Ben Phipps]], [[Charles Skiddy von Stade]], and [[Alan L. Corey Jr.]], who beat Aknusti 10–6.{{cite web |url=http://www.polomuseum.com/files/attachments/2015_historical_tournament_pages_0.pdf |title=USPA Historical Tournament Results |accessdate=2016-01-09 |quote=USPA Historical Tournament Results. |publisher=USPA }} ===Tennis career=== Also, an accomplished [[Court tennis]] player. Tuxedo Gold Racquet Singles Champion in 1946. Won the U.S. Amateur Doubles Championship in both 1949 and 1950 playing with [[Alastair Martin]]. Was a Charter Member of the [[United States Court Tennis Association]].[http://www.uscourttennis.org/fileadmin/user_upload/pdf/USCTA_AR_05-06-web.pdf USCTA Annual Report] ==Personal life== Gerry married Martha Leighton Kramer, daughter of A. Ludlow Kramer. Together, they had: *Nancy Gerry (born 1935){{cite news|title=Daughter to Mrs. R. L. Gerry Jr.|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1935/06/30/archives/i-daughter-to-mrs-r-l-gerry-jr-i.html|accessdate=29 November 2016|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=30 June 1935}} *[[Robert L. Gerry III]] (born 1937){{cite news|title=Son Born to Robert Gerrys Jr.|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1937/09/24/archives/son-born-to-robert-gerrys-jr.html|accessdate=29 November 2016|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=24 September 1937}} He later married Harriet Wells.{{cite news|last1=Times|first1=Special To The New York|title=Deaths|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1979/12/26/archives/obituary-4-no-title.html|accessdate=29 November 2016|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=26 December 1979}} Owned until his death was his sprawling {{convert|2000|acre|km2|sing=on}} estate "Aknusti" (later renamed Broadlands) in the rolling hills of [[Delaware County, New York]]. It has acreage in the townships of Andes, Delhi, and Bovina New York. It is an almost contiguous estate with a polo field, multiple working farms, a {{convert|20000|sqft|m2|abbr=on}}. mountain ridge sited colonial manor house designed by [[Walker & Gillette]], numerous dependencies, and landscaping done by [[Frederick Law Olmsted]]. That property has since been sold multiple times although it remains intact and owned by [[Amanresorts]].http://www.allianceforbovina.org/AmanFactSheet_Sept07-afb.pdf ==References== ;Notes {{reflist|30em}} ;Sources *[http://www.longislandsurnames.com/genealogy/getperson.php?personID=I5227&tree=VanRensselaer Genealogy – Gerry family] *[http://info.hartwick.edu/library/archives/gerry/moreinfo.html Gerry family archive] at Hartwick College *[http://www.usopenpolo.com/06/history1930-1953.php U.S. Open Polo history] *[http://ca.encarta.msn.com/encnet/refpages/RefAuxArt.aspx?refid=461501486 1939 U.S. Open Polo Championship] *[http://www.time.com/time/archive/preview/0,10987,766183,00.html Time Magazine documentation of 1941 loss in U.S. Open finals] *[http://www.mi-harness.com/SBreds/Memor60.html Standardbred Horsemans Memorial] {{DEFAULTSORT:Gerry, Robert L. Jr.}} [[Category:1911 births]] [[Category:1979 deaths]] [[Category:Goelet family]] [[Category:Livingston family|Robert Livingston Gerry Jr.]] [[Category:American polo players]] [[Category:American real tennis players]] [[Category:Gerry family]]

revision.comment: +{{[[Template:Authority control|Authority control]]}} (1 source from Wikidata), [[WP:GenFixes]] on, using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
{{For|the former Republican state representative from Bossier Parish|Henry Burns}} {{Infobox State Representative | name=Timothy Gerard "Tim" Burns | image= | nationality=[[United States|American]] | office= [[Louisiana State Legislature|Louisiana State Representative for
District 89 (St. Tammany Parish)]] | term_start=2004 | term_end=2016 | preceded=[[Mitch Landrieu]] (then [[Orleans Parish, Louisiana|Orleans Parish]]) | succeeded=[[Reid Falconer]] | party=[[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] | birth_date={{birth date and age|1957|4|1}} | birth_place= | alma_mater=[[Tulane University]] | occupation=[[Lawyer|Attorney]] | residence=[[Mandeville, Louisiana|Mandeville]]
[[St. Tammany Parish, Louisiana|St. Tammany Parish]]
[[Louisiana]] | spouse=Single | children= | religion= | footnotes= }} '''Timothy Gerard Burns''' (born April 1, 1957), also known as '''Tim Burns''', is a tax attorney{{cite web|url=http://www.congress.org/bio/id/141590|title=Rep. Timothy Burns|publisher=congress.org|accessdate=August 28, 2011}} from [[Mandeville, Louisiana|Mandeville]], [[Louisiana]], who is a [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] former member of the [[Louisiana State Legislature|Louisiana House of Representatives]] for District 89 in [[St. Tammany Parish, Louisiana|St. Tammany Parish]]. Political web sites do not indicate Burns's place of birth. He holds three degrees from [[Tulane University]] in [[New Orleans, Louisiana|New Orleans]] — [[Bachelor of Arts]] in economics in 1979, [[Master of Business Administration]] in 1980, and [[Juris Doctor]] in 1983.{{cite web|url=http://ucsb.www.ucforcalifornia.org/bio/id/141590|title=Rep. Timothy Burns|publisher=ucforcalifornia.org|accessdate=August 28, 2011}} Burns is a [[Certified Public Accountant]] licensed in Louisiana.{{cite news |url = http://lagniappe.lcpa.org/Vizion5/viewer.aspx?issueID=37&pageID=12 |magazine = Lagniappe |volume = 40 |issue = 8 |page = 11 |title = Rep. Tim Burns, CPA |date = March 2015 |accessdate = 2015-04-12 }} Burns nearly won outright the five-candidate, all-Republican [[nonpartisan blanket primary]] held on October 4, 2003. He led with 6,152 votes (46.7 percent). Susan Bonnett, with 3,534 votres (26.8 percent) ran second.{{cite web|url=http://staticresults.sos.la.gov/10042003/10042003_Legislative.html|title=Louisiana primary election returns, October 4, 2003|publisher=staticresults.sos.la.gov|accessdate=August 28, 2011}} Bonnett withdrew from the pending [[general election]], and Burns won the seat outright. Burns was reelected without opposition in 2007. After the election of Republican [[Bobby Jindal]] as [[governor of Louisiana|governor]] in 2007, Burns soon entered the [[special election]] called to fill Jindal's term in [[Louisiana's 1st congressional district]]. His principal rival was newly elected [[Louisiana State Legislature|State Senator]] [[Steve Scalise]] of [[Jefferson, Louisiana|Jefferson]]. Burns accused Scalise of having used [[push poll]]ing to mislead voters in their congressional race. Under this system, a campaign contacts voters by telephone and asks probing questions which leave a negative impression of an opposing candidate. Scalise defended his poll from criticism by Burns: "We were running a public opinion survey this week conducted by the largest Republican polling firm in the country, Public Opinion Strategies. . . . conducted with a sample of 300 people, and it shows Scalise at 57 percent, Burns at 26 percent and undecided at 17 percent. The margin of error is 5.6 percent. We ran a fact-based public opinion survey, not a push poll."[http://www.nola.com/news/t-p/capital/index.ssf?/base/news-5/1205560202224150.xml&coll=1 Scalise defends integrity of GOP runoff survey- NOLA.com]{{dead link|date=March 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} In the March 8, 2008, Republican primary, which was a [[closed primary|closed election]] restricted to registered Republicans, Scalise polled 16,799 votes (48 percent). Burns received 9,631 votes (28 percent), and two other candidates, Ben Morris and David Simpson, shared some 24 percent of the ballots cast.{{cite web|url=http://staticresults.sos.la.gov/03082008/03082008_MultiParish.html|title=Louisiana election returns, March 8, 2008|publisher=staticresults.sos.la.gov|accessdate=August 28, 2011}} In the [[runoff election]] on April 5, Scalise easily prevailed, 19,338 (58 percent) to Burns's 13,958 (41.9 percent).{{cite web|url=http://staticresults.sos.la.gov/04052008/04052008_Congressional.html|title=Congressional election results, April 5, 2008|publisher=staticresults.sos.la.gov|accessdate=August 28, 2011}} Burns serves on these House committees: (1) Health and Welfare, (2) Judiciary, and (3) Transportation, Highways, and Public Works.{{cite web|url=http://www.freedomspeaks.com/official/41576/louisiana-(la)-state-representative-timothy-g-burns-%5Bla-house-of-representatives%5D|title=Louisiana State Representative Timothy G. Burns|publisher=freedomspeaks.com|accessdate=August 28, 2011}} In 2010, Burns was rated in his legislative voting record 100 percent by the [[Louisiana Association of Business and Industry]] and 89 percent from the [[Louisiana Family Forum]]. In 2009, he was rated 100 percent by the Louisiana [[Right to Life]] Federation{{cite web|url=http://www.votesmart.org/issue_rating_category.php?can_id=35573|title=Rep. Timothy G. "Tim" Burns|publisher=votesmart.org|accessdate=August 28, 2011}} Burns won his third and final term in the state House in the primary election held on October 22, 2011. He received 6,156 votes (69.1 percent) to 2,752 (30.9 percent) for his intraparty opponent, Pat Phillips.{{cite web|url=http://staticresults.sos.la.gov/10222011/10222011_Legislative.html|title=Louisiana primary election returns, October 22, 2011|publisher=staticresults.sos.la.gov|accessdate=October 22, 2011}} He was succeeded in January 2016 by another Republican, [[Reid Falconer]] of [[Madisonville, Louisiana|Madisonville]] in St. Tammany Parish, who defeated Pat Phillips in the primary election held on October 24, 2015. {{Portal bar|New Orleans|Louisiana|Law|Business and Economics|Politics}} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{S-start}} {{s-par|us-la-hs}} {{Succession box |before=[[Mitch Landrieu]] (then [[Orleans Parish, Louisiana|Orleans Parish]]) |title=[[Louisiana House of Representatives|Louisiana State Representative for
District 89 (St. Tammany Parish)]] Timothy Gerard "Tim" Burns |years=2004–2016 |after=[[Reid Falconer]]}} {{S-end}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Burns, Timothy}} [[Category:1957 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:American accountants]] [[Category:Louisiana lawyers]] [[Category:Louisiana Republicans]] [[Category:Members of the Louisiana House of Representatives]] [[Category:People from Mandeville, Louisiana]] [[Category:Tulane University alumni]]

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta)
revision.text:
:''For the European Union post, see [[European Commissioner for Trade]]'' '''Trade commissioner''' is the title of a government official whose primary duties are to promote international [[trade agreements]] and [[export]] trade programs on behalf of a national or regional government authority. Such envoys are normally posted abroad, often being permanently resident in the country or region to which they have been assigned, but in some cases are locally engaged employees. If assigned by an authority or organization lacking sovereignty, or if a local employee, a trade commissioner may not enjoy diplomatic status. The title Trade Commissioner is also used by some international organizations for the senior official responsible for trade.
==Countries with trade commissioners==
===Canada=== The [[Canadian Trade Commissioner Service]] has 150 offices in Canada and abroad, employing both Canadian citizens and foreign nationals with this title.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tradecommissioner.gc.ca|title=The Canadian Trade Commissioner Service}}</ref>
==International organizations with trade commissioners== The following international organizations have commissioners for trade and related issues:
*The [[Economic Community of West African States]] has a [https://archive.is/20121212215136/http://www.comm.ecowas.int/dept/stand.php?id=i__dep&lang=en Commissioner of Trade, Customs and Free Movement] *The [[EUCLID (Euclid University)]] has a Commissioner for Economic Development and Trade Diplomacy.]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.euclid.int/news.asp|title=EUCLID News}}</ref> *The [[European Union]]'s senior official for international trade is the [[European Commissioner for Trade]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ec.europa.eu/trade/|title=European Commission Trade Homepage}}</ref> *The [[Pacific Islands Forum]] Secretariat posts trade commissioners to Tokyo, Japan; Sydney, Australia; Auckland, New Zealand; and Beijing, China.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.forumsec.org/pages.cfm/economic-governance/forum-trade-offices/|title=Pacific Island Forum Secretariat Trade Offices}}</ref>
==References== <references/>
==See also==
* [[Commissioner]] * [[Conseiller Chargé des Investissements]]
==External links== *[http://www.wto.org/english/thewto_e/whatis_e/tif_e/org6_e.htm World Trade Organisation member countries] (Including links to each country's trade-related national website)
{{Diplomacy}}
[[Category:Diplomats by role]] [[Category:International trade]]
